content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, for the total gross loans and advances representing lease financing, it is reported net of unearned revenue and gross of provisions.
content.name: Assets Loans And Receivables Lease Financing Gross Total Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, for investments relating to life insurance business.
content.name: Assets Insurance Investments Relating To Life Insurance Business Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, for the net market excess of the investment in a life insurance subsidiary over the recognised net assets of that subsidiary.
content.name: Assets Insurance Excess Of Net Market Values In Subsidiaries Over Recognised Net Assets Of Subsidiary Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, for total depreciation/impairment for all fixed assets as defined by relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Assets Other Non Financial Assets Accumulated Depreciation And Impairment On APRA Defined Fixed Assets Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, for investments in real estate, where the earnings and capital value are dependent on cash flows generated by the property through sale or rental income.
content.guidance: Include land, dwellings and other building structures.
content.name: Assets Other Non Financial Assets Land And Buildings Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, for total depreciation and impairment for all property, plant and equipment items excluding information technology.
content.name: Assets Other Non Financial Assets Plant And Equipment Accumulated Depreciation Impairment Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, for the net amount of property plant and equipment, which includes furniture, equipment (excluding Information technology), re-modelling costs to existing premises, and interest capitalised during the period of construction of buildings in accordance with relevant Australian Accounting Standards. The net amount is calculated as gross property plant and equipment less accumulated depreciation/impairment.
content.name: Assets Other Non Financial Assets Plant And Equipment Net Total Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, for accumulated depreciation/impairment in total for all information technology assets except when it is treated as an intangible for accounting purposes for example, in audited financial statements.
content.name: Assets Other Non Financial Assets Information Technology Accumulated Depreciation Impairment Total Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, for accumulated depreciation/impairment relating to 'Other fixed assets'.
content.name: Assets Other Non Financial Assets Accumulated Depreciation And Impairment On Other Fixed Assets Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, for the total amount of accumulated amortisation and impairment losses of intangible assets with a finite life.
content.name: Assets Intangible Intangible Assets With A Finite Life Other Than Information Technology Accumulated Amortisation Impairment Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, for the total amount of accumulated impairment of intangible assets with an infinite life.
content.name: Assets Intangible Intangible Assets With An Infinite Life Other Than Information Technology Accumulated Amortisation Impairment Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, for interest accrued for but not yet received.
content.name: Assets Other Financial Assets Interest Receivable Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, for general insurance premiums and other receivables.
content.name: Assets Other Financial Assets General Insurance Premiums Receivable Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, for deferred acquisition costs relating to general insurance policies.
content.name: Assets Other Financial Assets Deferred Acquisition Costs Of General Insurance Policies Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, for the costs associated with debt raisings and other similar transaction related costs.
content.name: Assets Intangible Capitalised Expenses Comprising Of Costs Associated With Debt Raisings Or Funding Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, for the balance of securitisation establishment costs that are capitalised and deferred.
content.name: Assets Intangible Capitalised Expenses Comprising Of Securitisation Establishment Costs Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, for the origination fees and commissions deferred.
content.name: Assets Other Financial Assets Capitalised Loan Broker Mortgage Origination Fees Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, for those institutions that have broking activity (i.e. equity broking) with clients who are other than financial institutions, record the amount due from clients in relation to security settlement transactions. Do not include amounts receivable from financial institutions or clearing houses in relation to security settlements.
content.name: Assets Loans And Receivables Amounts Receivable From Clients Outstanding Security Settlements Amount

content.definition: For interpretation/definition of this item refer to the Australian Accounting Standards, as an example, see provided reference
content.guidance: Report Deferred Tax Assets arising out of tax losses in accordance with AASB 112.
content.name: Income Tax Deferred Tax Assets From Tax Losses Amount

content.definition: For interpretation/definition of this item refer to the Australian Accounting Standards, as an example, see provided reference
content.guidance: Report Deferred Tax Assets associated with the provisioning for asset impairment in accordance with AASB 112.
content.name: Income Tax Deferred Tax Assets From Specific Provision And General Reserve For Credit Losses Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of all securitised assets and assets involved in a fundraising arrangement that involves providing an interest in or over assets originated by the reporting entity.  

This information is in accordance with the relevant prudential standards and is to include:
(a) the securitised assets that meet the operational requirements for regulatory capital relief, and are excluded from the calculation of regulatory capital; 
(b)  assets backing fundraising arrangements, subject to prior notification under the relevant prudential standard, that do not meet the operational requirements for regulatory capital relief, is otherwise considered a non-complying securitisation or a secured funding arrangement which APRA requires to be treated as if on-balance sheet and are included in the on-balance sheet assets of a reporting entity (or member of its Level 2 consolidated group) for capital adequacy purposes under the relevant prudential standards, as appropriate; and
(c) the securitised assets that meet the operational requirements for regulatory capital relief, and that the reporting entity elects to treat as on-balance sheet assets for capital adequacy purposes under the relevant prudential standards, as appropriate.
content.name: Assets Securitised Assets And Assets Supporting Secured Funding Arrangements Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, for the deferred tax assets other than from tax losses, specific provision and general reserve for credit losses.
content.name: Income Tax Deferred Tax Assets Other Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the assets backing secured fundraising arrangements, subject to prior notification, that do not meet the operational requirements for regulatory capital relief as per the relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Assets Securitised Assets Backing Fundraising Arrangements Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the securitised assets that meet the operational requirements for regulatory capital relief that has been elected to be treated as on-balance sheet assets for capital adequacy purposes as per the relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Assets Securitised Meet Prudential Capital Relief Requirements Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the transferred assets that have been placed into securitisation warehouses, other warehouses and other short-term (less than one year in maturity) funding vehicles,. These assets may or may not be funded by commercial paper or other arrangements.
content.name: Assets Securitised Assets Held By Warehouses Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of an interest rate swap aimed at limiting basis risk as per relevant prudential standard.  

A basis swap includes a payment stream on one leg of the swap based on an observable market rate or index, and a payment stream on the other leg based on rates set by a party to the swap.

Derivatives are generally defined as those instruments/contracts, where the value is based on other products, and/or on prices associated with financial products. Derivative contracts involve:
- Future delivery, receipt or exchange of financial items such as cash or another derivative instrument; or
- Future exchange of real assets for financial items where the contract may be tradeable and has a market value.
The contracts can either be binding on both parties (e.g. as with a currency swap) or subject to the exercise by one party of a right contained within the contract (as with options).

Report this item regardless of whether favourable or unfavourable to the reporting entity.
content.name: Assets Derivative Financial Instruments Basis Swaps Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the of the total committed amount, or limit, of cash collateral lodged by the reporting entity to back its obligations under the facilities it has provided.
content.name: Assets Facilities Backed By Cash Collateral Notional Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, during the relevant period, of total securitisation income received, excluding income from derivatives.  This includes facility fee income, servicing fee income, excess spread income and all other income not previously reported.

Facility fee income is all fee income received by the reporting entity during the relevant period from facilities provided to securitisation programs.  Income received from holding the residual units or other excess spread arrangements in a securitisation program are excluded.

Servicing fee income is all fee income received by the reporting entity during the relevant period from services provided to securitisation programs.   Income received from holding the residual units or other excess spread arrangements in a securitisation program are excluded.

Excess spread income is all income received during the relevant period from residual units or other excess spread arrangements.
content.name: Assets Securitisation Income Excluding Derivatives Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, during the relevant period, of net receipts or scheduled payments arising from basis swaps.

A basis swap is an interest rate swap aimed at limiting basis risk. For the purposes of the relevant prudential standard, a basis swap includes a payment stream on one leg of the swap based on an observable market rate or index, and a payment stream on the other leg based on rates set by a party to the swap.
content.name: Assets Derivative Financial Instruments Basis Swap Net Receipts Or Payments Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, during the relevant period, of the profit and loss impact due to the revaluation of basis swaps.

A basis swap is an interest rate swap aimed at limiting basis risk. For the purposes of the relevant prudential standard, a basis swap includes a payment stream on one leg of the swap based on an observable market rate or index, and a payment stream on the other leg based on rates set by a party to the swap.
content.name: Assets Derivative Financial Instruments Basis Swap Revaluation Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, during the relevant period, of the profit and loss impact due to basis swaps other than net receipts or payments and revaluation.

A basis swap is an interest rate swap aimed at limiting basis risk. For the purposes of the relevant prudential standard, a basis swap includes a payment stream on one leg of the swap based on an observable market rate or index, and a payment stream on the other leg based on rates set by a party to the swap.
content.name: Assets Derivative Financial Instruments Basis Swap Other Income Amount

content.definition: This is the value, during the relevant period, due to derivatives, excluding basis swaps, of net receipts or payments on scheduled payments.
content.name: Assets Derivative Financial Instruments Net Receipts Payments From Derivatives Excluding Basis Swaps Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, for the carrying value of purchased loan (e.g. mortgages) and credit card relationships when the reporting entity purchases the right to receive existing loan payments and credit card receivables in consideration for providing lending and credit card services to those customers. Also report any purchased loan/credit card servicing rights arising in the acquisition of an entire financial institution. The carrying value consists of the cost of the servicing right less accumulated amortisation for the right.
content.name: Assets Intangible Loan And Credit Card Servicing Rights Amount

content.definition: This is the value, during the relevant period, of the profit and loss impact due to derivatives, excluding basis swaps, other than net receipts or payments.
content.name: Assets Derivative Financial Instruments Revaluation From Derivatives Excluding Basis Swaps Amount

content.definition: This is the value, during the relevant period, of the securitisation income from derivatives excluding basis swaps, other than net receipts/payments and revaluation.
content.name: Assets Derivative Financial Instruments Other Derivatives Income Excluding Basis Swaps Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the securitisation special purpose vehicles (SPVs)/schemes or secured funding arrangements into which the reporting entity has sold, or otherwise originated loans during the reporting period.  Data are reported as at the effective date of the transaction.

An SPV is a financing vehicle that typically purchases and holds the pool for the purposes of a securitisation. The SPV's payment for the pool is typically funded by debt, including through the issue of units or securities by the SPV.
content.name: Assets Securitised Loans And Advances Sold Or Secured Funding Arrangements Amount

content.definition:
This is, as at the relevant date, the weighted average of the Loan to Valuation ratio (LVR) for the pool.  For any resecuritisation exposure in the pool, a reporting entity must look through to the underlying pools for that exposure in calculating the overall weighted average LVR.

A pool is the underlying exposure or exposures that are securitised by way of assignment or the transfer of rights and obligations to an SPV (special purpose vehicle). The pool may consist of, but need not be limited to, loans, bonds or equities.

A resecuritisation exposure is a securitisation exposure in which the risk associated with an underlying pool of exposures is tranched and at least one of the underlying exposures is a securitisation exposure. In addition, an exposure to one or more resecuritisation exposures is a resecuritisation exposure.
content.name: Assets Pool Loan To Valuation Ratio Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of derivative financial instruments as determined in accordance to relevant accounting standards.

Derivatives are generally defined as those instruments/contracts, where the value is based on other products, and/or on prices associated with financial products. Derivative contracts involve:
- Future delivery, receipt or exchange of financial items such as cash or another derivative instrument; or
- Future exchange of real assets for financial items where the contract may be tradeable and has a market value.
The contracts can either be binding on both parties (e.g. as with a currency swap) or subject to the exercise by one party of a right contained within the contract (as with options).

Report this item regardless of whether favourable or unfavourable to the reporting entity.
content.name: Assets Derivatives Amount
Assets Exposures Facilities And Derivatives Approved Limit Amount
Assets Exposures Facilities And Derivatives Drawn Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date,of the principal amount, or drawn amount, of cash collateral lodged by the reporting entity to back its obligations under the facilities it has provided.
content.name: Assets Facilities Backed By Cash Collateral Drawn Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the funding provided in exchange for the transferred loans, during the reporting period.  Data are reported as at the effective date of the transaction.

An SPV is a financing vehicle that typically purchases and holds the pool for the purposes of a securitisation. The SPV's payment for the pool is typically funded by debt, including through the issue of units or securities by the SPV.
content.name: Assets Securitised Loans And Advances Value Of Funding Received Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the securitisation special purpose vehicles (SPVs) or secured funding arrangements to which the reporting entity has provided new liquidity facilities, during the reporting period.

An SPV is a financing vehicle that typically purchases and holds the pool for the purposes of a securitisation. The SPV's payment for the pool is typically funded by debt, including through the issue of units or securities by the SPV.

Liquidity facilities are loan agreements entered into by a counterparty with the reporting party for the purpose of liquidity, being to fund any timing mismatches between receipts of fund on underlying exposures and payments on securities issued by the counterparty, or to cover the inability of the counterparty to roll-over securities due to market disruption.
content.name: Assets Loans And Advances Liquidity Facilities Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the securitisation special purpose vehicles (SPVs) or secured funding arrangements to which the reporting entity has provided new funding facilities, excluding warehouse, during the reporting period.

An SPV is a financing vehicle that typically purchases and holds the pool for the purposes of a securitisation. The SPV's payment for the pool is typically funded by debt, including through the issue of units or securities by the SPV.

Funding facilities, excluding warehouse, are loan agreements entered into by a counterparty with the reporting party for the purpose of funding purchases of exposures for a pool.
content.name: Assets Loans And Advances Funding Facilities Excluding Warehouse Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the securitisation special purpose vehicles (SPVs) or secured funding arrangements to which the reporting entity has provided new warehouse funding facilities during the reporting period.

An SPV is a financing vehicle that typically purchases and holds the pool for the purposes of a securitisation. The SPV's payment for the pool is typically funded by debt, including through the issue of units or securities by the SPV.

Warehouse funding facilities are loan agreements entered into by a counterparty with the reporting party for the purpose of funding to warehouse special purpose vehicles (SPVs).
content.name: Assets Loans And Advances Warehouse Funding Facilities Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the securitisation special purpose vehicles (SPVs) or secured funding arrangements to which the reporting entity has provided new lending facilities during the reporting period.

An SPV is a financing vehicle that typically purchases and holds the pool for the purposes of a securitisation. The SPV's payment for the pool is typically funded by debt, including through the issue of units or securities by the SPV.

Lending facilities are loan agreements entered into for the purpose of providing loans directly to investors to invest in securitisation programs.
content.name: Assets Loans And Advances Lending Facilities Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of derivative financial instruments, excluding basis swaps, as determined in accordance to relevant accounting standards during the reporting period.

Derivatives are generally defined as those instruments/contracts, where the value is based on other products, and/or on prices associated with financial products. Derivative contracts involve:
- Future delivery, receipt or exchange of financial items such as cash or another derivative instrument; or
- Future exchange of real assets for financial items where the contract may be tradeable and has a market value.
The contracts can either be binding on both parties (e.g. as with a currency swap) or subject to the exercise by one party of a right contained within the contract (as with options).


A basis swap includes a payment stream on one leg of the swap based on an observable market rate or index, and a payment stream on the other leg based on rates set by a party to the swap.
content.name: Assets Total Derivatives Excluding Basis Swaps Amount

content.definition: Balancing item for ARF120_2
content.name: Assets Exposures Facilities Other ARF120 2 Amount

content.definition: All transferred assets and exposures originated or sold by the reporting entity to a securitisation program that have been repurchased by the reporting entity during the reporting period.
content.name: Assets Securitisation Program Repurchased Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the outstanding principal amount, gross of provisions form impairment and including accrued interest of securitised assets and assets involved in fundraising arrangements.

Securitised assets are loans and advances that have been sold to or originated into securitisation programs, by or on behalf of the reporting party, or by a third party to a securitisation program sponsored by the reporting party, as at the relevant date.

Loans and advances are those financial assets categorised as 'Loans and Receivables' in the accounting standards, other than 'Trade Receivables' and 'Cash'.

A securitisation program represents a structure (a special purpose vehicle, or SPV) where the cash flows from a pool (of assets, or interests in assets) are used to service obligations to creditors (typically holders of debt securities) who fund the SPV.
     
A SPV is a 'bankruptcy-remote entity' with operations limited to the acquisition and financing of specific assets. Usually a subsidiary entity with balance sheet and legal status that makes its obligations secure even if the parent company goes bankrupt."

Assets involved in fundraising arrangements are the value of collateral which provides an interest in or over assets of the ADI to the funding provider.
content.name: Assets Securitised Loans And Advances Value Of Assets In Pool Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of any fair value gains and losses where the values do not meet the requirements for use of fair values specified in the relevant prudential standard.
content.name: Financial Risk Capital Adequacy Net Adjustments For Ineligible Unrealised Fair Value Gains Or Losses Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of regulatory capital for credit risk that are associated with cash collateral provided by the reporting entity to collateralise its obligations under liquidity and other facilities, in accordance with the relevant prudential standards. 

For the purposes of calculating risk-weighted assets, cash collateral amounts (where not treated as a drawn facility), together with the undrawn portion of the relevant facility (or credit equivalent amount), may be treated as overlapping securitisation exposures under the relevant prudential standard. 

Cash collateral can be lodged for securitisation and resecuritisation exposures.

Securitisation exposures are on-balance sheet and off-balance sheet risk positions held by a reporting entity arising from a securitisation including, but not limited to:

(i) investments by the reporting entity in securities issued by a special purpose vehicle (SPV), including retention of a subordinated tranche of securities issued by an SPV;

(ii) other credit enhancements, such as guarantees provided by the reporting entity;

(iii) drawn and undrawn funding, underwriting, liquidity and other facilities provided by the reporting entity to a securitisation; and

(iv) exposures arising from swaps and other derivative transactions with an SPV.

A resecuritisation exposure is a securitisation exposure in which the risk associated with an underlying pool of exposures is tranched and at least one of the underlying exposures is a securitisation exposure. In addition, an exposure to one or more resecuritisation exposures is a resecuritisation exposure.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Cash Collateral Amount

content.definition: This is, as at the relevant date, the exposure where the reporting entity does not have the information on the underlying collateral necessary to permit exposures to be risk weighted in accordance with the relevant prudential standards
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Exposures That Do Not Meet Due Diligence Requirements Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, for the reporting of  suspense or unreconciled/unidentified transactions/balances. It is recommended that the institution's internal procedures be adopted regarding the recording and reporting of these types of balances.
content.name: Assets Items In Suspense Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of credit exposures (on and off-balance sheet) arising from senior positions.

An exposure is treated as a senior tranche if it is effectively secured by a first claim on the entire amount of the exposures in the pool. For this purpose, the reporting party does not have to take into consideration taxes and similar imposts, fees to service providers, amounts due under interest rate swaps, currency swaps or eligible servicer cash advances.

A credit exposure represents an asset, liability, claim or commitment of an entity, which may be recorded on or off the balance sheet and which gives rise to credit risk.

Revolving facility exposures are those exposures arising from redrawable facilities, other than exposures in the nature of redrawable home loans where the amounts likely to be redrawn are expected to be immaterial relative to the size of the pool. Only exclude those revolving facility exposures where the reporting party has transferred a pool of the revolving exposures into a securitisation that contains an early amortisation provision.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Exposures Senior Positions Excluding Revolving Facilities With Early AmortisationProvision Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of credit exposures (on and off-balance sheet) arising from non-senior positions.

An exposure is treated as a senior tranche if it is effectively secured by a first claim on the entire amount of the exposures in the pool. For this purpose, the reporting party does not have to take into consideration taxes and similar imposts, fees to service providers, amounts due under interest rate swaps, currency swaps or eligible servicer cash advances.

A credit exposure represents an asset, liability, claim or commitment of an entity, which may be recorded on or off the balance sheet and which gives rise to credit risk.

Revolving facility exposures are those exposures arising from redrawable facilities, other than exposures in the nature of redrawable home loans where the amounts likely to be redrawn are expected to be immaterial relative to the size of the pool. Only exclude those revolving facility exposures where the reporting party has transferred a pool of the revolving exposures into a securitisation that contains an early amortisation provision.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Exposures Non Senior Positions Excluding Revolving Facilities With Early AmortisationProvision Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of securitisation (including resecuritisation) exposures relating to liquidity, underwriting or funding facilities.  A liquidity, underwriting or funding facility will be considered an eligible facility when it meets the requirements as  detailed in the relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Exposures Liquidity Or Underwriting Or Funding Facility Excluding Revolving With Early Amortisation Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of securitisation (including resecuritisation) exposures where the reporting entity, subject to a written approval from APRA, applies the approach detailed in the relevant prudential standard, to an eligible facility. The unrated facilities can not be subject to ratings-based approach (RBA),internal assessment approach (IAA) or supervisory formula (SF).
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Exposures Unrated Facilities Approved by APRA Excluding Revolving With Early Amortisation Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of short  positions in nth-to-default credit derivatives, calculated in accordance to the relevant prudential standards.

An nth-to-default credit derivative is a contract where the payoff is based on the nth asset to default in a basket of underlying reference instruments. Once the nth default occurs the transaction terminates and is settled.

Short positions represent positions where a fall in the value of the asset or derivative would result in a profit.
content.name: Financial Risk Market Nth To Default Credit Derivatives Short Position Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of short positions used for hedging the correlation trading portfolio which are neither securitisation exposures nor nth-to-default credit derivatives

Correlation trading is a strategy in which traders or investors take both long and short positions in credit correlation products such as synthetic CDOs and basket credit derivatives. Exposures reported under this category require special approval from APRA.

Short positions represent positions where a fall in the value of the asset or derivative would result in a profit.
content.name: Financial Risk Market Other Positions For Hedging The Correlation Trading Portfolio Short Position Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the Stressed Value at Risk (VaR) that would be generated if the market factors with the greatest influence on trading losses were experiencing a period of stress.   

Stressed VaR, like VaR is a technique used to estimate the likelihood of losses in a portfolio based on analysis of historical price movements and volatilities, over a specified observation period. For the stressed VaR however, the model inputs are calibrated to historical data from a one year observation period of significant market stress relevant to the portfolio being simulated.
content.name: Financial Risk Market Stressed VaR Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of total traded market risk, foreign exchange and commodities capital requirement (TFC capital requirement).   

It is calculated as the sum of the standard method charges for each asset class plus any charge reported under the internal model approach.  Specifically, it is the sum of the subtotals from the specific risk capital charge for non-securitisation exposures and the correlation trading portfolio, plus the sum of:
a) The capital charges (long positions) for securitisation and resecuritisation exposures; and
b)  The capital charges (short positions) for securitisation and resecuritisation exposures.
content.name: Financial Risk Market Capital Charge Standard Method Interest Rate Risk Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the regulatory capital default and migration risk on trading book positions that is incremental to the risk captured by the Value at Risk (VaR) based calculation of the reporting party. This item is to be reported where the VaR measures include an estimation of the specific risk charge, and is to be determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards
content.name: Financial Risk Market Incremental Risk Charge Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the capital charge for the reporting entity's correlation trading portfolio as determined by the comprehensive approach, in accordance with relevant prudential standards. The comprehensive approach is an internal model approach that captures all price risks related to correlation trading portfolios.
content.name: Financial Risk Market Comprehensive Risk Charge Correlation Trading Portfolio Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the effect on long positions in physical (or non-derivative) exposures, due to movements in the current credit spreads and market prices as specified in the credit spread scenarios. This represents the change in value of these positions given stress testing scenarios applied.

All trading book positions which have credit spread risk (including, but not limited to: corporate bonds, floating rate notes, credit derivatives, credit indices, and securitisations) must be included in the credit spread stress test portfolio revaluations. Many products with credit spread risk will have been priced at a spread over a relevant benchmark.
content.name: Financial Risk Market Long Credit Exposures Physicals Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the effect on long positions in derivative exposures, excluding credit indices, due to movements in the current credit spreads and market prices as specified in the credit spread scenarios. This represents the change in value of these positions given stress testing scenarios applied.

All trading book positions which have credit spread risk (including, but not limited to: corporate bonds, floating rate notes, credit derivatives, credit indices, and securitisations) must be included in the credit spread stress test portfolio revaluations. Many products with credit spread risk will have been priced at a spread over a relevant benchmark.
content.name: Financial Risk Market Long Credit Exposures Derivatives Excluding Credit Indices Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the effect on long positions in credit indices exposures, due to movements in the current credit spreads and market prices as specified in the credit spread scenarios. This represents the change in value of these positions given stress testing scenarios applied.

All trading book positions which have credit spread risk (including, but not limited to: corporate bonds, floating rate notes, credit derivatives, credit indices, and securitisations) must be included in the credit spread stress test portfolio revaluations. Many products with credit spread risk will have been priced at a spread over a relevant benchmark.
content.name: Financial Risk Market Long Credit Exposures Credit Indices Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the effect on short positions in physical (or non-derivative) exposures, due to movements in the current credit spreads and market prices as specified in the credit spread scenarios. This represents the change in value of these positions given stress testing scenarios applied.

All trading book positions which have credit spread risk (including, but not limited to: corporate bonds, floating rate notes, credit derivatives, credit indices, and securitisations) must be included in the credit spread stress test portfolio revaluations. Many products with credit spread risk will have been priced at a spread over a relevant benchmark.
content.name: Financial Risk Market Short Credit Exposures Physicals Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the effect on short positions in derivative exposures, excluding credit indices, due to movements in the current credit spreads and market prices as specified in the credit spread scenarios. This represents the change in value of these positions given stress testing scenarios applied.

All trading book positions which have credit spread risk (including, but not limited to: corporate bonds, floating rate notes, credit derivatives, credit indices, and securitisations) must be included in the credit spread stress test portfolio revaluations. Many products with credit spread risk will have been priced at a spread over a relevant benchmark.
content.name: Financial Risk Market Short Credit Exposures Derivatives Excluding Credit Indices Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the effect on short positions in credit indices exposures, due to movements in the current credit spreads and market prices as specified in the credit spread scenarios. This represents the change in value of these positions given stress testing scenarios applied.

All trading book positions which have credit spread risk (including, but not limited to: corporate bonds, floating rate notes, credit derivatives, credit indices, and securitisations) must be included in the credit spread stress test portfolio revaluations. Many products with credit spread risk will have been priced at a spread over a relevant benchmark.
content.name: Financial Risk Market Short Credit Exposures Credit Indices Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the stressed value at risk (VaR) for positions giving rise to interest rate risk, as determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.

Interest rate positions include both on and off-balance sheet exposures which are affected by changes in interest rates. This includes holdings of, or positions in:
     - debt securities, including non-convertible preference shares and other quasi-debt securities/instruments that behave like debt (convertible bonds are to be included as debt securities if they trade like debt securities, but not if they trade like equities);
     - forward transactions in foreign exchange, equities and commodities; and
     - options that are subject to a change in value following a change in interest rates.

Stressed VaR, like VaR is a technique used to estimate the likelihood of losses in a portfolio based on analysis of historical price movements and volatilities, over a specified observation period. For the stressed VaR however, the model inputs are calibrated to historical data from a one year observation period of significant market stress relevant to the portfolio being simulated.
content.name: Financial Risk Market Stressed VaR Interest Rate Positions Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the stressed value at risk (VaR) for positions giving rise to equity risk, as determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.

Equity positions include both on and off-balance sheet exposures which are affected by changes in equity price. This includes holdings of, or positions in:
     - ordinary shares, whether voting or non-voting;
     - convertible securities that behave like equities;
     - commitments to buy or sell equity securities; and
     - any other instruments that exhibit market behaviour similar to equities.

Stressed VaR, like VaR is a technique used to estimate the likelihood of losses in a portfolio based on analysis of historical price movements and volatilities, over a specified observation period. For the stressed VaR however, the model inputs are calibrated to historical data from a one year observation period of significant market stress relevant to the portfolio being simulated.
content.name: Financial Risk Market Stressed VaR Equity Positions Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the stressed value at risk (VaR), calculated as at the relevant date, for positions giving rise to foreign exchange risk, as determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.

Foreign exchange positions include on and off-balance sheet exposures which are affected by changes in foreign exchange rates. This includes holdings of, or positions in:
(a) the net spot position, i.e. all asset items less all liability items, including accrued interest and other accrued income and accrued expenses, denominated in the currency in question; 
(b) the net forward position, i.e. all amounts to be received less all amounts to be paid under forward foreign exchange transactions, including currency futures, the principal on currency swaps not included in the spot position, and interest rate transactions such as futures and swaps denominated in a foreign currency; This amount should represent the value of positions at current spot market exchange rates or using net present values;
(c) guarantees (and similar instruments) that are certain to be called and likely to be irrecoverable; and 
(d) any other item representing a profit or loss in foreign currencies.

For the purposes of this item:
- include unearned but expected future interest and anticipated expenses if the amounts are certain and the reporting party has hedged them; and
- exclude structural positions where permitted by the relevant prudential standards.

Stressed VaR, like VaR is a technique used to estimate the likelihood of losses in a portfolio based on analysis of historical price movements and volatilities, over a specified observation period. For the stressed VaR however, the model inputs are calibrated to historical data from a one year observation period of significant market stress relevant to the portfolio being simulated.
content.name: Financial Risk Market Stressed VaR Foreign Exchange Positions Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the stressed value at risk (VaR), calculated as at the relevant date, for positions giving rise to commodities risk, as determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.

Commodity positions include both on and off-balance sheet exposures which are affected by changes in commodity prices. This includes holdings of, or positions in:
     - commodity forwards;
     - commodity futures; 
     - commodity swaps; and
     - other applicable commodity instruments (e.g. commodity options).


Stressed VaR, like VaR is a technique used to estimate the likelihood of losses in a portfolio based on analysis of historical price movements and volatilities, over a specified observation period. For the stressed VaR however, the model inputs are calibrated to historical data from a one year observation period of significant market stress relevant to the portfolio being simulated.
content.name: Financial Risk Market Stressed VaR Commodities Positions Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the average stressed value at risk (VaR), calculated over the most recent 60 trading days prior to and including the relevant date, for positions giving rise to interest rate risk.

Interest rate positions include both on and off-balance sheet exposures which are affected by changes in interest rates. This includes holdings of, or positions in:
     - debt securities, including non-convertible preference shares and other quasi-debt securities/instruments that behave like debt (convertible bonds are to be included as debt securities if they trade like debt securities, but not if they trade like equities);
     - forward transactions in foreign exchange, equities and commodities; and
     - options that are subject to a change in value following a change in interest rates.

Stressed VaR, like VaR is a technique used to estimate the likelihood of losses in a portfolio based on analysis of historical price movements and volatilities, over a specified observation period. For the stressed VaR however, the model inputs are calibrated to historical data from a one year observation period of significant market stress relevant to the portfolio being simulated.
content.name: Financial Risk Market Average Stressed VaR Past 60 Trading Days Interest Rate Positions Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the stressed Value at Risk (VaR) calculated over the most recent 60 trading days prior to and including the relevant date, for positions giving rise to market risk.

Equity positions include both on and off-balance sheet exposures which are affected by changes in equity price. This includes holdings of, or positions in:
     - ordinary shares, whether voting or non-voting;
     - convertible securities that behave like equities;
     - commitments to buy or sell equity securities; and
     - any other instruments that exhibit market behaviour similar to equities.

content.name: Financial Risk Market Average Stressed VaR Past 60 Trading Days Equity Positions Amount

content.definition:

Foreign exchange positions include on and off-balance sheet exposures which are affected by changes in foreign exchange rates. This includes holdings of, or positions in:

content.name: Financial Risk Market Average Stressed VaR Past 60 Trading Days Foreign Exchange Positions Amount
Financial Risk Market Average Stressed VaR Past 60 Trading Days Commodity Positions Amount

content.definition:
Report the average stressed value at risk (VaR), calculated over the most recent 60 trading days prior to and including the relevant date, for positions giving rise to market risk, as determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.

Stressed VaR, like VaR is a technique used to estimate the likelihood of losses in a portfolio based on analysis of historical price movements and volatilities, over a specified observation period. For the stressed VaR however, the model inputs are calibrated to historical data from a one year observation period of significant market stress relevant to the portfolio being simulated.
content.name: Financial Risk Market Average Stressed VaR Past 60 Trading Days Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, for the average stressed Value at Risk (VaR) for positions giving rise to interest rate risk. This represents the average VaR, calculated over the most recent 60 trading days prior to and including the relevant date, multiplied by the scaling factor applicable.

Interest rate positions include both on and off-balance sheet exposures which are affected by changes in interest rates. This includes holdings of, or positions in:
     - debt securities, including non-convertible preference shares and other quasi-debt securities/instruments that behave like debt (convertible bonds are to be included as debt securities if they trade like debt securities, but not if they trade like equities);
     - forward transactions in foreign exchange, equities and commodities; and
     - options that are subject to a change in value following a change in interest rates.


Stressed VaR, like VaR is a technique used to estimate the likelihood of losses in a portfolio based on analysis of historical price movements and volatilities, over a specified observation period. For the stressed VaR however, the model inputs are calibrated to historical data from a one year observation period of significant market stress relevant to the portfolio being simulated.
content.name: Financial Risk Market Scaled Average Stressed VaR Past 60 Trading Days Interest Rate Positions Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, for the average stressed Value at Risk (VaR) for positions giving rise to equity position risk, as determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards. This represents the average VaR, calculated over the most recent 60 trading days prior to and including the relevant date, multiplied by the scaling factor applicable.

Equity positions include on and off-balance sheet exposures which are affected by changes in Equity prices. This includes holdings of, or positions in:
     - ordinary shares, whether voting or non-voting;
     - convertible securities that behave like equities;
     - commitments to buy or sell equity securities; and
     - any other instruments that exhibit market behaviour similar to equities.

content.name: Financial Risk Market Scaled Average Stressed VaR Past 60 Trading Days Equity Positions Amount

content.name: Financial Risk Market Scaled Average Stressed VaR Foreign Exchange Positions Amount

     - commodity forwards;

content.name: Financial Risk Market Scaled Average Stressed VaR Commodity Excluding Gold Position Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, calculated as at the relevant date, of the Stressed Value at Risk (VaR) method capital requirement, as determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.

The capital requirement is the larger of 'End of Period Stressed VaR' and 'Scaled Average Stressed VaR' across asset classes plus the 'Incremental Default Risk Charge'.

Stressed VaR, like VaR is a technique used to estimate the likelihood of losses in a portfolio based on analysis of historical price movements and volatilities, over a specified observation period. For the stressed VaR however, the model inputs are calibrated to historical data from a one year observation period of significant market stress relevant to the portfolio being simulated. 

Scaled average Stressed VaR represents the average Stressed VaR, calculated over the most recent 60 trading days prior to and including the relevant date, multiplied by the scaling factor applicable.
content.name: Financial Risk Market Stressed VaR Capital Charge Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of long  positions in nth-to-default credit derivatives, calculated in accordance to the relevant prudential standards.

An nth-to-default credit derivative is a contract where the payoff is based on the nth asset to default in a basket of underlying reference instruments. Once the nth default occurs the transaction terminates and is settled.

Long positions represent positions where a rise in the value of the asset or derivative would result in a profit.
content.name: Financial Risk Market Nth To Default Credit Derivatives Long Position Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of long positions used for hedging the correlation trading portfolio which are neither securitisation exposures nor nth-to-default credit derivatives

Correlation trading is a strategy in which traders or investors take both long and short positions in credit correlation products such as synthetic CDOs and basket credit derivatives. Exposures reported under this category require special approval from APRA.

Long positions represent positions where a rise in the value of the asset or derivative would result in a profit.
content.name: Financial Risk Market Other Positions For Hedging The Correlation Trading Portfolio Long Position Amount

content.definition:
This is, as at the relevant date, the scaling factor for the stressed Value at Risk (VaR) applicable, for positions giving rise to market risk.

Stressed VaR, like VaR is a technique used to estimate the likelihood of losses in a portfolio based on analysis of historical price movements and volatilities, over a specified observation period. For the stressed VaR however, the model inputs are calibrated to historical data from a one year observation period of significant market stress relevant to the portfolio being simulated.

The scaling factor consists of a multiplication factor and a plus factor, as determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards. The multiplication factor is set for each reporting party by APRA, and is subject to a minimum of three. A plus factor may also be required by APRA. This factor relates directly to back-testing results from the most recent 250 trading days prior to the relevant date.

Interest rate positions include both on and off-balance sheet exposures which are affected by changes in interest rates. This includes holdings of, or positions in:
     - debt securities, including non-convertible preference shares and other quasi-debt securities/instruments that behave like debt (convertible bonds are to be included as debt securities if they trade like debt securities, but not if they trade like equities);
     - forward transactions in foreign exchange, equities and commodities; and
     - options that are subject to a change in value following a change in interest rates.

Back-testing represents the process of comparing the daily trading outcome (profit or loss) with the corresponding stressed VaR number for that day.
content.name: Financial Risk Market Scaling Factor Stressed VaR Interest Rate Positions Number

This factor relates directly to back-testing results from the most recent 250 trading days prior to the relevant date.

Back-testing represents the process of comparing the daily trading outcome (profit or loss) with the corresponding stressed VaR number for that day.
content.name: Financial Risk Market Scaling Factor Stressed VaR Equity Positions Number

content.definition:
Report the scaling factor Stressed Value at Risk (VaR) applicable.

The scaling factor (stressed VaR) consists of a multiplication factor and a plus factor, as determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards. The multiplication factor is set for each reporting party by APRA, and is subject to a minimum of three. A plus factor may also be required by APRA. This factor relates directly to back-testing results from the most recent 250 trading days prior to the relevant date.

Back-testing represents the process of comparing the daily trading outcome (profit or loss) with the corresponding stressed VaR number for that day.
content.name: Financial Risk Market Scaling Factor Stressed VaR Number

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the component of other equity investments which are purchased goodwill and other intangible assets.
Equity securities are, as defined by the Australian Accounting Standards, contracts that evidence a residual interest in the assets of an entity after deducting all its liabilities. This includes equity securities lent or sold by the entity under repurchase agreements, where the transaction does not result in the transfer of the rights of ownership of the securities away from the entity to another party.
content.name: Assets Goodwill And Intangible Assets Other GRF300 Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the component of other equity investments which are not purchased goodwill and other intangible assets.
Equity securities are, as defined by the Australian Accounting Standards, contracts that evidence a residual interest in the assets of an entity after deducting all its liabilities. This includes equity securities lent or sold by the entity under repurchase agreements, where the transaction does not result in the transfer of the rights of ownership of the securities away from the entity to another party.
content.name: Assets Net Tangible Assets Other GRF300 Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of any other items which form the total of net premiums liabilities as per relevant accounting standards.  This would include deferred reinsurance exchange commission, unearned commission revenue and deferred levies and charges.
content.name: Liabilities Insurance Net Premium Liabilities Other GRF210 1A And 1B Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of recoveries receivable by the reporting party in relation to Outstanding Claims Liability (OCL) other than reinsurance recoveries, gross of related input tax credit, and net of any provisions for depreciation or impairment.

OCL relates to all claims incurred prior to the valuation date, whether or not they have been reported to the reporting party. The value of the OCL must include an amount in respect of the expenses that the reporting party expects to incur in settling these claims. The value of OCL must not include any Government charges directly imposed on the reporting party such as levies, duties and taxes, but must be gross of input tax credit recoveries.
content.name: Assets Loans And Receivables Outstanding Claims Liability Recoveries Not Reinsurance Gross Input Tax Credit Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of recoveries receivable by the reporting party in relation to paid insurance claims other than reinsurance recoveries, gross of related input tax credit, and net of any provisions for depreciation or impairment.
content.name: Assets Loans And Receivables Insurance Recoveries Not Reinsurance Paid Claims Gross Input Tax Credit Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, that Specialist Credit Card Institutions can charge back to the merchant under the card scheme rules as a result of disputes or fraud.
content.name: Assets Credit Card Chargebacks Paid To Card Issuers Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the difference between the value of the assets/liabilities as determined per the relevant Accounting Standards and the fair value of those assets/liabilities as determined in accordance with relevant Prudential Standards.
content.name: Assets Adjustments Fair Value Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, for amounts payable by the reporting party to clearing houses for unsettled exchanges of securities and derivatives. This item arises only if the reporting institution records securities on a settlement date basis as opposed to trade date basis.
content.name: Liabilities Other Financial Liabilities Due To Clearing Houses Total Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of indexed debt securities including income accrued but not received. This method of disclosure differs from the Australian Accounting Standards.

Debt securities are transferable instruments evidencing a relationship of indebtedness. It is characterised by having a definable income stream that is not based on the economic performance of the issuing entity.

Indexed debt securities pay an income stream that is dependent on an external factor.
content.name: Assets Debt Securities Plus Accrued Income Indexed Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of non-indexed debt securities, including income accrued but not received. This method of disclosure differs from the Australian Accounting Standards.

Debt securities are transferable instruments evidencing a relationship of indebtedness. It is characterised by having a definable income stream that is not based on the economic performance of the issuing entity.

Non-indexed debt securities pay an income stream that is not dependent on any external factor.
content.name: Assets Debt Securities Plus Accrued Income Non Indexed Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of Deferred Tax Assets. This item is to be determined in accordance with relevant accounting standards.
content.name: Assets Deferred Tax Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of equity securities plus income accrued but not received. This method of disclosure differs from the Australian Accounting Standards. Equity securities are, as defined by the Australian Accounting Standards, contracts that evidence a residual interest in the assets of an entity after deducting all its liabilities.
content.name: Assets Equity Securities Plus Accrued Income Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of assets excluding deferred acquisition costs arising in respect of policies. This method of disclosure differs from the Australian Accounting Standards. Acquisition costs, as defined by the Australian Accounting Standards, are the fixed and variable costs of acquiring new business including commissions and similar distribution costs, and costs of accepting, issuing and initially recording policies.
content.name: Assets Excluding Deferred Acquisition Costs Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of counterparty exposures to assets as determined in accordance with relevant accounting standards. 

An exposure to a counterparty or a group of related counterparties is the aggregate of claims, commitments arising from on-balance sheet transactions with the all counterparties.

On-balance sheet refers to those assets, or exposure items, which are recognised or recorded on the statement of financial position of the reporting entity, as determined in accordance with relevant Accounting Standards.
content.name: Assets Exposures Counterparty Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of appropriate asset concentration limits determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Assets Concentration Limit Value Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of counterparty exposures to notes and coins; deposits withdrawable or redeemable within 24 hours; and securities purchased under agreements to resell.

An exposure to a counterparty or a group of related counterparties is the aggregate of claims and commitments arising from on-balance sheet transactions with all counterparties.

On-balance sheet refers to those assets, or exposure items, which are recognised or recorded on the statement of financial position of the reporting entity, as determined in accordance with relevant Accounting Standards.
content.name: Assets Exposures Cash And Liquid Assets Amount

content.definition:
This is a balancing item in the list in which it is being used. It is the value, as at the relevant date, of counterparty exposures to other assets. 

An exposure to a counterparty or a group of related counterparties is the aggregate of all claims, commitments arising from on-balance sheet transactions with the counterparty or group of related counterparties. 

On-balance sheet refers to those assets, or exposure items, which are recognised or recorded on the statement of financial position of the reporting entity, as determined in accordance with relevant Accounting Standards.
content.name: Assets Exposures Other Amount

content.definition: This is the value, of counterparty exposures to cash, after adjusting for derivatives. An exposure to a counterparty or a group of related counterparties is the aggregate of all claims, commitments arising from on-balance sheet transactions with the counterparty or group of related counterparties. On-balance sheet refers to those assets, or exposure items, which are recognised or recorded on the statement of financial position of the reporting entity, as determined in accordance with relevant Accounting Standards.
content.name: Assets Exposures Cash Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of counterparty exposures to debt securities at the reporting date. 

An exposure to a counterparty or a group of related counterparties is the aggregate of all claims, commitments arising from on-balance sheet transactions with the counterparty or group of related counterparties. 

Debt securities are transferable instruments evidencing a relationship of indebtedness. They are characterised by having a definable return that is not based on the economic performance of the issuing entity.

On-balance sheet refers to those assets, or exposure items, which are recognised or recorded on the statement of financial position of the reporting entity, as determined in accordance with relevant Accounting Standards.
content.name: Assets Exposures Debt Securities Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of counterparty exposures to derivative assets. 

This is forward-type contracts held by the reporting entity that are favourable (i.e. where it represents net gain to the reporting entity) or option type derivatives that are brought. Credit derivatives take the form of either forward-type and option-type contracts so include under assets either when the revaluation is favourable or when the credit protection is brought. This item is to be determined in accordance with accounting standards. A derivative is a financial instrument that is derived from some other asset, index, value or other variable (known as the underlying).

An exposure to a counterparty or a group of related counterparties is the aggregate of all claims, commitments arising from on-balance sheet transactions with the counterparty or group of related counterparties. 

On-balance sheet refers to those assets, or exposure items, which are recognised or recorded on the statement of financial position of the reporting entity, as determined in accordance with relevant Accounting Standards.
content.name: Assets Exposures Derivative Instruments Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date of counterparty exposures to equity securities. 

An exposure to a counterparty or a group of related counterparties is the aggregate of all claims, commitments arising from on-balance sheet transactions with the counterparty or group of related counterparties. 

Equity securities are, as defined by the Australian Accounting Standards, contracts that evidence a residual interest in the assets of an entity after deducting all its liabilities. This includes equity securities lent or sold by the entity under repurchase agreements, where the transaction does not result in the transfer of the rights of ownership of the securities away from the entity to another party.

On-balance sheet refers to those assets, or exposure items, which are recognised or recorded on the statement of financial position of the reporting entity, as determined in accordance with relevant Accounting Standards.
content.name: Assets Exposures Equity Securities Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of counterparty exposures to investment vehicles, which represent the net assets of unit trusts or managed investment schemes invested in by the reporting party, or mandates individually managed on behalf of the reporting entity.
content.name: Assets Exposures Investment Vehicle Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of counterparty exposures to loans and advances (including any accrued interest). 

Loans and advances are those financial assets categorised as "Loans and receivables" in the accounting standards other than "Trade receivables" and "Cash".

An exposure to a counterparty or a group of related counterparties is the aggregate of all claims, commitments arising from on-balance sheet transactions with the counterparty or group of related counterparties. 

On-balance sheet refers to those assets, or exposure items, which are recognised or recorded on the statement of financial position of the reporting entity, as determined in accordance with relevant Accounting Standards.
content.name: Assets Exposures Loans Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of counterparty exposures to non indexed interest bearing securities, after adjusting for derivatives. 

Non-indexed securities pay an income stream that is not dependent upon any external factor. 

Interest bearing securities are debt securities paying an income stream based upon an interest rate consistent with the classification and measurement basis used for investment securities in accordance with the accounting standards. 

An exposure to a counterparty or a group of related counterparties is the aggregate of claims, commitments arising from on-balance sheet transactions with the all counterparties. 

On-balance sheet refers to those assets, or exposure items, which are recognised or recorded on the statement of financial position of the reporting entity, as determined in accordance with relevant Accounting Standards.
content.name: Assets Exposures Non Indexed Interest Bearing Securities Adjusted For Derivatives Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date of counterparty exposures to property.

Property is defined in accordance with the classification and measurement basis under the relevant accounting standards.

An exposure to a counterparty or a group of related counterparties is the aggregate of all claims, commitments arising from on-balance sheet transactions with the counterparty or group of related counterparties. 

On-balance sheet refers to those assets, or exposure items, which are recognised or recorded on the statement of financial position of the reporting entity, as determined in accordance with relevant Accounting Standards.
content.name: Assets Exposures Property Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of counterparty exposures to receivables. 

An exposure to a counterparty or a group of related counterparties is the aggregate of all claims, commitments arising from on-balance sheet transactions with the counterparty or group of related counterparties. 

On-balance sheet refers to those assets, or exposure items, which are recognised or recorded on the statement of financial position of the reporting entity, as determined in accordance with relevant Accounting Standards.
content.name: Assets Exposures Receivables Amount

content.definition: This indicates whether the adjustment is approved by the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority for transitional purposes.
content.guidance:
A choice of TRUE/FALSE values.

true = The adjustment approved by the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority is transitional.

false = The adjustment approved by the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority is not transitional.
content.name: Financial Risk Adjustment Status Indicator

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the aggregation benefit which relates to the recognition of diversification benefits between asset risk and the sum of insurance risk and insurance concentration risk in the calculation of the prescribed capital amount. This item must be calculated in accordance with the prescribed formula in the relevant prudential standard.
content.name: Financial Risk Aggregation Benefit Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of aggregation benefit which relates to the recognition of diversification benefits between asset and insurance risks for life business other than variable annuities. This item must be calculated in accordance with the prescribed formula in the relevant prudential standard.
content.name: Financial Risk Aggregation Benefit Life Business Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of adjustments to the loan mortgage insurance concentration risk charge (LMICRC) as approved by APRA and in accordance to the relevant prudential standards
content.name: Financial Risk APRA Approved Adjustments To LMICRC Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date of adjustments for the risk charge, as approved by the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority.
content.name: Financial Risk Charge Adjustment Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of adjustment to capital due to a shortfall in a lower category of capital.  This item is calculated for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant Prudential Standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Capital Adequacy Adjustment Capital Shortfall Lower Category Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of deductions for investments in related parties that are subject to regulatory capital requirements in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Capital Adequacy Adjustment Investments Related Parties Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of adjustments to capital as approved by the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority.
content.name: Financial Risk Capital Adequacy Adjustments APRA Approved Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of assets already deducted from capital base. This item is calculated for capital adequacy purposes and is determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Capital Adequacy Capital Base Deductions Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of capital instruments issued by the reporting entity. This item is calculated for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant Prudential Standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Capital Adequacy Capital Instruments Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of capital instruments issued by the reporting party that are no longer complying and therefore being progressively de-recognised in the relevant capital categories for transitional purposes. This item is calculated for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant Prudential Standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Capital Adequacy Capital Instruments Transitional Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the reporting entity's direct, indirect and synthetic holdings of Capital instruments of other Authorised Deposit-taking institutions, or overseas equivalents and their subsidiaries, insurance companies and other financial institutions. For the purposes of this item, exclude:
(a) exposures acquired through underwriting of a new capital instrument and the exposure is disposed of within five days of the date of issue. If the exposure is not disposed of within five days of issuance, it must be reported; or
(b) exposures that are held under a legal agreement on behalf of:
* at Level 1 - an external third party, even if held in the name of the reporting entity; or
* at Level 2 - a party outside the Level 2 consolidated group, even if held in the name of the reporting entity (or another member of its Level 2 consolidated group).
This item is calculated for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant Prudential Standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Capital Adequacy Capital Investments Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the assets in cover pools that do not qualify for treatment of assets of the Authorised Deposit-taking Institution in accordance with the Banking Act.
content.name: Financial Risk Capital Adequacy Covered Bonds Assets Cover Pool Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the diversification factor that has been estimated between asset and insurance risks. This item is calculated for capital requirement (including hedging) and is to be determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Capital Adequacy Diversification Factor Number

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the effectiveness factor used to reflect the level of sophistication of the assumed model of dynamic hedging. This is calculated for capital requirements and is to be determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Capital Adequacy Effectiveness Factor Number

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of direct, indirect and synthetic equity exposures, guarantees and other capital support held by the reporting entity. For the purposes of this item, exclude equity exposures where:
(a) the equity exposure is acquired through underwriting of a new equity instrument and the equity instrument is disposed of within five days of the date of issue. If the equity instrument is not disposed of within five days of issuance, it must be reported; or
(b) the equity exposure is held under a legal agreement on behalf of:
* at Level 1 - an external third party, even if held in the name of the reporting entity; or
* at Level 2 - a party outside the Level 2 consolidated group, even if held in the name of the reporting entity (or another member of its Level 2 consolidated group).
This item is calculated for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant Prudential Standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Capital Adequacy Equity Exposures And Capital Support Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the cash flow hedge reserve that relates to the hedging of items that are not recorded at fair value on the accounting balance sheet (including projected cash flows).
content.name: Financial Risk Capital Adequacy Fair Value Gains Net Effective Cash Flow Hedges Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of guarantees and credit derivatives that provide for a materiality threshold below which no payment will be made in the event of a loss. This item is calculated for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant Prudential Standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Capital Adequacy Guarantees And Credit Derivatives That Provide Materiality Threshold Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the reporting entity's holdings of its own capital instruments, unless exempted by APRA. Include:

- any unused trading limit on these instruments where agreed with APRA
- instruments that the entity is obliged to purchase.

This item is calculated for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant Prudential Standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Capital Adequacy Holdings Of Own Capital Instruments Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of liability adjustments. The liability adjustment reflects the difference between the adjusted policy liabilities and the net policy liabilities and policy owners' retained profits for the purpose of determining the capital base under the relevant prudential standards. For the purposes of this item, include all tax effects arising from the liability adjustment.
content.name: Financial Risk Capital Adequacy Liability Adjustments Including Tax Effects Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of adjustments to capital, as approved by the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority.
content.name: Financial Risk Capital Adequacy Net Assets Adjustments APRA Approved Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of adjustments to capital, as required by relevant prudential standards.
