content.name: Financial Risk Capital Adequacy Net Assets Adjustments Regulatory Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of non-repayable loans advanced by the reporting entity under APRA's certified industry support arrangements.

This item is calculated for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Capital Adequacy Non Repayable Loans APRA Certified Industry Support Arrangements Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of adjusted policy liabilities. This item is determined for capital base purposes in accordance with the relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Capital Adequacy Policy Liabilities Adjusted Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the discretionary component of adjusted policy liabilities. This item is determined for capital base purposes in accordance with the relevant prudential and reporting standards. The discretionary component relates to the component of the policy liabilities whose valuation is subject to certain discretionary decisions made by the reporting entity.
content.name: Financial Risk Capital Adequacy Policy Liabilities Adjusted Discretionary Component Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of adjusted Probable Maximum Loss (PML). This item is to be determined in accordance with the relevant prudential standards. Probable Maximum Loss (PML) is the largest gross loss to which an insurer will be exposed (taking into account the probability of that loss) due to a concentration of risk exposures, without any allowance for potential reinsurance recoveries.
content.name: Financial Risk Capital Adequacy Probable Maximum Loss Adjusted Amount

content.definition: This is a balancing item in the list in which it is being used. This is the value, as at the relevant date, of adjustments to all other applicable securitisation related amounts. This item is calculated for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant Prudential Standards. A securitisation represents a structure where the cash flow from a pool is used to service obligations to at least two different tranches or classes of creditors (typically holders of debt securities), with each class or tranche reflecting a different degree of credit risk (i.e. one class of creditors is entitled to receive payments from the pool before another class of creditors).
content.name: Financial Risk Capital Adequacy Securitisation Related Adjustments Other Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of adjustments to cover undercapitalisation of a non-consolidated subsidiary (or subsidiaries) as required by the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority in accordance with the relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Capital Adequacy Undercapitalisation Non Consolidated Subsidiaries Adjustment Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the estimate of capital requirement, for variable annuities business, covering the associated insurance and asset risks under the combined scenario. The item excludes any hedging/risk mitigation arrangements, as determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards. Variable annuity means a policy with benefits calculated by reference to the value of the units allocated to the policy, but the benefits may exceed the value of those units in specified circumstances.
content.name: Financial Risk Capital Adequacy Variable Annuities Excluding Hedging Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the estimate of capital requirement, for variable annuities business, covering the associated insurance and asset risks under the combined scenario. This includes the effects of hedging/risk mitigation arrangements, as determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards. Variable annuity means a policy with benefits calculated by reference to the value of the units allocated to the policy, but the benefits may exceed the value of those units in specified circumstances.
content.name: Financial Risk Capital Adequacy Variable Annuities Including Hedging Amount
Financial Risk Credit Claims On Guaranteed By Secured Against Governments Central Banks Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of direct credit substitutes.
     
A direct credit substitute is any irrevocable off-balance sheet obligation that carries the same credit risk as a direct extension of credit, such as an undertaking to make a payment to a third party in the event that a counterparty fails to meet a financial obligation, or an undertaking to a counterparty to acquire a potential claim on another party in the event of default by that party (i.e. the risk of loss depends on the creditworthiness of the counterparty or the party on which a potential claim is acquired).
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Direct Credit Substitutes Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, for the risk weight of delivery-versus-payment (DvP) transactions that remain unsettled after their due delivery dates. The treatment of the exposure is in accordance to the relevant prudential standards.

Exclude repurchase and reverse-repurchase agreements as well as securities lending and borrowing.

Delivery-versus-payment transactions are those transactions of securities using a settlement mechanism which links the securities transfer and the funds transfer in such a way as to ensure that delivery occurs if, and only if, the corresponding payment occurs.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Unsettled Delivery Versus Payment Transactions Risk Weight Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the risk weight percent for non-delivery-versus-payment (non-DvP) transactions that remain unsettled after their due delivery dates. Delivery-versus-payment transactions are those transactions of securities using a settlement mechanism which links the securities transfer and the funds transfer in such a way as to ensure that delivery occurs if, and only if, the corresponding payment occurs. This item is to be determined in accordance with the relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Unsettled Non Delivery Versus Payment Transactions Percent

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date of adjustment for cumulative exposures, as determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Cumulative Exposures Adjustment Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of deductions to the Probable Maximum Loss (PML) for the net premium liability that relates to an economic downturn. This is to be determined in accordance to the relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Deductions For Net Premiums Liability Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the dividend yield of the S&P /ASX 200 index, used in determining the reduction in equity asset values under the equity stress scenario. This item is to be determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Dividend Yield Percent

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the average earnings yield before taxes, used in determining the reduction in infrastructure asset values under the property stress scenario. This item is to be determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Earnings Yield Percent

content.definition: This indicates whether the reporting entity has applied the eligible credit support to calculate the asset concentration risk charge, where the exposure is covered by an eligible collateral, guarantee, or letter of credit.
content.guidance:
A choice of TRUE/FALSE values. 

true = The reporting entity has applied the eligible credit support. 

false = The reporting entity has not applied the eligible credit support.
content.name: Financial Risk Eligible Credit Support Indicator

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of on-balance sheet exposures.
On-balance sheet refers to those assets, or exposure items, which are recognised or recorded on the statement of financial position of the reporting entity, as determined in accordance with relevant accounting standards.
The value of this item is to be determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Exposures On Balance Sheet Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, for prefunded default fund contribution with this central counterparty (CCP). This equates to the money contributed by the clearing member that will be applied upon such clearing member's default, either along with or immediately following such member's initial margin, to reduce the CCP loss.

A central counterparty is defined as a clearing house that interposes itself between counterparties to contracts traded in one or more financial markets, becoming the buyer to every seller and the seller to every buyer. A CCP becomes counterparty to trades with market participants through novation, an open offer system, or another legally binding arrangement. For the purposes of the capital framework, a CCP is a financial institution.

It is calculated in accordance with the relevant prudential standard.
content.name: Financial Risk Management Capital Prefunded Default Fund Contribution Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of adjustments which include potential reinsurance recoverables from aggregate reinsurance cover. Aggregate reinsurance cover is eligible to be considered for inclusion once the aggregate reinsurance cover has reached its attachment point, or will as a result of the occurrence of natural perils probable maximum loss, or net whole-of-portfolio loss, as appropriate.
content.name: Financial Risk Natural Perils Adjustments Other Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of aggregate offset as per agreed methodology with APRA. This represents the amount of potential reinsurance recoverables from aggregate reinsurance cover, as per contractual agreements with the reinsurer(s).
content.name: Financial Risk Natural Perils Aggregate Offset Amount

content.definition: This is the outstanding claims risk capital factor determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Outstanding Claims Capital Factor Percent

content.definition: This is the premiums liability risk capital factor determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Premiums Liability Capital Factor Percent

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the premiums liability offset, the portion of the premiums liability provision which relates to catastrophic losses, as determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards by the relevant actuary.
content.name: Financial Risk Premiums Liability Offset Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of reinstatement premiums. This is the amount of premium a reinsurer receives from an insurer as a result of the event that gives rise to its probable maximum loss.
Probable Maximum Loss (PML) is the largest gross loss to which an insurer will be exposed (within the realms of possibility) due to a concentration of risk exposures, without any allowance for potential reinsurance assets.
content.name: Financial Risk Premiums Reinstatement Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date of adjustments to prescribed capital amount, as approved by the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority.
content.name: Financial Risk Prescribed Capital Adjustment Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the probable maximum loss determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards. Probable Maximum Loss (PML) is the largest gross loss to which an insurer will be exposed (within the realms of possibility) due to a concentration of risk exposures, without any allowance for potential reinsurance assets.
content.name: Financial Risk Probable Maximum Loss Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of adjustment to the probable maximum loss that is already specifically allowed for in the premiums liabilities of the insurer.
content.name: Financial Risk Probable Maximum Loss Adjustment Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the regulatory capital requirement, determined in accordance with relevant legislation and standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Regulatory Capital Requirement Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of reinstatement costs. This is the cost of reinstating all catastrophe reinsurance cover relating to reinsurance recoverables.
content.name: Financial Risk Reinsurance Cover Reinstatement Cost Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the average rental yield based on current leases net of expenses, used in determining the reduction in the property asset values under the property stress scenario. This item is to be determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Rental Yield Percent

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date of the asset risk charge, determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards. The asset risk charge is the minimum amount of capital required to be held against asset risks. The asset risk charge relates to the risk of adverse movements in the value of on-balance sheet and off-balance sheet exposures. Asset risk can be derived from a number of sources, including market risk and credit risk.
content.name: Financial Risk Risk Charge Asset Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date of the asset concentration risk capital charge, determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards. The asset concentration risk charge is the minimum amount of capital required to be held against asset concentration risks. The asset concentration risk charge relates to the risk of concentration in particular assets resulting in adverse movements in the capital base.
content.name: Financial Risk Risk Charge Concentration Asset Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date of the insurance concentration risk capital charge, determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards. The Insurance Concentration Risk Charge represents the net financial impact on the reporting insurer from either a single event, or a series of multiple events, within a one year period.
content.name: Financial Risk Risk Charge Concentration Insurance Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date of the insurance risk charge, determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards. The insurance risk charge is the minimum amount of capital required to be held against insurance risks. The insurance risk charge relates to the risk of adverse impacts due to movements in future mortality, morbidity, longevity, servicing expenses and lapses.
content.name: Financial Risk Risk Charge Insurance Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date of the insurance risk charge for outstanding claims liabilities (OCL), determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards. It relates to the risk that the value of net outstanding liabilities (OCL) will be insufficient to cover associated net claim payments and any associated claim expenses as they fall due.
content.name: Financial Risk Risk Charge Insurance Outstanding Claims Liabilities Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date of the insurance risk charge for premiums liability (PL), determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards. It relates to the risk that the value of net premiums liability (PL) will be insufficient to cover associated net claim payments and any associated claim expenses as they fall due.
content.name: Financial Risk Risk Charge Insurance Premiums Liability Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date of the operational risk capital charge, determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards. The operational risk charge is the minimum amount of capital required to be held against operational risks. The operational risk charge relates to the risk of loss resulting from inadequate or failed internal processes, people and systems or from external events.
content.name: Financial Risk Risk Charge Operational Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date of the combined stress scenario adjustment to the prescribed capital amount in respect of the tax benefits and the management actions that can be recognised in determining the insurance risk charge and the asset risk charge.  This item also recognises the second order interactions between the asset and insurance risk stresses and is to be determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Risk Charge Prescribed Capital Adjustment Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date of the capital risk charge for variable annuity business that relates to asset and insurance risks, after allowance for diversification. This item is determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards. 
Variable annuity means a policy with benefits calculated by reference to the value of the units allocated to the policy, but the benefits may exceed the value of those units in specified circumstances.
The asset risk charge relates to the risk of adverse movements in the value of a fund's on-balance sheet and off-balance sheet exposures. Asset risk can be derived from a number of sources, including market risk and credit risk.
The insurance risk charge is the minimum amount of capital required to be held against insurance risks. The insurance risk charge relates to the risk of adverse impacts due to movements in future mortality, morbidity, longevity, servicing expenses and lapses.
content.name: Financial Risk Risk Charge Variable Annuities Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of single event loss, as determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards. Single event loss is the loss arising from the occurrence of a single event where that loss is not less than the whole-of-portfolio annual loss with a probability of occurrence stated in the relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Single Loss Event Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the Termination Value of insurance policies, as calculated by the relevant standard. The Termination Value of a policy is either: a) the amount that would be paid in the event of voluntary termination; or b) where no amount would be paid, the discounted present value of the unexpired risks, future payments and/or contractual premium refunds.
content.name: Financial Risk Termination Value Amount

content.definition: This is the valuation date on which the information was last calculated and reported.
content.name: Financial Risk Valuation Date

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of whole-of-portfolio loss, as determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards. Whole-of-portfolio loss is the loss arising from the occurrence of a single event where that loss is not less than the whole-of-portfolio annual loss with a probability of occurrence stated in the relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Whole Of Portfolio Loss Amount

content.definition: This indicates whether the reporting entity is an APRA regulated entity.
content.guidance:
A choice of TRUE/FALSE values.

true = The reporting entity is an APRA regulated entity.

false = The reporting entity is not an APRA regulated entity.
content.name: Financial Services Insurance APRA Regulated Indicator

content.definition: This indicates whether the exposure is to a non-APRA-authorised reinsurer.
content.guidance:
A choice of TRUE/FALSE values.

true = The exposure is to a non-APRA authorised reinsurer. 

false = The exposure is not to a non-APRA authorised reinsurer.
content.name: Financial Services Insurance Non APRA Authorised Reinsurer Indicator

content.definition: This is the value, during the relevant period, for all fees received arising from the provision of management services that are not related to the premium on policy.
content.name: Income Fees Non Premium Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, for deposit elements for life investment and life insurance investment account business i.e. exclude any revenue components. Include the deposit component of premiums in respect of deferred or immediate annuities that are life investment business written as inwards reinsurance.
content.name: Income Insurance Inwards Premium Deposit Component Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of premiums received from life insurance policies that are accounted for as insurance policy revenue.

Include premiums in respect of deferred and immediate annuities that are life insurance business.

Life insurance policies are contracts (policies) that will pay a specified sum to beneficiaries upon the death of the insured.

An annuity is a periodic payment of a fixed or variable amount arising out of a contract obligation. Immediate annuities are those purchased with a single payment, where the income stream commences immediately. Deferred annuities are those where the income stream commences at some time in the future.
content.name: Income Insurance Life Premium Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, for the deposit components of regular and single premiums received or receivable for life investment and life insurance investment account business i.e. exclude any revenue components. Include the deposit component of premiums in respect of deferred or immediate annuities that are life investment business.

Life insurance policies are contracts that will pay a specified sum to beneficiaries upon the death of the insured.

An annuity is a periodic payment of a fixed or variable amount arising out of a contract obligation. Immediate annuities are those purchased with a single payment, where the income stream commences immediately. Deferred annuities are those where the income stream commences at some time in the future.
content.name: Income Insurance Life Premium Deposit Component Amount

content.definition: This is the value, during the relevant period, for all the total deposit (investment) component of premiums received from all insurance investment policies.
content.name: Income Insurance Premium Deposit Component Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, during the relevant period, for insurance policy revenue and consists only of premiums related fees received from life insurance policies. 
Premiums for life investment business are recognised as deposits, and adjusted for as changes in policy liabilities. This item is to be determined in accordance with the relevant accounting standards.
content.name: Income Insurance Policy Amount

content.definition:
This is the value of written insurance premium revenue, recognised during the relevant period, as determined in accordance with relevant accounting standards. This item includes any fire service levy or other levies imposed by state and territory governments.

Written premium is an accounting term in the insurance business used to describe the total premiums on policies issued by an insurance company during a specific period of time regardless of what portions have been earned. Written premiums are the amount of premium charged for a policy that has already become effective.
content.name: Income Insurance Written Premium Revenue Amount

content.definition: Report the value of deposits held at the reporting date redeemable or withdrawable by depositors from the reporting party. This item is to be determined in accordance with accounting standards.
content.name: Liabilities Deposits Total Amount

content.definition: This is the value, during the relevant period, of the movement in the surplus distributed to fund members as net policy liabilities.
content.name: Expense Insurance Net Policy Liability Movement Distributed Fund Members Amount

content.definition: This is the value, during the relevant period, for direct business, report the number of risks written during the relevant period, on a financial year to date basis. For policies in which a premium has been allocated to multiple classes of business, one risk should be reported in each class of business to which premium was allocated.
content.name: Insurance Policies Written Number

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, for borrowings, plus overdrafts less any borrowings classified as seed capital. This method of disclosure differs from the Australian Accounting Standards. Borrowings are amounts of money on loan from financial institutions or other creditors with the promise or understanding that it will be repaid. Seed capital is the preliminary contribution of funding toward the financing of a new business. Commonly this is in the form of a loan, usually provided by a related entity.
content.name: Liabilities Borrowings Excluding Seed Capital Including Overdrafts Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, borrowings, including overdrafts. This method of disclosure differs from the Australian Accounting Standards.

Borrowings are amounts of money on loan from financial institutions or other creditors with the promise or understanding that it will be repaid.
content.name: Liabilities Borrowings Plus Overdrafts Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of counterparty exposures to borrowings. Borrowings are generally amounts of money on loan from financial institutions or other creditors with the promise or understanding that it will be repaid.

An exposure to a counterparty or a group of related counterparties is the aggregate of all claims, commitments arising from on-balance sheet transactions with the counterparty or group of related counterparties. 

On-balance sheet refers to those assets, liabilities, or exposure items, which are recognised or recorded on the statement of financial position of the reporting entity, as determined in accordance with relevant Accounting Standards.
content.name: Liabilities Exposures Borrowings Amount

content.definition:
This is a balancing item in the list in which it is being used. It is the value, as at the relevant date, of counterparty exposures to other liabilities. 

An exposure to a counterparty or a group of related counterparties is the aggregate of all claims, commitments arising from on-balance sheet transactions with the counterparty or group of related counterparties. 

On-balance sheet refers to those assets, liabilities, or exposure items, which are recognised or recorded on the statement of financial position of the reporting entity, as determined in accordance with relevant Accounting Standards.
content.name: Liabilities Exposures Other Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of counterparty exposures to trade creditors and accruals (including goods and services tax payable but not income tax payable). 

An exposure to a counterparty or a group of related counterparties is the aggregate of all claims, commitments arising from on-balance sheet transactions with the counterparty or group of related counterparties. 

On-balance sheet refers to those assets, liabilities, or exposure items, which are recognised or recorded on the statement of financial position of the reporting entity, as determined in accordance with relevant Accounting Standards.
content.name: Liabilities Exposures Trade Creditors Accruals Amount

content.definition: This is the value as at the relevant date of policy liabilities, as determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Liabilities Insurance Insurance Policy Liabilities Amount

content.definition: This is the amount, as at the relevant date, by which the outstanding claims liability (OCL), determined in accordance with accounting standards exceeds (or is in deficit of) the equivalent figure determined in accordance with prudential standards. OCL relates to all claims incurred in the relevant accident or underwriting year prior to the valuation date, whether or not they have been reported to the insurer. The value of the OCL must include an amount in respect of the expenses that the insurer expects to incur in settling these claims. The value of OCL must not include any Government charges imposed such as levies, duties and taxes.
content.name: Liabilities Insurance Outstanding Claims Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the outstanding claims liability (OCL) as determined in accordance with relevant Accounting Standards.
content.name: Liabilities Insurance Outstanding Claims Liability Accounting Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the central estimate component of outstanding claims liability (OCL), determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.

OCL relates to all claims incurred prior to the valuation date, whether or not they have been reported to the insurer. The value of the OCL must include an amount in respect of the expenses that the insurer expects to incur in settling these claims. The value of OCL must not include any Government charges directly imposed on the insurer such as levies, duties and taxes, but must be gross of input tax credit recoveries.

The central estimate will be measured as the present value of the future expected payments, i.e. discounted for future investment income, determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards. The central estimate is intended to reflect the mean value in the range of possible values for the outcome (that is, the mean of the distribution of probabilistic outcomes), and so does not include any risk margin.
content.name: Liabilities Insurance Outstanding Claims Liability Central Estimate Amount

content.definition:
This is a balancing in the list in which it is being used.

This is the value, as at the relevant date of the central estimate component of Outstanding Claims Liability Group Adjustments calculated as A - (B+C), where:

     A = central estimate component of outstanding claims liability (OCL) - Total consolidated Level 2
     B = central estimate component of outstanding claims liability (OCL) - Total direct business partially consolidated
     C = central estimate component of outstanding claims liability (OCL) - Total reinsurance business partially consolidated

For the purposes of this item the OCL central estimate component is determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards. 

OCL relates to all claims incurred prior to the valuation date, whether or not they have been reported to the insurer. The value of the OCL must include an amount in respect of the expenses that the insurer expects to incur in settling these claims. The value of OCL must not include any Government charges directly imposed on the insurer such as levies, duties and taxes, but must be gross of input tax credit recoveries.

The central estimate will be measured as the present value of the future expected payments, i.e. discounted for future investment income, determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards. The central estimate is intended to reflect the mean value in the range of possible values for the outcome (that is, the mean of the distribution of probabilistic outcomes), and so does not include any risk margin.
content.name: Liabilities Insurance Outstanding Claims Liability Central Estimate Group Adjustments Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the outstanding claims liability (OCL), determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards. OCL relates to all claims incurred prior to the valuation date, whether or not they have been reported to the insurer. The value of the OCL must include an amount in respect of the expenses that the insurer expects to incur in settling these claims. The value of OCL must not include any Government charges directly imposed on the insurer such as levies, duties and taxes, but must be gross of input tax credit recoveries.
content.name: Liabilities Insurance Outstanding Claims Liability Excluding Government Charges Amount

content.definition:
This is a balancing item calculated as A - (B+C), where:

     A = outstanding claims liability (OCL) - Total consolidated Level 2
     B = outstanding claims liability (OCL) - Total direct business partially consolidated
     C = outstanding claims liability (OCL) - Total reinsurance business partially consolidated

For the purposes of this item OCL is reported as at the relevant date as determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.

OCL relates to all claims incurred prior to the valuation date, whether or not they have been reported to the insurer. The value of the OCL must include an amount in respect of the expenses that the insurer expects to incur in settling these claims. The value of OCL must not include any Government charges directly imposed on the insurer such as levies, duties and taxes, but must be gross of input tax credit recoveries.

The OCL will be measured as the present value of the future expected payments, i.e. discounted for future investment income, plus a risk margin determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Liabilities Insurance Outstanding Claims Liability Group Adjustments Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the outstanding, outstanding claims liability (OCL) determined in accordance with relevant accounting standards, but not discounted as required by those accounting standards.

OCL relates to all claims incurred in the relevant accident or underwriting year prior to the valuation date, whether or not they have been reported to the insurer. The value of the OCL must include an amount in respect of the expenses that the insurer expects to incur in settling these claims. The value of OCL must not include any Government charges imposed such as levies, duties and taxes.
content.name: Liabilities Insurance Outstanding Claims Liability Not Discounted Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the risk margin component of outstanding claims liability (OCL), determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.

OCL relates to all claims incurred prior to the valuation date, whether or not they have been reported to the insurer. The value of the OCL must include an amount in respect of the expenses that the insurer expects to incur in settling these claims. The value of OCL must not include any Government charges directly imposed on the insurer such as levies, duties and taxes, but must be gross of input tax credit recoveries.

The risk margin is the component of the value of OCL that relates to the inherent uncertainty that outcomes will differ from the central estimate.

The risk margin relates to the central estimate measured as the present value of the future expected payments i.e. discounted for future investment income, determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards. The central estimate is intended to reflect the mean value in the range of possible values for the outcome (that is, the mean of the distribution of probabilistic outcomes), and the risk margin, when added to the central estimate, is intended to increase the likelihood that the OCL will be sufficient to the level required in relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Liabilities Insurance Outstanding Claims Liability Risk Margin Amount

content.definition:
This is a balancing item calculated as A - (B+C), where:

     A = risk margin component of outstanding claims liability (OCL) - Total consolidated Level 2
     B = risk margin component of outstanding claims liability (OCL) - Total direct business partially consolidated
     C = risk margin component of outstanding claims liability (OCL) - Total reinsurance business partially consolidated

For the purposes of this item the OCL risk margin component is reported as at the relevant date as determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.  The risk margin must be assessed at the level specified by APRA for capital purposes; this may not be the same risk margin used for other purposes such as statutory accounts.

OCL relates to all claims incurred prior to the valuation date, whether or not they have been reported to the insurer. The value of the OCL must include an amount in respect of the expenses that the insurer expects to incur in settling these claims. The value of OCL must not include any Government charges directly imposed on the insurer such as levies, duties and taxes, but must be gross of input tax credit recoveries.

The risk margin is the component of the value of OCL that relates to the inherent uncertainty that outcomes will differ from the central estimate.

The risk margin relates to the central estimate measured as the present value of the future expected payments gross of any recoveries, i.e. discounted for future investment income, determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards. The central estimate is intended to reflect the mean value in the range of possible values for the outcome (that is, the mean of the distribution of probabilistic outcomes), and the risk margin, when added to the central estimate, is intended to increase the likelihood that the OCL will be sufficient to the level required in relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Liabilities Insurance Outstanding Claims Liability Risk Margin Group Adjustments Amount

content.definition: This is the amount, as at the relevant date, by which the outstanding claims liability (OCL), as determined in accordance with accounting standards, exceeds (or is in deficit of) the equivalent figure determined in accordance with prudential standards.OCL relates to all claims incurred prior to the valuation date, whether or not they have been reported to the insurer. The value of the OCL must include an amount in respect of the expenses that the insurer expects to incur in settling these claims. The value of OCL must not include any Government charges directly imposed on the insurer such as levies, duties and taxes.
content.name: Liabilities Insurance Outstanding Claims Liability Surplus Deficit Amount

content.definition: This is the amount, as at the relevant date, by which the outstanding claims liabilities (OCL), determined in accordance with accounting standards exceeds (or is in deficit of) the equivalent figure determined in accordance with prudential standards. OCL relates to all claims incurred prior to the valuation date, whether or not they have been reported to the insurer. The value of the OCL must include an amount in respect of the expenses that the insurer expects to incur in settling these claims. The value of OCL must not include any Government charges directly imposed on the insurer such as levies, duties and taxes.
content.name: Liabilities Insurance Outstanding Claims Surplus Deficit Excluding Government Charges Amount

content.definition: Report the value of deposits held at the reporting date redeemable or withdrawable by depositors from the reporting party on demand or within 24 hours. This item is to be determined in accordance with accounting standards.
content.name: Liabilities Deposits Call Or On Demand Total Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of value of the impact of the insurance stresses on participating policy liabilities, as determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Liabilities Insurance Participating Policy Liabilities Amount

content.definition: This is the amount, as at the relevant date, of the tax effect relating to adjustments to policy liabilities as determined in accordance with relevant Prudential Standards.
content.name: Liabilities Insurance Policy Liabilities Adjust Tax Effect Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of policy liabilities net of all policy liabilities ceded under reinsurance, together with policy owner retained profits, determined in accordance with the methodologies stated in relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Liabilities Insurance Policy Liabilities And Policy Owner Retained Profits Amount

content.definition: This is the value as at the relevant date of the proportion of policy liabilities that equates to the maximum amount of unallocated surplus shown as unallocated surplus that could be immediately distributed to benefit fund members without causing a breach of the capital adequacy standards. This number is to be determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Liabilities Insurance Policy Liabilities Unallocated Distributable Surplus Amount

content.definition: This is the value as at the relevant date of policy liabilities, of which are unallocated surpluses (Unallocated surplus classified as liabilities included in this item relates to all other unallocated surpluses that have not been included as unallocated benefit fund reserves). It equates to the unallocated surplus remaining after distributions to benefit fund members. This number is to be determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Liabilities Insurance Policy Liabilities Unallocated Surplus Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of premiums liabilities as determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
Prudential Premiums Liabilities relate to all future claim payments arising from future events post the valuation date that will be insured under the reporting party's existing policies that have not yet expired. The value of Prudential Premium Liabilities must include an amount in respect of the expenses that the reporting entity expects to incur in administering and settling the relevant claims and allow for expected premium refunds. 
The value of prudential premiums liabilities must not include any Government charges directly imposed on the reporting entity such as levies, duties and taxes. Also a deferred acquisition cost asset must not be reported as part of Prudential Premium Liabilities.
content.name: Liabilities Insurance Premiums Liabilities Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the sum of net premiums liabilities as determined in accordance with relevant accounting standards plus the value of the deficiency recognised in premium liability valuations due to the application of Liability Adequacy Test (LAT) as determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.

Net premiums liabilities is calculated as UPL - DAC - DRE + URL + other items, where:

UPL = Unearned Premium Liability as determined in accordance with the relevant accounting standards.

DAC = Deferred Acquisition Cost as determined in accordance with the relevant accounting standards.  This represents the portion of acquisition costs that relate to the unearned portion of premium revenue and which are capitalised as a result.

DRE = Deferred Reinsurance Expense as determined in accordance with the relevant accounting standards.  This represents the portion of reinsurance expenses that relate to the unearned portion of premium revenue and which are capitalised as a result.

URL = Unexpired Risk Liability as determined in accordance with the relevant accounting standards.

Other items include anything else required under the relevant accounting standards to be included in the calculation of Net Premium Liabilities.
content.name: Liabilities Insurance Premiums Liabilities Adjusted Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the central estimate component of premiums liabilities, determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.

Premiums liabilities relate to all future claim payments arising from future events post the valuation date that will be insured under the reporting entity's existing policies that have not yet expired. The value of the premiums liabilities must include an amount in respect of the expenses that the reporting entity expects to incur in administering and settling the relevant claims and allow for expected premium refunds.

The value of premiums liabilities must not include any Government charges directly imposed on the reporting entity such as levies, duties and taxes, and must be gross of input tax credit recoveries. Also a deferred acquisition cost asset must not be reported.

The central estimate will be measured as the present value of the future expected payments, i.e. discounted for future investment income, determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards. The central estimate is intended to reflect the mean value in the range of possible values for the outcome (that is, the mean of the distribution of probabilistic outcomes), and so does not include any risk margin.
content.name: Liabilities Insurance Premiums Liabilities Central Estimate Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of premiums liabilities which can be determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards or in accordance with relevant accounting standards.
                                                                           
Prudential Premiums Liabilities relate to all future claim payments arising from future events post the valuation date that will be insured under the reporting entity's existing policies that have not yet expired. The value of Prudential Premium Liabilities must include an amount in respect of the expenses that the reporting entity expects to incur in administering and settling the relevant claims and allow for expected premium refunds. 

The value of prudential premiums liabilities must not include any Government charges directly imposed on the reporting entity such as levies, duties and taxes. Also a deferred acquisition cost asset must not be reported as part of Prudential Premium Liabilities. 

The Prudential Premium Liabilities will be measured as the present value of the future expected payments, i.e. discounted for future investment income, plus a risk margin determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards. The risk margin must be assessed at the level specified by APRA for capital purposes; this may not be the same risk margin used for other purposes.
                                                  
Accounting Premiums Liabilities are calculated as UPL - DAC, where: 
                                                          
UPL = Unearned Premium Liability as determined in accordance with the relevant accounting standards.
                                                          
DAC = Deferred Acquisition Costs as determined in accordance with the relevant accounting standards.
content.name: Liabilities Insurance Premiums Liabilities Prudential Or Accounting Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the risk margin component of premiums liabilities, as determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.  The risk margin must be assessed at the level specified by APRA for capital purposes; this may not be the same risk margin used for other purposes such as statutory accounts.

Premiums liabilities relate to all future claim payments arising from future events post the valuation date that will be insured under the reporting entity's existing policies that have not yet expired. The value of the premiums liabilities must include an amount in respect of the expenses that the reporting entity expects to incur in administering and settling the relevant claims and allow for expected premium refunds.

The value of premiums liabilities must not include any Government charges directly imposed on the insurer such as levies, duties and taxes. Also a deferred acquisition cost asset must not be reported.

The risk margin is the component of the value of premiums liabilities that relates to the inherent uncertainty that outcomes will differ from the central estimate.

The risk margin relates to the central estimate measured as the present value of the future expected payments, i.e. discounted for future investment income, determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards. The central estimate is intended to reflect the mean value in the range of possible values for the outcome (that is, the mean of the distribution of probabilistic outcomes), and the risk margin, when added to the central estimate, is intended to increase the likelihood that the premiums liabilities will be sufficient to the level required in relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Liabilities Insurance Premiums Liabilities Risk Margin Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of annuity payments and expenses arising from premiums received.
content.name: Liabilities Insurance Provisions Annuity Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of claim payments and expenses in respect of claims in course of payments, that are associated with premiums received.
content.name: Liabilities Insurance Claims Expenses Provisions Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of claim payments and expenses in of respect of claims incurred but not reported, that are associated with premiums received.
content.name: Liabilities Insurance Provisions Claims Incurred Not Reported Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of claim payments and expenses in of respect of claims reported but not assessed, that are associated with premiums received.
content.name: Liabilities Insurance Provisions Claims Reported Not Assessed Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, claim payments and expenses associated with unexpired proportion of premiums received (unearned premium reserve).
content.name: Liabilities Insurance Provisions Claims Unearned Premium Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of premiums expected to be received from policies remaining in force.
content.name: Liabilities Insurance Provisions Expected Premiums Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of claim payments arising from premiums expected to be received.
content.name: Liabilities Insurance Provisions Expected Premiums Claims Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of expenses from premiums expected to be received.
content.name: Liabilities Insurance Provisions Expected Premiums Expenses Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of tax liabilities from profits emerging from premiums expected to be received.
content.name: Liabilities Insurance Provisions Expected Premiums Liabilities Tax Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of net profits after tax attributable to shareholders, emerging from premiums expected to be received.
content.name: Liabilities Insurance Provisions Expected Premiums Net Profit After Tax Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of liabilities arising from premiums expected to be received.
content.name: Liabilities Insurance Provisions Premium Liabilities Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of premium refund payable, in excess of the unearned premium reserve held. The refund is due to termination of the policy and is payable based on the policy document's contractual agreement.
content.name: Liabilities Insurance Refund Unearned Premium Excess Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of value of the impact of the insurance stresses on the risk-free best estimate liabilities, as determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Liabilities Insurance Risk Free Best Estimate Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of servicing expenses expected to be determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards. Servicing expenses refers to the combination of maintenance expenses and investment management expenses.
content.name: Liabilities Insurance Servicing Expenses Expected Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, for liabilities other than: - Borrowings- Trade and other payables- Provisions- Gross policy liabilities- Policy owner retained profits- Unearned premium income- Approved subordinated debt Liabilities, as defined by the Australian Accounting Standards, are present obligations of an entity arising from past events, the settlement of which is expected to result in an outflow from the entity of resources embodying economic benefits.
content.name: Liabilities Other Balance Sheet Liabilities Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the cumulative life to date unrealised losses on financial liabilities excluding all derivatives.
content.name: Liabilities Unrealised Losses Excluding Derivatives Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the cumulative life to date gains in the unrealised liability value.
content.guidance: For the purposes of this item exclude all derivatives.
content.name: Liabilities Unrealised Gain Excluding Derivatives Amount

content.definition: This is the value, at the relevant date, of all financial liability as defined in relevant accounting standards. For the purposes of this item, exclude derivatives.
content.name: Liabilities Financial Excluding Derivatives Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of borrowings classified as seed capital. Seed capital is the preliminary contribution of funding toward the financing of a new business. Commonly this is in the form of a loan, usually provided by a related entity.

Borrowings are amounts of money on loan from financial institutions or other creditors with the promise or understanding that it will be repaid.
content.name: Liabilities Seed Capital Borrowings Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of subordinated debt, as determined in accordance with the relevant prudential standards. 
Subordinated debt is that debt which is ranked lower in priority than other senior debt, including policyholders. In the event of bankruptcy, subordinated debt holders receive payment only after senior debt claims are paid in full.
content.name: Liabilities Subordinated Debt Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of eligible subordinated debt, as determined in accordance with the relevant prudential standards. 
Subordinated debt is that debt which is ranked lower in priority than other senior debt, including policyholders. In the event of bankruptcy, subordinated debt holders receive payment only after senior debt claims are paid in full.
content.name: Liabilities Subordinated Debt Eligible Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of non eligible subordinated debt, as determined in accordance with the relevant prudential standards. 
Subordinated debt is that debt which is ranked lower in priority than other senior debt, including policyholders. In the event of bankruptcy, subordinated debt holders receive payment only after senior debt claims are paid in full.
content.name: Liabilities Subordinated Debt Non Eligible Amount

content.definition: This is the value, during the relevant period, of liabilities transferred between different fair value hierarchy levels, as determined in accordance with relevant accounting standards.
content.name: Liabilities Transfers Between Hierarchy Level Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of counterparty exposures to off-balance sheet assets. 

An exposure to a counterparty or a group of related counterparties is the aggregate of all claims, commitments and contingent liabilities from on- or off-balance sheet transactions with the counterparty or group of related counterparties.

Off-balance sheet exposures refer to items that are not recognised in the statement of financial position of the reporting entity, such as contingent assets and liabilities.
content.name: Off Balance Sheet Assets Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, for off balance sheet credit derivatives where protection is sold. This is where the reporting entity assumes the credit risk by selling protection to a third party. Upon this party calling on this protection the reporting entity is obliged to pay cash and provide for a claim to receive a financial asset.
content.name: Off Balance Sheet Credit Derivatives Sold Protection Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of any irrevocable commitments that are not formal standby facilities or credit lines. These are non-market related off-balance sheet contingent liabilities relating to the maximum unused portion of any irrevocable commitments that could be drawn during the remaining period to maturity.

In reporting this item the reporting entity is to follow the basis that is used for the preparation of the annual financial statements in accordance with the Australian accounting standards. Actuarial valuations and calculations used in deriving the value of the item must be in accordance with prudential standards.
content.name: Off Balance Sheet Irrevocable Commitments Not Standby Facilities Not Credit Lines Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of counterparty exposures to off-balance sheet liabilities. 

An exposure to a counterparty or a group of related counterparties is the aggregate of all claims, commitments and contingent liabilities from on- or off-balance sheet transactions with the counterparty or group of related counterparties.

Off-balance sheet exposures refer to items that are not recognised in the statement of financial position of the reporting entity, such as contingent assets and liabilities.
content.name: Off Balance Sheet Liabilities Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the non-market related off-balance sheet contingent liabilities relating to formal standby facilities or credit lines.

A formal standby facility or credit line is a formalised arrangement in which the counterparty has the right but not the obligation to draw down funds to a specified limit.

In reporting this item the reporting entity is to follow the basis that is used for the preparation of the annual financial statements in accordance with the Australian accounting standards. Actuarial valuations and calculations used in deriving the value of the item must be in accordance with prudential standards.
content.name: Off Balance Sheet Undrawn Formal Standby Facilities Amount

content.definition:
This indicates whether or not the reporting entity is a general fund.

General fund refers to the shareholder's fund of a life company other than friendly societies, or the management fund of a friendly society, as relevant.
content.guidance:
A choice of TRUE/FALSE values.

true = The reporting entity is a General Fund.

false = The reporting entity is not a General Fund.
content.name: Organisation Details General Fund Indicator

content.definition:
This indicates whether the reporting entity is a Lenders Mortgage Insurer (LMI).

Lenders mortgage insurer means an insurer that has written or reinsured, or proposes to write or reinsure, policies of lenders mortgage insurance.

Lenders mortgage insurance has its ordinary commercial meaning and includes insurance under a policy which protects a lender from losses in the event of borrower default on a loan secured by a mortgage over residential or other property.
content.guidance:
A choice of TRUE/FALSE values.

true = The reporting entity is a lenders mortgage insurer. 

false = The reporting entity is not a lenders mortgage insurer.
content.name: Organisation Details Lenders Mortgage Insurer Indicator

content.definition:
This indicates whether the reporting entity is a specialist reinsurer.

Specialist reinsurer refers to statutory fund of a registered life company where all policies referable to the fund are reinsurance policies and none of the policies are owned by a related entity of the life company.
content.guidance:
A choice of TRUE/FALSE values.

true = The reporting entity is a specialist reinsurer. 

false = The reporting entity is not a specialist reinsurer.
content.name: Organisation Details Specialist Reinsurer Indicator

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of goodwill net of impairment and other intangible net of both impairment and amortisation. This item is to be determined in accordance with relevant Accounting Standards. 

Goodwill is calculated as the excess of the cost of a business combination over the acquirer's interest in the net fair value of the identifiable assets, liabilities and contingent liabilities. It represents the future economic benefits arising from other assets acquired in a business combination that are not individually identified and separately recognised.
content.name: Assets Goodwill And Other Intangible Assets Net Impairment And Amortisation Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of deferred reinsurance expense (DRE), as determined in accordance with the relevant Accounting Standards. For the purposes of this item, exclude amounts under reinsurance contracts that do not meet the reinsurance documentation test or governing law requirements under relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Assets Insurance Deferred Reinsurance Expense Excluding Contracts That Do Not Meet Documentation Test Or Government Law Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of deferred reinsurance expense where the reinsurer has not complied with the governing law requirements in the relevant prudential standard.
content.name: Assets Insurance Deferred Reinsurance Expense Not Meet Governing Law Test Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, for management fees expected to be received. This item is to be determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards and is net of any reduction in management fees assumed under asset and/or insurance stresses.
content.name: Assets Insurance Management Fees Expected Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, for any reduction in management fees assumed under asset and/or insurance stresses, and is to be determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Assets Insurance Management Fees Stress Adjustment Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of insurance premiums due but not yet received.
content.name: Assets Insurance Receivables Premium Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of any asset recognised by the reporting entity that relates to reinsurance where the reporting entity has not complied with the threshold levels of reinsurance documentation set out in the relevant prudential standards. A reinsurance arrangement meets the reinsurance documentation test if it satisfies the requirements specified in the relevant prudential standard.
content.name: Assets Insurance Reinsurance Do Not Meet Documentation Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of reinsurance recoverable. Reinsurance recoverables are any amounts due to the reporting entity from a reinsurer determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Assets Insurance Reinsurance Recoverables Amount

content.definition: Term deposits refer to an account in which money has been placed for a fixed period of time for a stated interest rate.
content.name: Liabilities Deposits Term Deposits Total Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of reinsurance recoverables in relation to reinsurance contracts for both paid and outstanding claims against the reporting entity.  For the purposes of this item, exclude amounts under reinsurance contracts that do not meet the reinsurance documentation test or governing law requirements under relevant prudential standards.

Reinsurance recoverables are any amounts due to the reporting entity from a reinsurer that arise from the recognition of Outstanding Claims Liabilities in accordance with capital and prudential standards.
content.name: Assets Insurance Reinsurance Recoverables Paid Outstanding Claims Ex Contracts That Do Not Meet Doc Test Or Gov Law Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of reinsurance recoverables in relation to reinsurance contracts for both paid and outstanding claims against the reporting entity where the reporting entity has complied with the threshold levels of reinsurance documentation set out in the relevant prudential standards.

Reinsurance recoverables are any amounts due to the reporting entity under a reinsurance arrangement that arise from paid claims and the recognition of Outstanding Claims Liabilities are in accordance with the relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Assets Insurance Reinsurance Recoverables Paid Outstanding Claims Meet Documentation Test Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of total capitalised expenses. Capitalised expenses are defined in accordance with relevant accounting standards. This item is reported for capital adequacy and is to be determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Assets Intangible Capitalised Expenses Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of interest bearing securities. Interest bearing securities are debt securities paying an income stream based upon an interest rate consistent with the classification and measurement basis used for investment securities in accordance with relevant accounting standards.
content.name: Assets Interest Bearing Securities Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the debt component of non-indexed hybrid securities, plus income accrued but not received in relation to this asset. This method of disclosure differs from the Australian Accounting Standards. Hybrid securities, or compound financial instruments, as defined by the Australian Accounting Standards, are financial instruments that, from the issuer's perspective, contain a liability (debt) and an equity element. Non-indexed securities pay an income stream that is not dependent upon any external factor. Compound financial instruments include all equities related items such as convertible notes and other hybrid securities which, taking into account market conditions, have attributes that demonstrate exposure to debt and equities markets.
content.name: Assets Investment Debt Securities Hybrid Plus Accrued Income Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of non-indexed pure (i.e. non hybrid) debt securities, plus income accrued but not received in relation to this asset. This method of disclosure differs from the Australian Accounting Standards.

Non-indexed debt securities pay an income stream based upon an interest rate, which is not dependent on any external factor. Debt securities are transferable instruments evidencing a relationship of indebtedness. It is characterised by having a definable income stream that is not based on the economic performance of the issuing entity. Pure debt securities are financial instruments that, from the issuer's perspective, contain only a liability element.
content.name: Assets Investment Debt Securities Non Hybrid Plus Accrued Income Non Indexed Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of non-indexed debt securities, including income accrued but not received. This method of disclosure differs from the Australian Accounting Standards. Debt securities are transferable instruments evidencing a relationship of indebtedness. It is characterised by having a definable income stream that is not based on the economic performance of the issuing entity.

Non-indexed debt securities pay an income stream that is not dependent on any external factor.
content.name: Assets Investment Debt Securities Plus Accrued Income Non Indexed Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date of the equity component of hybrid securities, plus income accrued but not received in relation to this asset. This method of disclosure differs from the Australian Accounting Standards. Hybrid securities, or compound financial instruments, as defined by the Australian Accounting Standards, are financial instruments that, from the issuer's perspective, contain a liability and an equity element. Compound financial instruments include all equities related items such as convertible notes and other hybrid securities which, taking into account market conditions, have attributes that demonstrate exposure to equities markets.
content.name: Assets Investment Equity Securities Hybrid Plus Accrued Income Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date of the equity component of investments in unitised trusts, plus income accrued but not received in relation to these assets. This method of disclosure differs from the Australian Accounting Standards.

Equity investments or securities are, as defined by the Australian Accounting Standards, contracts that evidence a residual interest in the assets of an entity after deducting all its liabilities.

Unitised trusts are a type of managed investment which issues units representing equal shares in the trust's investments. The value of the units fluctuates in line with the value, and income received from, the underlying investments.
content.name: Assets Investment Equity Securities Trusts Unitised Include Income Accrued Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date which equates to the balancing item in the list in which it is being used. Report the actual value, plus the value of accrued income, of any asset that has been classified as an investment asset, other than: - Cash; - Property; - Equities; - Interest bearing securities; or- Loans.
content.name: Assets Investment Investment Including Accrued Income Other Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant reporting date, of specified loans classified as assets, plus income accrued but not received in relation to this asset. This method of disclosure differs from the Australian Accounting Standards. Specified loans for reporting of this item are secured loans or loans to public sector entities. Loans include but are not limited to financial leases and mortgages. Loans differ from interest bearing securities as usually the asset is non negotiable (i.e. able to be traded on a secondary market).
content.name: Assets Investment Loans Plus Accrued Income Public Sector Secured Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date for this balancing item in the list it is being used.

Report the value, of any asset that has not been classified as an investment asset, other than receivables.
content.name: Assets Non Investment Other Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of investments in related partied, as determined in accordance with relevant accounting standards.
content.name: Assets Investment Related Party Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of specific investment classifications referred to as strategic investments / acquisitions of the reporting insurer related party investments and other investments. Related parties are determined in accordance with relevant Australian Accounting Standards.
content.name: Assets Investment Total Other Strategic Investments Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of income that is receivable by the reporting entity. For the purposes of this item, include only income from the holding of assets that are not equity securities (e.g. Interest and rental income that is accrued but not yet received). 

Equity securities are, as defined by the Australian Accounting Standards, contracts that evidence a residual interest in the assets of an entity after deducting all its liabilities. This includes equity securities lent or sold by the entity under repurchase agreements, where the transaction does not result in the transfer of the rights of ownership of the securities away from the entity to another party.
content.name: Assets Loans And Receivables Income Asset Holding Not Equity Securities Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of recoveries receivable by the reporting entity in relation to paid and unpaid insurance claims.
content.name: Assets Loans And Receivables Insurance Recoveries Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, for recoveries under arrangements other than reinsurance arrangements, receivable by the reporting insurer associated with the outstanding claims liability (OCL). This item is to be determined in accordance with relevant accounting standard.
content.name: Assets Loans And Receivables Insurance Recoveries Not Reinsurance Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the central estimate of recoveries, other than reinsurance recoveries, receivable by the reporting entity in relation to outstanding (unpaid) claims. This item is to be determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards. Recoveries to be included at this item include salvage, subrogation, and input tax credit recoveries, amongst others.

The central estimate will be measured as the present value of the future expected recoveries except from reinsurance, i.e. discounted for future investment income, determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards. The central estimate is intended to reflect the mean value in the range of possible values for the outcome (that is, the mean of the distribution of probabilistic outcomes), and so does not include any risk margin.
content.name: Assets Loans And Receivables Insurance Recoveries Not Reinsurance Outstanding Claims Liability Central Estimate Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the central estimate of recoveries, other than reinsurance recoveries, receivable by the reporting entity associated with the premiums liabilities. This item is to be determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards. 

The central estimate will be measured as the present value of the future expected recoveries except from reinsurance, i.e. discounted for future investment income, determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards. The central estimate is intended to reflect the mean value in the range of possible values for the outcome (that is, the mean of the distribution of probabilistic outcomes), and so does not include any risk margin.
content.name: Assets Loans And Receivables Insurance Recoveries Not Reinsurance Premiums Liabilities Prudential Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, for reinsurance recoverables, being amounts due to the reporting insurer under a reinsurance arrangement that arise from the recognition of outstanding claims liability (OCL). This item is to be determined in accordance with relevant accounting standard.
content.name: Assets Loans And Receivables Insurance Recoveries Reinsurance Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of receivables, including outstanding premiums, but not deferred acquisition costs arising in respect of policies. Do not include accrued income from investment assets as well as investment income due but not received. This method of disclosure differs from the Australian Accounting Standards.

Acquisition costs, as defined by the Australian Accounting Standards, are the fixed and variable costs of acquiring new business including commissions and similar distribution costs, and costs of accepting, issuing and initially recording policies.
content.name: Assets Loans And Receivables Including Accrued Income Excluding Deferred Acquisition Costs Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the central estimate of expected reinsurance recoveries receivable by the reporting entity associated with the premiums liabilities. This item is to be determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards. 

The central estimate will be measured as the present value of the future expected reinsurance recoveries, i.e. discounted for future investment income, determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards. The central estimate is intended to reflect the mean value in the range of possible values for the outcome (that is, the mean of the distribution of probabilistic outcomes), and so does not include any risk margin.

Expected reinsurance recoveries means any amounts due to an insurer, or to an entity that carries on international business within a Level 2 insurance group, from a reinsurer that arise from the recognition of premiums liabilities referred to in the GI Prudential Standards. This is distinguished from reinsurance recoverables.
content.name: Assets Loans And Receivables Reinsurance Recoveries Expected Premiums Liabilities Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of receivables classified as seed capital. Seed capital is the preliminary contribution of funding toward the financing of a new business. Commonly this is in the form of a loan, usually provided by a related entity.
content.name: Assets Loans And Receivables Seed Capital Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of total receivables, including investment income, total net recoveries other than reinsurance receivable, premium receivables, net amount recoverable from reinsurance contracts on outstanding claims and paid claims, other reinsurance assets, current tax assets, GST receivable, and any other general insurance receivables. This method of disclosure differs from the Australian Accounting Standards.
content.name: Assets Loans And Receivables Receivables Total General Insurance Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of total receivables, including outstanding premiums, but not deferred acquisition costs arising in respect of policies. Do not include accrued income from investment assets. This method of disclosure differs from the Australian Accounting Standards. Acquisition costs, as defined by the Australian Accounting Standards, are the fixed and variable costs of acquiring new business including commissions and similar distribution costs, and costs of accepting, issuing and initially recording policies. (Acquisition costs relate to the costs incurred in acquiring specific life insurance contracts during the relevant period. They do not include the general growth and development costs incurred by a life insurer).
