content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, for all current derivatives consistent with the classification and measurement basis used for derivatives by institutions in accordance with relevant Australian Accounting Standards where the value is positive.
content.name: Assets Other Financial Assets Current Derivative Financial Instruments Total Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, for all non current derivatives consistent with the classification and measurement basis used for derivatives by institutions in accordance with relevant Australian Accounting Standards where the value is positive.
content.name: Assets Other Financial Assets Non Current Derivative Financial Instruments Total Amount

content.definition:
Report the value, as at the reporting date, of Goods and Services Tax (GST) that is receivable on purchases, as determined in accordance with the Goods and Services Tax Act 1999.

GST is a tax on the supply of most goods and services and other taxable supplies (for example, real property and rights) in Australia, including things that are imported. In most cases it does not apply to exports of goods or services, and other things consumed outside Australia. It is similar to 'value-added taxes' applying in other countries. The GST is a multi-stage tax, that is, GST is paid at each stage of the supply chain. Liability for this tax rests on the supplier.
content.name: Assets Trade and Receivables Goods And Services Tax Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, for all current receivables.
content.name: Assets Current Receivables Total Amount

content.definition: This is the value, for the relevant period, of prepayments due to the reporting party that are classified as current determined in accordance with accounting standards.
content.name: Assets Other Financial Assets Prepayments Current Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, for the total of all Non Current receivables.
content.name: Assets Non Current Receivables Total Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, for the total of creditors and accruals, including account payables. Do not include overdrafts or GST liability.
content.name: Liabilities Current Creditors And Accruals Excluding Goods And Services Tax Liability Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, for the value of finance lease liability due and payable within 12 months.
content.name: Liabilities Other Financial Liabilities Current Finance Lease Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, for all borrowings by the reporting entity in the form of commercial paper, promissory notes and other forms of securities issued by the insurer.

Include all notes/securities such as commercial paper or promissory notes issued with a residual term to maturity of more than 12 months.
content.name: Liabilities Other Financial Liabilities Current Debt Securities Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, for all provisions raised for the restructuring of an organisation that are due and payable within the next 12 months, including:
- Severance, termination and redundancy payments; and
- Integration cost.
content.name: Liabilities Provisions Current Restructuring Costs Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, for non current provision for dividends is the allowance that the reporting entity has made in terms of the obligation for declared dividends that are expected to be paid beyond the next 12 months.
content.name: Liabilities Provisions Non Current Dividends Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, for all provisions raised for the restructuring of an organisation that are not due and payable within the next 12 months, including:
- severance, termination and redundancy payments; and
- integration cost.
content.name: Liabilities Provisions Non Current Restructuring Costs Amount

content.definition: This is the value, during the relevant period, of fee expense of the reporting party that relates to the management of the entity's investment portfolios except fees paid to asset consultants. Include fees paid to investment managers, including independent third parties as well as related entities.
content.name: Expense Operating Investment Management Fees Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, during the relevant period, for  fees paid/payable to asset consultants engaged by the trustees, in relation to the management of the superannuation entity's investment portfolios. Include fees paid to independent third parties as well as related entities of the superannuation entity.

Include all expenses which are associated with the generation of income on the investment portfolio of the entity. 

Do not include expenses of an administrative or operating nature.

Important:
Do not net fee related income rebates off against investment expenses.
Commissions or deductions should be shown on a gross basis here. For example, where there is a separately identifiable charge to the entity, fees charged by the asset consultants should not be netted against investment income.
content.name: Expense Operating Investment Asset Consultant Fees Amount

content.definition: This is the value, during the relevant period, of any fees paid/payable by the reporting party that relate to the provision of actuarial services as determined in accordance with relevant accounting standards.
content.name: Expense Operating Actuary Fees Amount

content.definition: This is the value, during the relevant period, for fees for all external audit services.
content.name: Auditor Disclosures Remuneration On External Audit Services Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the number of lives insured in the fund multiplied by $20,000.
content.name: Equity Notional Fund Balance Amount

content.definition: This is the value, during the relevant period, for the expense for benefits paid to members by the trustee(s) under the early release provisions relating to severe financial hardship or compassionate grounds.
content.name: Superannuation Payment Benefit Lump Sum Financial Hardship And Compassionate Grounds Amount

content.definition: For interpretation/definition of this item refer to the Australian Accounting Standards, as an example, see provided reference
content.name: Profit Or Loss Negative Goodwill Amount

content.definition: For interpretation/definition of this item refer to the Australian Accounting Standards, as an example, see provided reference
content.name: Expense Bad And Doubtful Debts Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, during the relevant period, for:
:-any gains on foreign exchange separately for each region
:-bargain purchases immediately recognised in profit and loss
:-the value of any defined benefit actuarial gains recognised
:-all other income not reported
:-report any gain on the measurement of a non-current asset (or disposal group) classified as held for sale that does not meet the definition of a discontinued operation
content.name: Income Investment Other Amount

content.definition: For interpretation/definition of this item refer to the Australian Accounting Standards, as an example, see provided reference
content.name: Equity Adjustments In Retained Profits Change In Standards Amount

content.definition: This is the value, during the relevant period, for fees for all internal audit services.
content.name: Auditor Disclosures Remuneration On Internal Audit Services Amount

content.definition: This is the value of the reduction in the reporting party's retained profits due to the buy back, or repurchase, of shares on issue during the relevant period. This represents the portion of the consideration used for share buy backs that is allocated to retained profits
content.name: Equity Reduction In Retained Profits Share Buy Back Amount

content.definition: This is the value, during the relevant period, of amounts transferred out resulting in a decrease in the reserves in accordance with Australian Accounting Standards.
content.name: Equity Transferred From Reserves Amount

content.definition: Report the value, as at the reporting date, of retained earnings available for appropriation in the form of a distribution to equity holders or a transfer to reserves.
content.name: Equity Available For Appropriation Amount

content.definition: This is the value, during the relevant period, of amounts transferred in resulting in an increase in the reserves in accordance with Australian Accounting Standards.
content.name: Equity Transferred To Reserves Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, for the balancing item within the list in which it is being used.
content.name: Assets Foreign Assets Other Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, for any timing adjustments made to asset total for recording securities held on a settlement day rather than trade day basis.
content.name: Assets Other Financial Assets Trade Day Versus Settlement Adjustments Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, for securities purchased under agreements to resell, stock borrowing.

Treatment in accordance with relevant Australian Accounting Standards. Where the transferee of the stock effectively receives a lenders rate of return (i.e. the underlying risks and rewards of ownership of the underlying stock is not effectively transferred), these transactions are to be accounted for as collateralised lending activities. Securities purchased under agreements to resell represents the receivable due .
content.name: Assets Other Financial Assets Claims Arising From Repos And Stock Borrowing Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, for the value of derivatives that represent a net gain to the reporting entity, determined in accordance with relevant Australian Accounting Standards.
content.name: Assets Other Financial Assets Derivative Financial Instruments Total Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, for any receivables from operating leases of terms of one year or more for tangible assets for example motor vehicles and other plant and equipment. Exclude leasing of land and buildings.
content.name: Assets Other Non Financial Assets Operating Lease Receivables Machinery And Equipment Amount

content.definition: This is the value, during the relevant period, for the average balance of interest earning securities. The average may be calculated by any method consistent with internal systems of the reporting entity.
content.name: Assets Average Balance Of Interest Earning Investment Securities Physical Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, for any timing adjustments made to liability total for recording securities held on a settlement day rather than trade day basis.
content.name: Liabilities Other Financial Liabilities Trade Day Versus Settlement Adjustments Amount

content.definition:
Report the value of the derivative financial instruments on issue by the reporting party as at the reporting date, and where the net position of these instruments is unfavourable to the reporting party. This item is to be determined in accordance with the accounting standards. 
A derivative is a financial instrument that is derived from some other asset, index, value or other variable (known as the underlying). Derivatives allow risk about the price of the underlying asset to be transferred from one party to another.
content.name: Liabilities Other Financial Liabilities Derivative Financial Instruments Total Amount

content.guidance: This is the balancing item in the list in which it is being used
content.name: Liabilities Total Other Amount

content.definition: This is the value, for the relevant period, of contingent liabilities arising from the endorsement of bills of exchange by the reporting party, where the reporting party is the first endorser of a non-Australian Deposit-taking Institutions or Registered Financial Corporations accepted bill.
content.name: Liabilities Contingent Liabilities Arising From Bill Endorsements Amount

content.definition: Report the value, as at the reporting date, of accumulated amortisation and impairment on intangible assets with a finite life, as determined in accordance with relevant accounting standards.
content.name: Assets Intangible Impairment Intangible Assets With A Finite Life Amount

content.definition: Report the value, as at the reporting date, of accumulated amortisation and impairment on intangible assets with an infinite life, as determined in accordance with relevant accounting standards.
content.name: Assets Intangible Impairment Intangible Assets With An Infinite Life Amount

content.definition: Report the value of finance lease liability not due and payable within 12 months.
content.name: Liabilities Other Financial Liabilities Non Current Finance Lease Amount

content.definition:
Report all borrowings by the reporting entity in the form of commercial paper, promissory notes and other forms of securities issued by the insurer. Commercial paper or promissory notes are short-term debt securities usually issued with an original term to maturity of less than 180 days.
Include all notes/securities issued with a residual term to maturity of more than 12 months. Commercial paper or promissory notes with a residual maturity greater than 12 months should be reported as "non-current liability - borrowings".
content.name: Liabilities Other Financial Liabilities Non Current Debt Securities Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, for the member's total death and or disability insurance premiums paid or payable during the reporting period.
content.name: Insurance Expense Premium Members Death Disability Gross Amount

content.definition: This is the value, for the relevant period, of plant and equipment net of accumulated depreciation and impairment, as determined in accordance with relevant accounting standards.
content.name: Assets Other Non Financial Assets Plant And Equipment Excluding Property Net Total Amount

content.definition: This is the value, during the relevant period, for the average balance of all interest earning assets excluding Intragroup.  The average may be calculated by any method consistent with internal systems of the reporting entity.
content.name: Assets Average Balance Of Interest Earning Total Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of borrowings. This represents amounts taken in the form of loans. This item is to be determined in accordance with relevant accounting standards.
content.name: Liabilities Other Financial Liabilities Borrowings Total Amount

content.definition: This is the value, during the relevant period, for the average balance of interest earning trading securities total.  The average may be calculated by any method consistent with internal systems of the reporting entity.
content.name: Assets Average Balance Of Interest Earning Trading Securities Total Amount

content.definition: This is the value, during the relevant period, for the average balance of interest earning loans and advances credit cards.  The average may be calculated by any method consistent with internal systems of the reporting entity.
content.name: Assets Average Balance Of Interest Earning Loans And Advances Credit Cards Amount

content.definition: This is the value, during the relevant period, for the average balance of interest earning loans and advances Housing Loans.  The average may be calculated by any method consistent with internal systems of the reporting entity.
content.name: Assets Average Balance Of Interest Earning Loans And Advances Housing Loans Amount

content.definition: This is the value, during the relevant period, for the average balance of interest earning loans and advances lease financing.  The average may be calculated by any method consistent with internal systems of the reporting entity.
content.name: Assets Average Balance Of Interest Earning Loans And Advances Lease Financing Amount

content.definition: This is the value, during the relevant period, for the average balance of interest earning loans and advances other.  The average may be calculated by any method consistent with internal systems of the reporting entity.
content.name: Assets Average Balance Of Interest Earning Loans And Advances Other Amount

content.definition: This is the value, during the relevant period, for the average balance of interest earning loans and advances overdrafts.  The average may be calculated by any method consistent with internal systems of the reporting entity.
content.name: Assets Average Balance Of Interest Earning Loans And Advances Overdrafts Amount

content.definition: This is the value, during the relevant period, for the average balance of interest earning loans and advances term loans.  The average may be calculated by any method consistent with internal systems of the reporting entity.
content.name: Assets Average Balance Of Interest Earning Loans And Advances Term Loans Amount

content.definition: This is the value, during the relevant period, for the average balance of interest bearing bonds notes and long term borrowings. The average may be calculated by any method consistent with internal systems of the reporting entity.
content.name: Liabilities Average Balance Of Interest Bearing Bonds Notes And Long Term Borrowings Amount

content.definition: This is the value, during the relevant period, for the average balance of interest bearing deposits.  The average may be calculated by any method consistent with internal systems of the reporting entity.
content.name: Liabilities Average Balance Of Interest Bearing Deposits Amount

content.definition: This is the value, during the relevant period, for the average balance of interest bearing loan capital over the reporting period.  The average may be calculated by any method consistent with internal systems of the reporting entity.
content.name: Liabilities Average Balance Of Interest Bearing Loan Capital Amount

content.definition: This is the value, during the relevant period, for the average balance of interest bearing other borrowings over the reporting period.  The average may be calculated by any method consistent with internal systems of the reporting entity.
content.name: Liabilities Average Balance Of Interest Bearing Other Borrowings Amount

content.definition: This is the value, during the relevant period, for the average balance of total interest bearing liabilities excluding Intragroup over the reporting period.  The average may be calculated by any method consistent with internal systems of the reporting entity.
content.name: Liabilities Average Balance Of Interest Bearing Total Amount

content.definition: This is the value, during the relevant period, for the average balance of interest earnings cash and liquid assets.  The average may be calculated by any method consistent with internal systems of the reporting entity.
content.name: Assets Average Balance Of Interest Earning Cash And Liquid Assets Amount

content.definition: Computer software expensed is the cost of acquiring, developing or commissioning software for the purpose of performing the functions for which it was acquired or developed. The development of web sites is included in the scope of computer software.
content.name: Expense Computer Software Amount

content.definition: Operating expenses are defined as expenses incurred in the ordinary activities of an entity. Other operating expenses refers to all operating expenses incurred that are not collected elsewhere.
content.name: Expense Other Operating Amount

content.definition:
A royalty is defined as a right to use the property of another person for economic gain. This is usually an intellectual property, such as a copyright (e.g. in a book) or a patent (e.g. in an invention). Natural resources are defined as unexploited products of nature that have economic value e.g. forests, petroleum deposits, ore deposits.

Natural resource royalties refers to the right to use the unexploited products of nature which have economic value on land owned by another person for economic gain.

Royalties expenses excluding natural resource royalties refers to the payments a business makes in exchange for the right to use the property of another person for economic gain, other than for natural resource royalties.
content.name: Expense Royalties Other Amount

content.definition:
Capital expenditure is the expenditure by an entity of a significant amount for the purchase or improvement of a fixed asset; the amount expended would warrant the item being depreciated over an estimated useful life of a reasonably extended period. Capital expenditure is not charged against the profits of the entity when it takes place, but is regarded as an investment to be capitalised in the balance sheet as a fixed asset and subsequently charged against profits by depreciating the asset over its estimated useful life.

Road vehicles refer to vehicles driven by a motor, usually an internal combustion engine, such as a motor car, bus, truck, motorcycle or the like, made for travel on roadways open for the passage of road vehicles. It excludes tractors.

Capital expenditure for road vehicles is limited to the cost of the motor vehicle and associated capitalised costs only (e.g. road vehicle transfer costs incurred upon acquiring the asset) and does not include capital expenditure on any other asset types.
content.name: Capital Expenditure Road Vehicles Amount

content.definition:
Capital expenditure is the expenditure by an entity of a significant amount for the purchase or improvement of a fixed asset; the amount expended would warrant the item being depreciated over an estimated useful life of a reasonably extended period. Capital expenditure is not charged against the profits of the entity when it takes place, but is regarded as an investment to be capitalised in the balance sheet as a fixed asset and subsequently charged against profits by depreciating the asset over its estimated useful life.

Capital expenditure for computer software is limited to computer software and associated capitalised costs only (e.g. legal fees) and does not include capital expenditure on any other asset types.
content.name: Capital Expenditure Computer Software Amount

content.definition:
Capital expenditure is the expenditure by an entity of a significant amount for the purchase or improvement of a fixed asset; the amount expended would warrant the item being depreciated over an estimated useful life of a reasonably extended period. Capital expenditure is not charged against the profits of the entity when it takes place, but is regarded as an investment to be capitalised in the balance sheet as a fixed asset and subsequently charged against profits by depreciating or amortising the asset over its estimated useful life.

Capital expenditure for communications equipment is limited to communications equipment and associated capitalised costs only (e.g. legal fees) and does not include capital expenditure on any other asset types.
content.name: Capital Expenditure Communications Equipment Amount

content.definition:
Capital expenditure is the expenditure by an entity of a significant amount for the purchase or improvement of a fixed asset; the amount expended would warrant the item being depreciated over an estimated useful life of a reasonably extended period. Capital expenditure is not charged against the profits of the entity when it takes place, but is regarded as an investment to be capitalised in the balance sheet as a fixed asset and subsequently charged against profits by depreciating the asset over its estimated useful life.

Capital expenditure for land is limited to land and associated capitalised costs only (e.g. legal fees) and does not include capital expenditure on any other asset types.
content.name: Capital Expenditure Land Amount

content.definition:
Capital expenditure is the expenditure by an entity of a significant amount for the purchase or improvement of a fixed asset; the amount expended would warrant the item being amortised over an estimated useful life of a reasonably extended period. Capital expenditure is not charged against the profits of the entity when it takes place, but is regarded as an investment to be capitalised in the balance sheet as a fixed asset and subsequently charged against profits by amortising the asset over its estimated useful life.

Capital expenditure for intangible assets is limited to intangible assets and associated capitalised costs only (e.g. legal fees) and does not include capital expenditure on any other asset types.
content.name: Capital Expenditure Intangible Assets Amount

content.definition:
Capital work increases the value of assets by extending, altering and/or improving them. The assets to which capital work is typically undertaken are a wide range of structures that include buildings, roads, bridges, pipelines, retaining walls and environment protection earthworks, but extends to manufacturing and enhancing pre-existing computer software products. The work may be undertaken for use by the business that carried it out or used for rental or lease to other businesses.

Capitalised wages and salaries are those amounts paid for capital work done by own employees for own use or for rental or lease (e.g. wages and salaries paid to spread gravel required as an underlay for a carpark that is to be covered with bitumen) and does not include expenditure on any other asset types.
content.name: Capital Expenditure Capital Work Wages And Salaries Amount

content.definition: Fringe benefits tax is a tax on the value of benefits provided to an employee or an employees associate by an employer in respect of the employees duties. The employer is liable for payment of fringe benefits tax. A benefit is widely defined to include any right, privilege, service or facility.
content.name: Fringe Benefits Tax Expense Amount

content.definition: Payroll tax is a tax levied on the amount of the business payroll at a rate determined in proportion to the number of employees the business has.
content.name: Payroll Tax Expense Amount

content.definition:
Workers compensation is a compulsory insurance program financed by contributions from employers, to pay for medical care and rehabilitation of workers who are incapacitated by work-related injury or illness.

Workers compensation expenses refers to expenses related to workers compensation premiums and associated costs, including any provisions for workers compensation expenses.
content.name: Employment Conditions Workers Compensation Amount
Assets Investment Including Accrued Income Other Net Market Value Amount

content.definition: Report the value of benefit funds which has not been allocated to either the benefit fund members or to the management fund.
content.name: Equity Reserves Unallocated Benefit Fund Amount

content.definition:
Report the look-through adjustment for loans classified as assets held indirectly via listed unit trusts, unlisted unit trusts or controlled unit trusts.

A look through adjustment item represents the adjustment required to convert effective holdings in investments via trusts from aggregated amounts classified as loans or unit trusts to the appropriate categories on a look-through basis.
content.name: Assets Investment Loans Adjustment Look Through Amount

content.definition:
Report the net of all movements in equity investments or securities other than acquisition and disposal transactions. These movements would not involve the exchange of valuable consideration between counterparties. This may include changes arising from the revaluation increments and decrements of the debt securities, or income accrued on discount securities. Where this results in a net decrease in the net market value of equity securities, then report a negative figure.

Equity investments or securities are, as defined by the Australian Accounting Standards, contracts that evidence a residual interest in the assets of an entity after deducting all its liabilities. This includes equity securities lent or sold by the entity under repurchase agreements, where the transaction does not result in the transfer of the rights of ownership of the securities away from the entity to another party.

If the reporting entity holds listed notes/hybrid securities which have characteristics of a debt security & an equity security, these securities should be classified in the same manner as they appear in the entity's audited financial statements.
content.name: Assets Investment Equity Securities Net Other Changes Amount

content.definition:
Report the hedging adjustment required to translate the aggregate indexed debt securities balance to the effective post-derivatives position. 

A hedging adjustment represents the adjustment required to translate the effective exposure associated with hedging investments. The purpose of a hedging investment is to offset the risk of changes in the fair value or investment cash flows of another contract.

Indexed debt securities pay an income stream that is dependent on an external factor.
content.name: Assets Investment Debt Securities Indexed Adjustment Hedging Amount

content.definition: Report benefits paid or payable in relation to the surrender or early termination of a policy, i.e. where the policy is ended by either party prior to the maturity date. Where no amount would be paid, the value to be reported is the discounted present value of the unexpired risks, future payments and/or contractual premium refunds.
content.name: Expense Insurance Surrender And Termination Amount

content.definition: Report the value of statutory fund profits allocated to participating policy owners generally, but not yet vested as specific amounts to particular policies.
content.name: Liabilities Insurance Retained Profits Policy Owners Amount
Income Insurance Other Amount

content.definition: Report the total value of policy expenses recognised as a withdrawal of the deposit (investment) component or change in policy liability, net of reinsurance.
content.name: Expense Insurance Total Deposit Component Amount

content.definition:
Report the net of all acquisition and disposal transactions of securitised instruments. These transactions involve the exchange of valuable consideration between counterparties. Where this results in a net decrease in the net market value of securitised instruments, then report a negative figure.

Securitised instruments represent securities using specifically selected assets (eg. mortgages, receivables) to provide backing (collateral) for the securities and generate the payment streams necessary to fulfil interest and principal requirements for investors. These forms of securities are usually issued by a Special Purpose Vehicle (SPV).
content.name: Assets Investment Debt Securities Asset Backed Net Acquisition Disposal Transactions Amount

content.definition:
Report the net value of all acquisition and disposal transactions of off balance sheet exposures related to assets classified as equity investments or securities. These transactions involve the exchange of valuable consideration between counterparties. Where this results in a net decrease in the net market value of equity securities, then report a negative figure.

Equity investments or securities are, as defined by the Australian Accounting Standards, contracts that evidence a residual interest in the assets of an entity after deducting all its liabilities. This includes equity securities lent or sold by the entity under repurchase agreements, where the transaction does not result in the transfer of the rights of ownership of the securities away from the entity to another party. Also included are interests in joint ventures.

If the reporting entity holds listed notes/hybrid securities which have characteristics of a debt security & an equity security, these securities should be classified in the same manner as they appear in the entity's audited financial statements.

The acquisition cost, or historical cost, of an asset is the original cost paid to acquire the asset, at the date the asset was initially acquired. Where the asset was acquired in stages, sum the initial acquisition cost of each stage, but only to the extent the acquisitions occurred during the relevant period.

The disposal of an asset takes place if a change of ownership occurs, whether because of some act or event (such as damage) or by operation of law, e.g. when an asset is transferred from one person to another by way of sale or gift.

Off-balance sheet asset exposures relate to those assets or rights that do not satisfy the recognition requirements of the relevant accounting standards and are therefore not recognised on the face of the balance sheet, or statement of financial position, such as contingent assets, performance-related rights and guarantees.
content.name: Assets Exposures Off Balance Sheet Equity Securities Net Acquisition Disposal Transactions Amount

content.definition:
Record the face value, or principle value, as at the relevant date, of off balance sheet exposures related to liabilities classified as audit and tax agent fees payable.

Audit and tax agent fees are typically amounts payable to an entity for performing agreed assurance and taxation services.

Net market value or fair value is the amount which could be expected to be received from the disposal of a liability in an orderly market; or in an arm's length transaction between knowledgeable, willing parties; after deducting costs expected to be incurred in realising the proceeds of such a disposal.

Off-balance sheet liability exposures relate to those liabilities or obligations that do not satisfy the recognition requirements of the relevant accounting standards and are therefore not recognised on the face of the balance sheet, or statement of financial position.
content.name: Liabilities Exposures Off Balance Sheet Audit Taxation Fees Payable Amount

content.definition: Report benefits paid or payable as withdrawal of any deposit elements for death and/or disability claims on life investment business.
content.name: Expense Insurance Claim Death Disability Deposit Component Amount

content.definition:
Report the Best Estimate Liability amount of policies that have been ceded under reinsurance.

Best Estimate Liability is the amount expected on Best Estimate Assumptions to be required to the end of the benefit period to meet future benefits and expenses related to past transactions for the business in force. The calculation process will take into account all factors which are known to be material, including future investment earnings, taxation, any options under the policies and future premiums, where relevant to the calculation.

Best Estimate Assumptions are assumptions about future experience determined in accordance with relevant actuarial valuation standards.
content.name: Liabilities Insurance Best Estimate Reinsurance Amount

content.definition:
Report the net market value, or fair value, of off balance sheet exposures related to assets classified as cash and fixed interest investments.

Net market value, or fair value, is the amount which could be expected to be received from the disposal of an asset in an orderly market; or in an arm's length transaction between knowledgeable, willing parties; after deducting costs expected to be incurred in realising the proceeds of such a disposal.

Off-balance sheet asset exposures relate to those assets or rights that do not satisfy the recognition requirements of the relevant accounting standards and are therefore not recognised on the face of the balance sheet, or statement of financial position, such as contingent assets, performance-related rights and guarantees.
content.name: Assets Exposures Off Balance Sheet Cash And Fixed Interest Amount

content.definition:
Report the value of eligible approved subordinated debt, as determined in accordance with the approval letter received from the relevant regulatory authority.

Subordinated debt is that debt which is ranked lower in priority than other senior debt, including policyholders. In the event of bankruptcy, subordinated debtholders receive payment only after senior debt claims are paid in full.

The eligible amount is the quantum of the approved subordinated debt (as determined in accordance with the approval letter received from the relevant regulatory authority) that can be used in meeting the solvency/capital adequacy requirements of the reporting party.
content.name: Liabilities Subordinated Debt Approved Eligible Amount

content.definition: Report the amount of interest (investment earnings) on Retained Profits as per prudential standards
content.name: Profit Or Loss Insurance Interest On Retained Profits Amount

content.definition:
Report the hedging adjustment required to translate the aggregate non-indexed debt securities balance to the effective post-derivatives position. 

A hedging adjustment represents the adjustment required to translate the effective exposure associated with hedging investments. The purpose of a hedging investment is to offset the risk of changes in the fair value or investment cash flows of another contract.

Non-indexed debt securities pay an income stream that is not dependent on any external factor.
content.name: Assets Investment Debt Securities Non Indexed Adjustment Hedging Amount

content.definition:
Report the total gross policy liability as per prudential standards, excluding current year bonuses. Note that this differs to the accounting standards treatment.

Report amounts gross of ceded reinsurance but inclusive of inwards reinsurance.
content.name: Liabilities Insurance Policy Gross Excluding Current Bonus Amount

content.definition:
The value to be reported is the net market value, or fair value, of the equity component of hybrid securities, plus income accrued but not received in relation to this asset. This method of disclosure differs from the Australian Accounting Standards.

Hybrid securities, or compound financial instruments, as defined by the Australian Accounting Standards, are financial instruments that, from the issuer's perspective, contain a liability and an equity element. 

Compound financial instruments include all equities related items such as convertible notes and other hybrid securities which, taking into account market conditions, have attributes that demonstrate exposure to equities markets.

Net market value, or fair value, is the amount which could be expected to be received from the disposal of an asset in an orderly market; or in an arm's length transaction between knowledgeable, willing parties; after deducting costs expected to be incurred in realising the proceeds of such a disposal.
content.name: Assets Investment Equity Securities Hybrid Net Market Value Plus Accrued Income Amount

content.definition:
Report the value of gross policy liabilities assumed under reinsurance, valued in accordance with prudential standards LPS 1.04, Valuation of Policy Liabilities. 

This amount includes liabilities for deferred fee revenue and deferred acquisition costs. For participating benefits, include bonuses in respect of the relevant period. This method of disclosure differs from the Australian Accounting Standards.

Fees are defined as amounts of money paid for a particular piece of work or for a particular right or service (i.e. policy management fees).

Reinsurance contracts as defined by the Australian Accounting Standards, are insurance contracts issued by one insurer (the reinsurer) to compensate another insurer (the cedent) for losses on one or more contracts issued by the cedent.
content.name: Liabilities Insurance Gross Policy Liabilities Reinsurance Including Unearned Fee Revenue And Deferred Acquisition Costs Amount

content.definition:
Report the look-through adjustment for cash held indirectly via listed unit trusts, unlisted unit trusts or controlled unit trusts.

A look through adjustment item represents the adjustment required to convert effective holdings in investments via trusts from aggregated amounts classified as equities or unit trusts to the appropriate categories on a look-through basis.
content.name: Assets Cash And Liquid Assets Adjustment Look Through Amount
Expense Insurance Other Amount

content.definition:
Report the net of all acquisition and disposal transactions of equity investments or securities. These transactions involve the exchange of valuable consideration between counterparties. Where this results in a net decrease in the net market value of equity securities, then report a negative figure.

Equity investments or securities are, as defined by the Australian Accounting Standards, contracts that evidence a residual interest in the assets of an entity after deducting all its liabilities. This includes equity securities lent or sold by the entity under repurchase agreements, where the transaction does not result in the transfer of the rights of ownership of the securities away from the entity to another party. Also included are interests in joint ventures.

If the reporting entity holds listed notes/hybrid securities which have characteristics of a debt security & an equity security, these securities should be classified in the same manner as they appear in the entity's audited financial statements.
content.name: Assets Investment Equity Securities Net Acquisition Disposal Transactions Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the date the asset was acquired, of the acquisition or historical cost of the equity security.
content.guidance: The acquisition cost, or historical cost of an equity security is the original cost paid to acquire the asset, at the date the asset was initially acquired. Where the asset was acquired in stages, sum the initial acquisition cost of each stage. The cost of an asset or investment acquisition, as defined by the Australian Accounting Standards, is the amount of cash or cash equivalents paid or the fair value of the other consideration given to acquire an asset at the time of its acquisition or construction, or, when applicable, the amount attributed to that asset when initially recognised in accordance with the specific requirements of other Australian Accounting Standards.
content.name: Assets Investment Equity Securities Historical Cost Amount

content.definition:
Report the net market value, or fair value, of off balance sheet exposures related to assets classified as investment loans and advances .

Net market value, or fair value, is the amount which could be expected to be received from the disposal of an asset in an orderly market; or in an arm's length transaction between knowledgeable, willing parties; after deducting costs expected to be incurred in realising the proceeds of such a disposal.

Off-balance sheet asset exposures relate to those assets or rights that do not satisfy the recognition requirements of the relevant accounting standards and are therefore not recognised on the face of the balance sheet, or statement of financial position, such as contingent assets, performance-related rights and guarantees.
content.name: Assets Exposures Off Balance Sheet Loans And Advances Amount

content.definition:
The amount of interest income derived from investment in debt securities recognised as income under the Australian Accounting Standards.

Debt securities are transferable instruments evidencing a relationship of indebtedness. It is characterised by having a definable income stream that is not based on the economic performance of the issuing entity.
content.name: Income Interest Debt Securities Net Amount

content.definition:
Report the changes to the Experience Profit or Loss for the period in relation to the surrender or early termination of a policy, i.e. where the policy is ended by either party prior to the maturity date.

The total Experience Profit or Loss is the profit or loss arising in the period from differences between the actual experience during the period and the expected experience on the basis of the Best Estimate Assumptions at the beginning of the period.

Best Estimate Assumptions are assumptions about future experience determined in accordance with relevant actuarial valuation standards.
content.name: Profit Or Loss Insurance Experience Discontinuance Amount

content.definition: This is the value, during the relevant period, of total payments to policy holders and net of outwards reinsurance.
content.name: Expense Insurance Payouts Net Of Reinsurance Amount

content.definition:
Report the value of the deposit (investment component) elements of Conversions into this statutory fund.

Life insurance policies are contracts (policies) that will pay a specified sum to beneficiaries upon the death of the insured.
content.name: Income Insurance Life Policy Conversion Deposit Component Amount

content.definition:
Report the hedging adjustment required to translate the aggregate loans classified as assets balance to the effective post-derivatives position. 

A hedging adjustment represents the adjustment required to translate the effective exposure associated with hedging investments. The purpose of a hedging investment is to offset the risk of changes in the fair value or investment cash flows of another contract.
content.name: Assets Investment Loans Adjustment Hedging Amount

content.definition: Report the value of all fixed costs incurred when acquiring new business and all variable costs other than those related to commissions and other incremental expenses incurred in relation to new insurance business.
content.name: Expense Insurance Policy Acquisition Other Amount
Assets Investment Exposure Other Amount

content.definition:
This is the liability in respect of the Management Services Element, determined as the difference between the Policy Liability and the Life Investment Contract liability as recognised and measured according to accounting standards, that has been ceded under reinsurance.
Include reinsured liabilities for deferred acquisition cost and deferred fee revenues.
content.name: Liabilities Insurance Balancing Item Policy Liabilities Amount

content.definition:
Report the net value of all acquisition and disposal transactions of off balance sheet exposures related to assets classified as balanced or mixed mandates. These transactions involve the exchange of valuable consideration between counterparties. Where this results in a net decrease in the net market value of assets, then report a negative figure.

The acquisition cost, or historical cost, of an asset is the original cost paid to acquire the asset, at the date the asset was initially acquired. Where the asset was acquired in stages, sum the initial acquisition cost of each stage, but only to the extent the acquisitions occurred during the relevant period.

The disposal of an asset takes place if a change of ownership occurs, whether because of some act or event (such as damage) or by operation of law, e.g. when an asset is transferred from one person to another by way of sale or gift.

Off-balance sheet asset exposures relate to those assets or rights that do not satisfy the recognition requirements of the relevant accounting standards and are therefore not recognised on the face of the balance sheet, or statement of financial position, such as contingent assets, performance-related rights and guarantees.
content.name: Assets Exposures Off Balance Sheet Balanced Mixed Mandates Net Acquisition Disposal Transactions Amount

content.definition:
Record the face value, or principle value, as at the relevant date, of off balance sheet exposures related to liabilities classified as Adminitstration Fees payable.

Adminitstration Fees are typically amounts payable to an entity for performing required administration activities.

Net market value or fair value is the amount which could be expected to be received from the disposal of a liability in an orderly market; or in an arm's length transaction between knowledgeable, willing parties; after deducting costs expected to be incurred in realising the proceeds of such a disposal.

Off-balance sheet liability exposures relate to those liabilities or obligations that do not satisfy the recognition requirements of the relevant accounting standards and are therefore not recognised on the face of the balance sheet, or statement of financial position.
content.name: Liabilities Exposures Off Balance Sheet Administration Fees Payable Amount

content.definition:
Report the net market value, or fair value, of both negotiable and non-negotiable bank certificates of deposit. 

Certificates of Deposit are certificates issued by a bank or other financial institution that indicate a specified sum of money has been deposited at the issuing depository institution.

Net market value, or fair value, is the amount which could be expected to be received from the disposal of an asset in an orderly market; or in an arm's length transaction between knowledgeable, willing parties; after deducting costs expected to be incurred in realising the proceeds of such a disposal.
content.name: Assets Investment Certificates of Deposit Net Market Value Amount

content.definition:
Report the net of all acquisition and disposal transactions of debt securities that are classified as bonds, notes, commercial paper or promissory notes. These are written promises to pay a specified sum of money on demand or at a specified future date. They may be secured or unsecured with interest payable over the term to maturity or on maturity.

This amount does not include bills of exchange or bank certificates of deposit.

These transactions involve the exchange of valuable consideration between counterparties.
content.name: Assets Investment Debt Securities Net Acquisition Disposal Transactions Amount

content.definition:
The value to be reported is the net market value, or fair value, of borrowings, plus overdrafts less any borrowings classified as seed capital. This method of disclosure differs from the Australian Accounting Standards.

Borrowings are amounts of money on loan from financial institutions or other creditors with the promise or understanding that it will be repaid.

Seed capital is the preliminary contribution of funding toward the financing of a new business. Commonly this is in the form of a loan, usually provided by a related entity.

Net market value, or fair value, is the amount which could be expected to be received from the disposal of an asset in an orderly market; or in an arm's length transaction between knowledgeable, willing parties; after deducting costs expected to be incurred in realising the proceeds of such a disposal.
content.name: Liabilities Borrowings Including Overdrafts Excluding Seed Capital Amount

content.definition:
Report the net market value, or fair value, of borrowings, including overdrafts. This method of disclosure differs from the Australian Accounting Standards.

Borrowings are amounts of money on loan from financial institutions or other creditors with the promise or understanding that it will be repaid.

Net market value, or fair value, is the amount which could be expected to be received from the disposal of an asset in an orderly market; or in an arm's length transaction between knowledgeable, willing parties; after deducting costs expected to be incurred in realising the proceeds of such a disposal.
content.name: Liabilities Borrowings Including Overdrafts Amount

content.definition: Report the amount due but not yet received as at the relevant date in relation to investment assets, excluding any amounts related to income accrued but not yet received.
content.name: Assets Investment Receivables Investment Assets Excluding Accrued Income Net Amount

content.definition:
Report the net market value, or fair value, of off balance sheet exposures related to assets classified as investment property.

For prudential reporting purposes a property investment exists where the investment (earnings and capital value) are dependent on the cash flows generated by the property through sale or rental income. 

Include: 
- Property investments acquired as part of the internal investment management of the reporting party; and 
- Underlying property investments held in the form of an external individually managed mandate/portfolio or discretely managed portfolio. 
Exclude: 
- Direct investments in property trusts (both listed and unlisted).

Net market value, or fair value, is the amount which could be expected to be received from the disposal of an asset in an orderly market; or in an arm's length transaction between knowledgeable, willing parties; after deducting costs expected to be incurred in realising the proceeds of such a disposal.

Off-balance sheet asset exposures relate to those assets or rights that do not satisfy the recognition requirements of the relevant accounting standards and are therefore not recognised on the face of the balance sheet, or statement of financial position, such as contingent assets, performance-related rights and guarantees.
content.name: Assets Exposures Off Balance Sheet Real Estate Property Amount

content.definition: The total Experience Profit or Loss is the profit or loss arising in the period from differences between the actual experience during the period and the expected experience on the basis of the Best Estimate Assumptions at the beginning of the period.
content.name: Profit Or Loss Insurance Experience Total Amount

content.definition: Management Services Profit is determined as the sum of all cash flows relating to the management service element of Life Investment Contracts (as per Australian Accounting Standards), plus/(less) the change in the value of any asset/(liability) arising in respect of the management services element. Essentially fees less expenses for that component of the business, where fees include changes in deferred fee revenue and expenses include changes in deferred acquisition costs.
content.name: Profit Or Loss Insurance Management Services Component Amount

content.definition:
Report expenses incurred in relation to general insurance policies.

General insurance policies are all insurance business other than Life and Health insurance. Life insurance policies are contracts (policies) that will pay a specified sum to beneficiaries upon the death of the insured. Health insurance policies are contracts (policies) that will pay a specified sum to beneficiaries in relation to healthcare expenses of the insured.
content.name: Expense Operating General Insurance Amount

content.definition:
Report the net of all movements in securitised instruments other than acquisition and disposal transactions. These movements would not involve the exchange of valuable consideration between counterparties. This may include adjustments and/or changes arising from the revaluation increments and decrements of the securitised instruments, or income accrued. Where this results in a net decrease in the net market value of securitised instruments, then report a negative figure.

Securitised instruments represent securities using specifically selected assets (eg. mortgages, receivables) to provide backing (collateral) for the securities and generate the payment streams necessary to fulfil interest and principal requirements for investors. These forms of securities are usually issued by a Special Purpose Vehicle (SPV). 

Net market value, or fair value, is the amount which could be expected to be received from the disposal of an asset in an orderly market; or in an arm's length transaction between knowledgeable, willing parties; after deducting costs expected to be incurred in realising the proceeds of such a disposal.
content.name: Assets Investment Debt Securities Asset Backed Net Other Changes Amount

content.definition:
Report the net present value of future Policy Owner Bonuses in relation to future profits for participating business. Current year bonuses are excluded.

Report amounts gross of ceded reinsurance but inclusive of inwards reinsurance.
content.name: Liabilities Insurance Participating Business Future Profits Gross Amount

content.definition: The cost of declared bonuses at the relevant date reflecting the cash value to the policy owners of those bonuses at the relevant date. Excludes interim and terminal bonuses.
content.name: Liabilities Insurance Bonus Declared Excluding Terminal Interim Amount

content.definition:
Record the face value, or principle value, as at the relevant date, of off balance sheet exposures related to liabilities classified as Management Fees payable.

Management Fees are typically amounts payable to an entity for performing agreed management activities.

Net market value or fair value is the amount which could be expected to be received from the disposal of a liability in an orderly market; or in an arm's length transaction between knowledgeable, willing parties; after deducting costs expected to be incurred in realising the proceeds of such a disposal.

Off-balance sheet liability exposures relate to those liabilities or obligations that do not satisfy the recognition requirements of the relevant accounting standards and are therefore not recognised on the face of the balance sheet, or statement of financial position.
content.name: Liabilities Exposures Off Balance Sheet Management Fees Payable Amount

content.definition:
Report the net market value, or fair value, of investments that result in an exposure to the asset class of property.

Net market value, or fair value, is the amount which could be expected to be received from the disposal of an asset in an orderly market; or in an arm's length transaction between knowledgeable, willing parties; after deducting costs expected to be incurred in realising the proceeds of such a disposal.
content.name: Assets Investment Exposure Property Class Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the assets held in respect of standard employer-sponsored business. This is the aggregate balance of the accounts of those members in the fund who joined the fund wholly or partly through an arrangement between the trustee of the regulated superannuation fund (including public offer funds) and each of the standard employer-sponsors which contribute to that fund.
content.name: Assets Standard Employer Sponsored Amount

content.definition:
Report the hedging adjustment required to translate the aggregate equities balance to the effective post-derivatives position. 

A hedging adjustment represents the adjustment required to translate the effective exposure associated with hedging investments. The purpose of a hedging investment is to offset the risk of changes in the fair value or investment cash flows of another contract.
content.name: Assets Investment Equity Securities Adjustment Hedging Amount

content.definition:
Report the total of all decreases to Contractual Regular Contributions due to claims or maturities during the period.

Decreases due to claims refer to the reduction in contractual regular contributions following a claim arising from the occurrence of an insured event. Note that it is only included when an insurance claim causes alteration or cessation of the premium, e.g. premiums paid on disability income policies will sometimes remain unaffected following a claim, depending on the policy terms and conditions.

Decreases due to maturities refer to the cessation of contractual regular contributions due to the maturity of a policy, i.e. following the completion of a policy's term. This would occur when a member retires and is paid his/her superannuation benefit, a policy owner reaches a defined age on an Endowment policy or the termination of a savings plan on or after the contractual period

Contractual Regular Contributions are the total gross premiums for the current relevant period that are accepted through direct debit, have a specific contractual requirement for future on-going premiums, have an expectation of renewal each year (e.g. Yearly Renewable term products) or generally cause a policy to discontinue on cessation of future payment.
content.name: Assets Insurance Contractual Regular Contributions Decrease Due To Claims Maturities Amount

content.definition:
The value to be reported is the net market value, or fair value, of equity investments or securities in corporations and interests in ventures, plus income accrued but not received in relation to these assets. This method of disclosure differs from the Australian Accounting Standards.

Equity investments or securities are, as defined by the Australian Accounting Standards, contracts that evidence a residual interest in the assets of an entity after deducting all its liabilities.

Interests in ventures are contracts that evidence a residual interest in the assets of a partnership, non-unitised trust or joint venture after deducting all of its liabilities.

Net market value, or fair value, is the amount which could be expected to be received from the disposal of an asset in an orderly market; or in an arm's length transaction between knowledgeable, willing parties; after deducting costs expected to be incurred in realising the proceeds of such a disposal.
content.name: Assets Investment Equity Securities Shares In Corporations And Interest In Other Ventures Net Market Value Plus Accrued Income Amount

content.definition:
Report the value of interest expense as determined in accordance with accounting standards that relates to subordinated debt.     
Subordinated debt is a debt where the claim to repayment ranks lower in priority to other claims.
content.name: Expense Interest Subordinated Debt Amount

content.definition: Report benefits paid or payable for claims due to maturity of policy. Policy maturity is where the agreed end date of the contract has been reached.
content.name: Expense Insurance Maturity Amount

content.definition:
Report the hedging adjustment required to translate the aggregate other liabilities balance to the effective post-derivatives position. This will contain liabilities other than:
- Borrowings
- Trade and other payables
- Provisions
- Gross policy liabilities
- Policy owner retained profits
- Unearned premium income
- Approved subordinated debt

A hedging adjustment represents the adjustment required to translate the effective exposure associated with hedging investments. The purpose of a hedging investment is to offset the risk of changes in the fair value or investment cash flows of another contract.
content.name: Liabilities Other Adjustment Hedging Amount

content.definition: Report the total deposit (investment) component of premiums received from all insurance investment policies, net of reinsurance.
content.name: Income Insurance Premium Net Of Reinsurance Deposit Component Amount

content.definition:
The value to be reported is the net market value, or fair value, of equity investments in unitised trusts, plus income accrued but not received in relation to these assets. This method of disclosure differs from the Australian Accounting Standards.

Equity investments or securities are, as defined by the Australian Accounting Standards, contracts that evidence a residual interest in the assets of an entity after deducting all its liabilities.

Unitised trusts are a type of managed investment which issues units representing equal shares in the trust's investments. The value of the units fluctuates in line with the value, and income received from, the underlying investments.

Net market value, or fair value, is the amount which could be expected to be received from the disposal of an asset in an orderly market; or in an arm's length transaction between knowledgeable, willing parties; after deducting costs expected to be incurred in realising the proceeds of such a disposal.
content.name: Assets Investment Equity Securities Units In Trusts Plus Accrued Income Amount
Expense Insurance Operating Other Amount
Assets Investment Other Adjustment Hedging Amount

content.definition:
Report the net market value, or fair value, of deposits, placements, loans and advances. 

This includes, but is not limited to:
- Interest-rate related cash and investments of the entity; and
- Deposits, placements, loans and advances.
This excludes:
- Debt securities (e.g. bills of exchange, certificates of deposit, commercial paper, promissory notes, Treasury Bonds, securitised instruments).
- Holding of units in unit trusts such as a cash management trust.

Net market value or fair value is the amount which could be expected to be received from the disposal of an asset in an orderly market; or in an arm's length transaction between knowledgeable, willing parties; after deducting costs expected to be incurred in realising the proceeds of such a disposal.
content.name: Assets Investment Deposits Placements And Loans Net Market Value Amount

content.definition:
Report the net market value, or fair value, of deposits, placements, loans and advances, and debt securities. 

This includes, but is not limited to:
- Interest-rate related cash and investments of the entity;
- Debt securities (e.g. bills of exchange, certificates of deposit, commercial paper, promissory notes, Treasury Bonds, securitised instruments); and
- Deposits, placements, loans and advances.
This excludes:
- Holding of units in unit trusts such as a cash management trust.

A debt security is a transferable instrument evidencing a relationship of indebtedness. It is characterised by having a definable income stream that is not based on the economic performance of the issuing entity.

If the entity holds listed notes/hybrid securities which have characteristics of a debt security & an equity security, these securities should be classified in the same manner as they appear in the entity's audited financial statements.

Net market value or fair value is the amount which could be expected to be received from the disposal of an asset in an orderly market; or in an arm's length transaction between knowledgeable, willing parties; after deducting costs expected to be incurred in realising the proceeds of such a disposal.
content.name: Assets Investment Deposits Placements Loans And Debt Securities Net Market Value Amount

content.definition:
Where projection techniques are used, report the component of the best estimate liability as at the relevant date, relating to the net present value of Future Policy Premiums that have been ceded under reinsurance.

Where projection techniques are not used, report nil.
content.name: Liabilities Insurance Future Policy Premiums Reinsurance Amount

content.definition:
The value to be reported is the net market value, or fair value, of both loans classified as assets and debt securities, plus income accrued but not received in relation to this asset. This method of disclosure differs from the Australian Accounting Standards.

Loans include but are not limited to financial leases and mortgages. Loans differ from interest bearing securities as usually the asset is non negotiable (i.e. able to be traded on a secondary market).

Debt securities are transferable instruments evidencing a relationship of indebtedness. It is characterised by having a definable income stream that is not based on the economic performance of the issuing entity.

Net market value, or fair value, is the amount which could be expected to be received from the disposal of an asset in an orderly market; or in an arm's length transaction between knowledgeable, willing parties; after deducting costs expected to be incurred in realising the proceeds of such a disposal.
content.name: Assets Investment Debt Plus Accrued Income Net Market Value Amount

content.definition: Report the value of investments that result in an exposure to the asset class of cash.
content.name: Assets Investment Exposure Cash Class Amount

content.definition:
For participating business this is the value of current period Shareholder Profits as per prudential standards.

For non-participating business valued by projection methods this is the current period planned profit.

For non-participating business valued by the accumulation method this is the current period planned acquisition expense recoveries.

Do not report any value for investment business without discretionary participation features.
content.name: Liabilities Insurance Best Estimate Shareholder Profits Amount

content.definition: Report the value of amortization and impairment of existing deferred acquisition costs (DAC) related to the risk component of premiums acquired, less additional deferrals of acquisition expenses for life insurance (risk) components during the relevant period as per the Australian Accounting Standards.
content.name: Expense Operating Acquisition Costs Deferred Net Movement Amount

content.definition:
Report the total value of outward (claim) side of conversions between statutory funds. Exclude deposit components.

Deposit components are to be recognised  and measured as per the accounting standards.
content.name: Expense Insurance Policy Conversions Outwards Amount

content.definition:
Report the value, for the duration of the relevant period, of premium revenue.  This item is to be determined in accordance with the relevant accounting standards.

This item is net of any associated outwards reinsurance expense.
content.name: Income Insurance Premium Net Of Reinsurance Amount

content.definition:
Report the value of gross policy liabilities ceded under outwards reinsurance.

This amount includes insurance liabilities, financial instrument liabilities and management services element liabilities ceded under reinsurance.

Reinsurance contracts as defined by the Australian Accounting Standards, are insurance contracts issued by one insurer (the reinsurer) to compensate another insurer (the cedent) for losses on one or more contracts issued by the cedent.

Outwards Reinsurance that meets the definition of an insurance contract consists of both a Reinsured Best Estimate Liability and the Value of Reinsured Profit Margins.
content.name: Assets Policy Liabilities Ceded Under Reinsurance Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, for receivables other than:
- outstanding insurance premiums
- receivables in relation to investment assets
- income accrued- deferred acquisition costs
as defined by the relevant Australian Accounting Standards.
content.name: Assets Receivables Other Amount

content.definition:
Report the amount expected on Best Estimate Assumptions to be required to the end of the benefit period to meet future benefits and expenses related to past transactions for the business in force. The calculation process will take into account all factors which are known to be material, including future investment earnings, taxation, any options under the policies and future premiums, where relevant to the calculation.

Best Estimate Assumptions are assumptions about future experience determined in accordance with relevant actuarial valuation standards.

Report amounts gross of ceded reinsurance but inclusive of inwards reinsurance.
content.name: Liabilities Insurance Best Estimate Gross Amount

content.definition: Report the value of commission and other incremental expenses incurred in relation to maintaining existing business. These are the variable costs of administering policies subsequent to their sale and the general administration costs.
content.name: Expense Operating Customer Retention Variable Amount

content.definition:
Report the value of the deposit (investment component) elements of Conversions out of this statutory fund.

Life insurance policies are contracts (policies) that will pay a specified sum to beneficiaries upon the death of the insured.
content.name: Expense Insurance Policy Conversions Outwards Deposit Component Amount

content.definition:
Report the acquisition cost, or historical cost, of investments classified as balanced or mixed mandates, and which are otherwise unable to be allocated across existing asset classes.

For the purposes of this item, only report those amounts acquired, or initially recognised, during the relevant period. Where an asset is an amount held in a bank account, the value reported is the net of all movements in the account over the relevant period, but only where this net movement represents a net increase in the account's balance.

This item is to be determined in accordance with relevant accounting standards.

The acquisition cost, or historical cost, of an asset is the original cost paid to acquire the asset, at the date the asset was initially acquired. Where the asset was acquired in stages, sum the initial acquisition cost of each stage, but only to the extent the acquisitions occurred during the relevant period.
content.name: Assets Investment Balanced Mixed Mandates Unable To Allocate Acquired Historical Cost Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, for the total amount of losses recognised and not reversed.
content.name: Liabilities Insurance Accumulated Loss Recognition Amount

content.definition:
Record the face value, or principle value, as at the relevant date, of off balance sheet exposures related to liabilities classified as investment fees payable.

Investment fees are typically amounts payable to an entity that arise as a result of investing activities undertaken.

Net market value or fair value is the amount which could be expected to be received from the disposal of a liability in an orderly market; or in an arm's length transaction between knowledgeable, willing parties; after deducting costs expected to be incurred in realising the proceeds of such a disposal.

Off-balance sheet liability exposures relate to those liabilities or obligations that do not satisfy the recognition requirements of the relevant accounting standards and are therefore not recognised on the face of the balance sheet, or statement of financial position.
content.name: Liabilities Exposures Off Balance Sheet Investment Fees Payable Amount

content.definition:
Report the net market value, or fair value, of loans and advances classified as investments. 

Net market value or fair value is the amount which could be expected to be received from the disposal of a liability in an orderly market; or in an arm's length transaction between knowledgeable, willing parties; after deducting costs expected to be incurred in realising the proceeds of such a disposal.
content.name: Assets Investment Loans And Advances Amount

content.definition:
Report the net value of all acquisition and disposal transactions of off balance sheet exposures related to assets classified as investment loans and advances. These transactions involve the exchange of valuable consideration between counterparties. Where this results in a net decrease in the net market value of assets, then report a negative figure.

The acquisition cost, or historical cost, of an asset is the original cost paid to acquire the asset, at the date the asset was initially acquired. Where the asset was acquired in stages, sum the initial acquisition cost of each stage, but only to the extent the acquisitions occurred during the relevant period.

The disposal of an asset takes place if a change of ownership occurs, whether because of some act or event (such as damage) or by operation of law, e.g. when an asset is transferred from one person to another by way of sale or gift.

Off-balance sheet asset exposures relate to those assets or rights that do not satisfy the recognition requirements of the relevant accounting standards and are therefore not recognised on the face of the balance sheet, or statement of financial position, such as contingent assets, performance-related rights and guarantees.
content.name: Assets Exposures Off Balance Sheet Loans And Advances Net Acquisition Disposal Transactions Amount

content.definition:
Report the historical value of trade and other receivables arising from the sale or exchange of goods and services to the entity's debtors, or from other non-investment activities.

For the purposes of this item, only report those amounts acquired, or initially recognised, during the relevant period.

This item is to be determined in accordance with relevant accounting standards.
content.name: Assets Trade And Other Receivables Recognised Historical Value Amount

content.definition:
Report the changes to the Experience Profit or Loss for the period in relation to Mortality, net of reinsurance.

The total Experience Profit or Loss is the profit or loss arising in the period from differences between the actual experience during the period and the expected experience on the basis of the Best Estimate Assumptions at the beginning of the period.

Mortality component is related to the likelihood of the death of policy owners.

Best Estimate Assumptions are assumptions about future experience determined in accordance with relevant actuarial valuation standards.
content.name: Profit Or Loss Insurance Experience Mortality Amount

content.definition:
Report the historical value of off-balance sheet exposures to trade and other receivables arising from the sale or exchange of goods and services to the entity's debtors, or from other non-investment activities.

For the purposes of this item, only report those amounts acquired, or initially recognised, during the relevant period.

Off-balance sheet asset exposures relate to those assets or rights that do not satisfy the recognition requirements of relevant accounting standards and are therefore not recognised on the face of the balance sheet, or statement of financial position, such as contingent assets, performance-related rights and guarantees.
content.name: Assets Exposures Off Balance Sheet Trade And Other Receivables Recognised Historical Value Amount
Assets Investment Other Adjustment Look Through Amount

content.definition:
Report the hedging adjustment required to translate the aggregate cash balance to the effective post-derivatives position. 

A hedging adjustment represents the adjustment required to translate the effective exposure associated with hedging investments. The purpose of a hedging investment is to offset the risk of changes in the fair value or cash flows of another contract.
content.name: Assets Cash And Liquid Assets Adjustment Hedging Amount

content.definition:
Report the fair value of the contractual obligation in relation to the deposit (investment) component of insurance policies in force as at the relevant date.

Report amounts gross of ceded reinsurance but inclusive of inwards reinsurance.
content.name: Liabilities Insurance Deposit Component Fair Value Amount

content.definition:
Report the look-through adjustment for equities held indirectly via listed unit trusts, unlisted unit trusts or controlled unit trusts.

A look through adjustment item represents the adjustment required to convert effective holdings in investments via trusts from aggregated amounts classified as equities or unit trusts to the appropriate categories on a look-through basis.
content.name: Assets Investment Equity Securities Adjustment Look Through Amount

content.definition: The amount of interest income derived from investment in Cash And Liquid Assets recognised as income under the Australian Accounting Standards.
content.name: Income Interest Cash And Liquid Assets Net Amount

content.definition:
