content.name: Financial Risk Credit Credit Exposures OREO Impairment Amount

content.definition: This is the value of the provision for impairment in relation to all assets other than real estate acquired by the reporting party in full or partial settlement of a loan or similar facility through enforcement of security arrangements.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Credit Exposures Other Assets Impairment Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of balances denominated in Australian dollars held in the Exchange Settlement Account with the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA), and all other Australian dollar claims on the RBA.
content.name: Assets RBA Australian Dollar Claims Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of gold bullion held in the reporting party's own vault or on an allocated basis by another party to the extent that it is backed by gold bullion liabilities.

This item includes all claims collateralised by gold to the extent that the underlying claim being collateralised is denominated in gold. 

This item excludes gold held in safe custody for other institutions, and gold held on an unallocated basis by another party, although backed by gold bullion liabilities.

Gold bullion liabilities include, gold borrowings, gold futures and forward sales of gold.
content.name: Assets Gold Bullion Own Vault Or Allocated Basis Amount
Assets Cash Items In Process Of Collection Amount

content.definition:
This is the past due amount of credit card balances receivable by the reporting party as at the relevant date, i.e. the amount that has remained continuously outside contractual or approved arrangements.

A credit card is a card whose holder has been granted a revolving credit line up to a pre-arranged limit.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Credit Card Past Due Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of loans and all other on-balance sheet claims secured against eligible residential mortgages.

For the purposes of this item, the repayment of funds advanced must have been secured through an eligible residential mortgage to satisfy the debt in the case of default by the borrower, as determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Claims Secured Against Eligible Residential Mortgages Amount

content.definition:
This is the past due amount of all credit facilities as at the relevant date.

The past due amount is calculated as:
(1) if the facility is not subject to a regular repayment schedule it is the amount that has remained continuously outside contractual or approved arrangements; or
(2) if the facility is subject to a regular repayment schedule then it is the total amount of contractual payments that remain unpaid beyond their due dates.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Credit Facilities Past Due Amount

content.definition:
This is the past due amount of term loans receivable by the reporting party as at the relevant date.

The past due amount is calculated as:
(1) if the facility is not subject to a regular repayment schedule it is the amount that has remained continuously outside contractual or approved arrangements; or
(2) if the facility is subject to a regular repayment schedule then it is the total amount of contractual payments that remain unpaid beyond their due dates.

Term loans are non securitised debt financing with a specified maturity date by which the loan must be repaid.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Term Loans Past Due Amount

content.definition: This is the past due amount of finance leases receivable as at the relevant date.  The past due amount is calculated as the total amount of contractual payments that remain unpaid beyond their due dates.
content.name: Assets Leases Past Due Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of Australian dollar claims on, or claims to the extent that they are guaranteed by or secured against securities issued by, the Australian Commonwealth Government.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Claims On Guaranteed By Or Secured Against Australian Commonwealth Government Australian Dollar Amount
Financial Risk Credit Claims On Guaranteed By Or Secured Against Australian State Territory And Overseas Governments And Foreign Currency Claim Australian Commonwealth Government Amount

content.definition:
This is a balancing item in the list in which it is being used.

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of other past due amounts of the reporting party, as required to be reported on Part 2B of forms ARF_220_0_L and ARF_220_0_C.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Credit Facilities Past Due Other ARF 220 0 Part2B Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of claims on, or claims to the extent that they are guaranteed by, or secured against securities issued by, local governments in Australia and non-commercial public sector entities in Australia and Overseas.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Claims On Guaranteed By Secured Against Local Government In Australia And Public Sector Entities Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of claims on, or claims to the extent that they are guaranteed by, or secured against securities issued by, overseas central banks and foreign currency claims on the Reserve Bank of Australia.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Claims On Guaranteed By Secured Against Overseas Central Banks And RBA Foreign Currency Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of claims on, or claims to the extent that they are guaranteed by, or secured against securities issued by, international banking agencies and multilateral regional development banks.

International banking agencies and multilateral regional development banks include, for example, the IMF, the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, the Bank for International Settlements and the Asian Development Bank.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Claims On Guaranteed By Secured Against International Banking Agencies And Multilateral Regional Development Banks Amount
Financial Risk Credit Claims On Guaranteed By Secured Against ADIs And Overseas Banks Excluding Equity Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of loans and all other claims secured against standard eligible residential mortgages, and which are not insured with an acceptable Lenders Mortgage Insurer (LMI). 

For the purposes of this item, lenders mortgage insurance must provide cover for all losses up to at least 40 percent of the higher of the original loan amount and outstanding loan amount. An acceptable LMI must meet APRA's requirements or those of the overseas host supervisor, as detailed in relevant prudential standards.

For the purposes of this item, the repayment of funds advanced must have been secured through a standard eligible residential mortgage to satisfy the debt in the case of default by the borrower, as determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.

A standard eligible mortgage is defined as a residential mortgage where the reporting party has:
- prior to loan approval and as part of the loan origination and approval process, documented, assessed and verified the ability of the borrowers to meet their repayment obligation;
- valued any residential property offered as security; and
- established that any property offered as security for the loan is readily marketable.
The reporting party must also revalue any property offered as security for such loans when it becomes aware of a material change in the market value of property in an area or region.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Claims Secured Against Standard Eligible Residential Mortgages No Mortgage Insurance Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of loans and all other claims secured against standard eligible residential mortgages, and which are insured with an acceptable Lenders Mortgage Insurer (LMI). 

For the purposes of this item, lenders mortgage insurance must provide cover for all losses up to at least 40 percent of the higher of the original loan amount and outstanding loan amount. An acceptable LMI must meet APRA's requirements or those of the overseas host supervisor, as detailed in relevant prudential standards.

For the purposes of this item, the repayment of funds advanced must have been secured through a standard eligible residential mortgage to satisfy the debt in the case of default by the borrower, as determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.

A standard eligible mortgage is defined as a residential mortgage where the reporting party has:
- prior to loan approval and as part of the loan origination and approval process, documented, assessed and verified the ability of the borrowers to meet their repayment obligation;
- valued any residential property offered as security; and
- established that any property offered as security for the loan is readily marketable.
The reporting party must also revalue any property offered as security for such loans when it becomes aware of a material change in the market value of property in an area or region.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Claims Secured Against Standard Eligible Residential Mortgages With Mortgage Insurance Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of delivery-versus-payment (DvP) transactions that remain unsettled after their due delivery dates.

Exclude repurchase and reverse-repurchase agreements as well as securities lending and borrowing.

Delivery-versus-payment transactions are those transactions of securities using a settlement mechanism which links the securities transfer and the funds transfer in such a way as to ensure that delivery occurs if, and only if, the corresponding payment occurs.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Unsettled Delivery Versus Payment Transactions Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the sum of delivery-versus-payment (DvP) transactions that remain unsettled 5 business days or more after their due delivery dates, and non-DvP transactions that remain unsettled for 4 or less business days after their due delivery dates.

Exclude repurchase and reverse-repurchase agreements as well as securities lending and borrowing.

Delivery-versus-payment transactions are those transactions of securities using a settlement mechanism which links the securities transfer and the funds transfer in such a way as to ensure that delivery occurs if, and only if, the corresponding payment occurs.

This item is reported as part of the credit risk component for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined under the standardised approach to credit risk in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Unsettled DvP And Non DvP Transactions Standardised Approach Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the unsecured portion of any claim (other than a loan or claim secured against eligible residential mortgages) where the specific provisions against those claims represent less than 20 percent of the outstanding amount of the claim or impaired asset.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Claims Unsecured Portion Where Specific Provision Less Than Twenty Percent Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the unsecured portion of any claim (other than a loan or claim secured against eligible residential mortgages) where the specific provisions against those claims represent no less than 20 percent of the outstanding amount of the claim or impaired asset.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Claims Unsecured Portion Where Specific Provision No Less Than Twenty Percent Amount

content.definition:
This is the amount of adjusted deposits placed with the reporting party as at the relevant date.

If the total deposits placed with the reporting party exceed the amount of total deposits the reporting party has placed with others, then this amount is the total deposits the reporting party has placed with others (i.e. deposit assets).

If the reverse is true (i.e. the total deposits placed with the reporting party does not exceed the amount of total deposits the reporting party has placed with others) then the amount is the total deposits placed with the reporting party (i.e. deposit liabilities).
content.name: Liabilities Deposits ARF210 Adjusted Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of claims (other than equity) on Australian and International corporate counterparties (including insurance and securities companies) and commercial public sector entities.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Claims On Corporate And Commercial Public Sector Entities Excluding Equity Amount
Financial Risk Credit Claims On Private Sector Entities Excluding Equity Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of fixed or operational assets held by the reporting party. The measurement and classification basis used is to be in accordance with the accounting standards. 

For the purpose of this item include property held for both operational and investment purposes, and claims on fixed assets under operating leases.

This item is reported as part of the credit risk component for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Fixed Assets Including Investment Property And Assets Under Operating Leases Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of claims on fixed assets under operating leases.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Claims On Fixed Assets Under Operating Lease Amount

content.definition:
This is a balancing item in the list in which it is being used.

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of all other claims and assets not allocated elsewhere on form ARF_112_1A.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Other Claims And Assets ARF 112 1A Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of interest rate derivative contracts, consistent with the classification and measurement basis used for derivatives by institutions in accordance with accounting standards. 

An interest rate contract is any contract that transfers the interest rate risk of an underlying asset from one party to another.

Derivatives are generally defined as those instruments/contracts, where the value is based on other products, and/or on prices associated with financial products. Derivative contracts involve:
- Future delivery, receipt or exchange of financial items such as cash or another derivative instrument; or
- Future exchange of real assets for financial items where the contract may be tradeable and has a market value.
The contracts can either be binding on both parties (e.g. as with a currency swap) or subject to the exercise by one party of a right contained within the contract (as with options).

Report this item regardless of whether favourable or unfavourable to the reporting entity.
content.name: Assets Derivative Financial Instruments Interest Rate Contracts Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of interest rate forward contracts, consistent with the classification and measurement basis used for derivatives by institutions in accordance with accounting standards.

A forward contract is an agreement to exchange a predetermined amount of currency, commodity, or other financial instrument at a specified future date and at a predetermined price.

An interest rate contract is any contract that transfers the interest rate risk of an underlying asset from one party to another.

Derivatives are generally defined as those instruments/contracts, where the value is based on other products, and/or on prices associated with financial products. Derivative contracts involve:
- Future delivery, receipt or exchange of financial items such as cash or another derivative instrument; or
- Future exchange of real assets for financial items where the contract may be tradeable and has a market value.
The contracts can either be binding on both parties (e.g. as with a currency swap) or subject to the exercise by one party of a right contained within the contract (as with options).

Report this item regardless of whether favourable or unfavourable to the reporting entity.
content.name: Assets Derivative Financial Instruments Interest Rate Forwards Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of interest rate swap contracts, consistent with the classification and measurement basis used for derivatives by institutions in accordance with accounting standards.

A Swap is a financial instrument representing a transaction in which two parties agree to swap or exchange some obligation, generally a series of cash flows on differing terms.

An interest rate contract is any contract that transfers the interest rate risk of an underlying asset from one party to another.

Derivatives are generally defined as those instruments/contracts, where the value is based on other products, and/or on prices associated with financial products. Derivative contracts involve:
- Future delivery, receipt or exchange of financial items such as cash or another derivative instrument; or
- Future exchange of real assets for financial items where the contract may be tradeable and has a market value.
The contracts can either be binding on both parties (e.g. as with a currency swap) or subject to the exercise by one party of a right contained within the contract (as with options).

Report this item regardless of whether favourable or unfavourable to the reporting entity.
content.name: Assets Derivative Financial Instruments Interest Rate Swaps Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of interest rate options the entity has purchased, as determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.

A bought option includes both put and call options that have been purchased by an entity. It provides the purchasing entity with the right but not the obligation to buy or sell a specific amount of the underlying asset at a pre-agreed price, on or before a specific future date.

An interest rate contract is any contract that transfers the interest rate risk of an underlying asset from one party to another.
content.name: Financial Risk Market Options Interest Rate Purchased Positions Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of written (sold) interest rate options, consistent with the classification and measurement basis used for derivatives by institutions in accordance with accounting standards.

A written (sold) option includes both put and call options that have been sold by an entity. It provides the selling entity with the obligation to buy or sell a specific amount of an underlying asset at a pre-agreed price, on or before a specific future date.

An interest rate contract is any contract that transfers the interest rate risk of an underlying asset from one party to another.

Derivatives are generally defined as those instruments/contracts, where the value is based on other products, and/or on prices associated with financial products. Derivative contracts involve:
- Future delivery, receipt or exchange of financial items such as cash or another derivative instrument; or
- Future exchange of real assets for financial items where the contract may be tradeable and has a market value.
The contracts can either be binding on both parties (e.g. as with a currency swap) or subject to the exercise by one party of a right contained within the contract (as with options).

Report this item regardless of whether favourable or unfavourable to the reporting entity.
content.name: Assets Derivative Financial Instruments Interest Rate Written Options Amount

content.definition:
This is a balancing item in the list in which it is being used.

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of other interest rate derivative contracts, consistent with the classification and measurement basis used for derivatives by institutions in accordance with accounting standards.

This balancing item represents the value of total interest rate derivative contracts less those contracts which are defined as any of the following:
- Forwards;
- Swaps;
- Bought options; or
- Written (Sold) options.

An interest rate contract is any contract that transfers the interest rate risk of an underlying asset from one party to another.

Derivatives are generally defined as those instruments/contracts, where the value is based on other products, and/or on prices associated with financial products. Derivative contracts involve:
- Future delivery, receipt or exchange of financial items such as cash or another derivative instrument; or
- Future exchange of real assets for financial items where the contract may be tradeable and has a market value.
The contracts can either be binding on both parties (e.g. as with a currency swap) or subject to the exercise by one party of a right contained within the contract (as with options).

Report this item regardless of whether favourable or unfavourable to the reporting entity.
content.name: Assets Derivative Financial Instruments Interest Rate Other Contracts Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of both foreign exchange and gold derivative contracts, consistent with the classification and measurement basis used for derivatives by institutions in accordance with accounting standards.

A foreign exchange contract is any contract that transfers the exchange rate risk of an underlying asset from one party to another.

A gold contract is any contract that transfers the gold price risk associated with an underlying asset from one party to another.

Derivatives are generally defined as those instruments/contracts, where the value is based on other products, and/or on prices associated with financial products. Derivative contracts involve:
- Future delivery, receipt or exchange of financial items such as cash or another derivative instrument; or
- Future exchange of real assets for financial items where the contract may be tradeable and has a market value.
The contracts can either be binding on both parties (e.g. as with a currency swap) or subject to the exercise by one party of a right contained within the contract (as with options).

Report this item regardless of whether favourable or unfavourable to the reporting entity.
content.name: Assets Derivative Financial Instruments Foreign Exchange And Gold Contracts Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of equity contracts held, consistent with the classification and measurement basis used for derivatives by institutions in accordance with accounting standards.

An equity contract is any contract that at least partly transfers the equity risk of an underlying equity security from one party to another.

Derivatives are generally defined as those instruments/contracts, where the value is based on other products, and/or on prices associated with financial products. Derivative contracts involve:
- Future delivery, receipt or exchange of financial items such as cash or another derivative instrument; or
- Future exchange of real assets for financial items where the contract may be tradeable and has a market value.
The contracts can either be binding on both parties (e.g. as with a currency swap) or subject to the exercise by one party of a right contained within the contract (as with options).

Report this item regardless of whether favourable or unfavourable to the reporting entity.
content.name: Assets Derivative Financial Instruments Equity Contracts Amount

content.definition:
This is a balancing item in the list in which it is being used.

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of other derivative contracts, consistent with the classification and measurement basis used for derivatives by institutions in accordance with accounting standards.

This balancing item represents the value of total derivative financial instruments less those derivatives which are classed as any of the following:
- Interest rate contracts;
- Foreign exchange contracts;
- Gold contracts; or
- Equity contracts;

Derivatives are generally defined as those instruments/contracts, where the value is based on other products, and/or on prices associated with financial products. Derivative contracts involve:
- Future delivery, receipt or exchange of financial items such as cash or another derivative instrument; or
- Future exchange of real assets for financial items where the contract may be tradeable and has a market value.
The contracts can either be binding on both parties (e.g. as with a currency swap) or subject to the exercise by one party of a right contained within the contract (as with options).

Report this item regardless of whether favourable or unfavourable to the reporting entity.
content.name: Assets Derivative Financial Instruments Other Contracts Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of both foreign exchange and gold forward contracts, consistent with the classification and measurement basis used for derivatives by institutions in accordance with accounting standards.

Outstanding spot transactions should be treated as forward foreign exchange contracts.

A Forward contract is an agreement to exchange a predetermined amount of currency, commodity, or other financial instrument at a specified future date and at a predetermined price.

A foreign exchange contract is any contract that transfers the exchange rate risk of an underlying asset from one party to another.

A gold contract is any contract that transfers the gold price risk associated with an underlying asset from one party to another.

Derivatives are generally defined as those instruments/contracts, where the value is based on other products, and/or on prices associated with financial products. Derivative contracts involve:
- Future delivery, receipt or exchange of financial items such as cash or another derivative instrument; or
- Future exchange of real assets for financial items where the contract may be tradeable and has a market value.
The contracts can either be binding on both parties (e.g. as with a currency swap) or subject to the exercise by one party of a right contained within the contract (as with options).

Report this item regardless of whether favourable or unfavourable to the reporting entity.
content.name: Assets Derivative Financial Instruments Foreign Exchange And Gold Forwards Amount

A gold contract is any contract that transfers the gold price risk associated with an underlying asset from one party to another.

content.definition:

A bought credit derivative is a credit derivative that has been purchased by an entity. A credit derivative enables the user to transfer the credit risk of an underlying asset from one party, the protection buyer, to another, the protection seller, in isolation from other risks.

Derivatives are generally defined as those instruments/contracts, where the value is based on other products, and/or on prices associated with financial products. Derivative contracts involve:
- Future delivery, receipt or exchange of financial items such as cash or another derivative instrument; or

Report this item regardless of whether favourable or unfavourable to the reporting entity.
content.name: Assets Derivative Financial Instruments Bought Credit Derivatives Amount

content.name: Assets Derivative Financial Instruments Sold Credit Derivatives Amount

content.definition:
This item is a balancing item in the list in which it is being used.

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of all other derivative financial instruments, consistent with the classification and measurement basis used for derivatives by institutions in accordance with accounting standards.

This balancing item represents total derivatives less those derivatives which are excluded below:

Exclude those types of derivative financial instruments defined as:
- Forwards;
- Swaps
- Bought option positions;
- Written (sold) option positions;
- Bought credit derivatives; or
- Sold credit derivatives.

Also exclude those derivative financial instruments that are classed as:
- Interest rate contracts;
- Foreign exchange contracts;
- Gold contracts; or
- Equity contracts.

Derivatives are generally defined as those instruments/contracts, where the value is based on other products, and/or on prices associated with financial products. Derivative contracts involve:
- Future delivery, receipt or exchange of financial items such as cash or another derivative instrument; or
- Future exchange of real assets for financial items where the contract may be tradeable and has a market value.
The contracts can either be binding on both parties (e.g. as with a currency swap) or subject to the exercise by one party of a right contained within the contract (as with options).

Report this item regardless of whether favourable or unfavourable to the reporting entity.
content.name: Assets Derivative Financial Instruments Other Other Contracts Amount
Financial Risk Credit Performance Related Contingencies Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of any potential credit exposures arising from the lending of securities or the posting of securities as collateral. This includes, but is not limited to, repurchase/reverse repurchase agreements and securities lending/borrowing transactions.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Lending Of Securities Or Posting Of Securities As Collateral Standardised Approach Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of any potential credit exposures (off-balance sheet) arising from partly paid shares and securities. This includes any amounts owing on the uncalled portion of partly paid shares, as well as securities held by an entity that represent commitments with certain drawdown by the issuer at a future date.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Partly Paid Shares And Securities Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of any potential credit exposures relating to the placements of forward deposits.

Placements of forward deposits are off-balance sheet transactions that relate to any agreement between an entity and another party whereby the entity will place a deposit at an agreed rate of interest with that party at a predetermined future date.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Placements Of Forward Deposits Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of any potential credit exposures arising from note issuance and revolving underwriting facilities.

Note issuance and revolving underwriting facilities are off-balance sheet arrangements whereby a borrower may draw down funds up to a prescribed limit over a predefined period by making repeated note issues to the market, and where, should the issue prove unable to be placed in the market, the unplaced amount is to be taken up or funds made available by the reporting entity being committed as an underwriter of the facility.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Note Issuance And Revolving Underwriting Facilities Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of credit derivatives used for acquiring credit risk exposures other than those classified as direct credit substitutes.

This item is reported for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.

A sold credit derivative is a credit derivative that has been sold, or written, by an entity. A credit derivative enables the user to transfer the credit risk of an underlying asset from one party, the protection buyer, to another, the protection seller, in isolation from other risks.

A direct credit substitute is an irrevocable off-balance sheet obligation that carries the same credit risk as a direct extension of credit, such as an undertaking to make a payment to a third party in the event that a counterparty fails to meet a financial obligation.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Sold Credit Derivatives Excluding Direct Credit Substitutes Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of undrawn (off-balance sheet) irrevocable commitments with certainty of drawdown. This represents the maximum unused portion of the commitment that could be drawn during the remaining period to maturity. Any drawn portion of a commitment forms part of an entity's on-balance sheet exposure and is not to be reported at this item.
     
Commitments are generally considered to have arisen once the reporting party makes a firm offer to a client (i.e. customer acceptance is not required). Therefore, a commitment will arise once a letter of offer is provided to the client by the reporting party.
     
For the purposes of this item, do not report the undrawn balance of revolving facilities (e.g. credit cards, overdrafts, etc.).
content.name: Assets Off Balance Sheet Undrawn Commitments Irrevocable Certain Drawdown Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of irrevocable loan amounts that are approved but not yet advanced, and which are certain of drawdown. This represents the maximum unused portion of the commitment that could be drawn during the remaining period to maturity. Any drawn portion of a commitment forms part of an entity's on-balance sheet exposure and is not to be reported at this item.
     
Loans that are approved but not yet advanced are contingent liabilities which represent loans that have been approved by the reporting party but the counterparty has yet to draw down the funds in relation to the arrangement.
     
Commitments, for capital adequacy purposes, are generally considered to have arisen once the reporting party makes a firm offer to a client (i.e. customer acceptance is not required). Therefore, a commitment will arise once a letter of offer is provided to the client by the reporting party.
      
For the purposes of this item, do not report the undrawn balance of revolving facilities (e.g. credit cards, overdrafts, etc.).
content.name: Assets Exposures Off Balance Sheet Undrawn Commitments Irrevocable Certain Drawdown Loans Approved But Not Yet Advanced Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of undrawn (off-balance sheet) irrevocable commitments, but which are not certain of drawdown. This represents the maximum unused portion of the commitment that could be drawn during the remaining period to maturity . Any drawn portion of a commitment forms part of an entity's on-balance sheet exposure and is not to be reported at this item. Exclude irrevocable standby commitments provided under APRA approved industry support arrangements. 

Commitments are generally considered to have arisen once the reporting party makes a firm offer to a client (i.e. customer acceptance is not required). Therefore, a commitment will arise once a letter of offer is provided to the client by the reporting party.

For the purposes of this item, do not report the undrawn balance of revolving facilities (e.g. credit cards, overdrafts, etc.).
content.name: Assets Off Balance Sheet Undrawn Commitments Irrevocable Not Certain Drawdown Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of undrawn (off-balance sheet) irrevocable commitments available for redraw under redraw facilities, but which are not certain of drawdown. This represents the maximum unused portion of the commitment that could be drawn during the remaining period to maturity. Any drawn portion of a commitment forms part of an entity's on-balance sheet exposure and is not to be reported at this item.

Commitments are generally considered to have arisen once the reporting party makes a firm offer to a client (i.e. customer acceptance is not required). Therefore, a commitment will arise once a letter of offer is provided to the client by the reporting party.

For the purposes of this item, do not report undrawn balances of revolving facilities (e.g. credit cards, overdrafts, etc.).
content.name: Assets Off Balance Sheet Undrawn Commitments Irrevocable Not Certain Drawdown Available For Redraw Under Redraw Facilities Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of undrawn (off-balance sheet) commitments which can be unconditionally cancelled at any time without notice (revocable). This represents the maximum unused portion of the commitment that could be drawn during the remaining period to maturity. Any drawn portion of a commitment forms part of an entity's on-balance sheet exposure and is not to be reported at this item.
     
Commitments are generally considered to have arisen once the reporting party makes a firm offer to a client (i.e. customer acceptance is not required). Therefore, a commitment will arise once a letter of offer is provided to the client by the reporting party.
     
For the purposes of this item, do not report undrawn balances of revolving facilities (e.g. credit cards, overdrafts, etc.).
content.name: Assets Off Balance Sheet Undrawn Commitments Unconditionally Cancelled At Any Time Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, for the contingent funding obligation that could generate outflows during the remaining period to maturity.
content.name: Liabilities Contingent Funding Obligation Amount

content.definition:
This is the total approved balance, as at the relevant date, of standby facilities approved and committed to the reporting party. 

A standby facility is an arrangement in which a party has the right but not the obligation to draw down funds to a specified limit. Generally, the drawing party is required to provide written notice to trigger draw down (access to the funds) on these facilities.

The approved balance of a facility is the maximum approved amount that can be drawn down in relation to that facility.
content.name: Liabilities Standby Facilities Available Approved Limit Amount

content.definition:
This is a balancing item in the list in which it is being used.

This is the total approved balance , as at the relevant date, of off-balance sheet liquidity support facilities available to the reporting party, other than those facilities classified as any of the following:
- Standby facilities;
- Bill acceptance and discount facilities;
- Letter of credit facilities; and
- Overdrafts.

The approved balance of a facility is the maximum approved amount that can be drawn down in relation to that facility.
content.name: Liabilities Liquidity Support Facilities Available Other Approved Limit Amount

content.definition: This is the total approved balance, as at the relevant date, of liquidity support facilities contracted to the reporting party. The approved balance of a facility is the maximum approved amount that can be drawn down in relation to that facility. Liquidity support facilities are contracted by entities to supplement their liquidity management practices, and include the following:     - Standby facilities;     - Bill acceptance/discount facilities;     - Letter of credit facilities;     - Overdrafts; and     - Other liquidity support facilities contracted.
content.name: Liabilities Liquidity Support Facilities Available Approved Limit Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the fixed charge that has been granted over the assets of the reporting party.

A fixed charge is a form of security provided by a borrower to a lender relating to a specific asset, or group of assets, and will generally limit the ability of the borrower to deal with those assets. This will typically enable to lender to sell the assets charged if the borrower defaults.
content.name: Liabilities Off Balance Sheet Fixed Charge Granted Over Assets Amount

content.definition:
This is a balancing item in the list in which it is being used.

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the charge, or security, that has been granted over the assets of the reporting party, but which are not classified as any of the following:
- Fixed charge; or
- Floating charge.
content.name: Liabilities Off Balance Sheet Charge Or Security Granted Over Assets Excluding Fixed and Floating Amount

content.definition:
This is a balancing item in the list in which it is being used.

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of other market-related off-balance sheet contracts (including credit derivatives), as required on form ARF_112_2A.

This item is reported for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with the relevant prudential standards. The reporting party may net claims and obligations with a counterparty that are covered by a legally binding eligible bilateral netting agreement. 

This balancing item represents the value of total market-related off-balance sheet contracts (including credit derivatives) less those contracts which are classed as any of the following:
- Interest rate contracts;
- Foreign exchange contracts;
- Equity contracts; or
- Precious metal, Gold and other commodity contracts.

Derivatives are generally defined as those instruments/contracts, where the value is based on other products, and/or on prices associated with financial products. Derivative contracts involve:
- Future delivery, receipt or exchange of financial items such as cash or another derivative instrument; or
- Future exchange of real assets for financial items where the contract may be tradeable and has a market value.
The contracts can either be binding on both parties (e.g. as with a currency swap) or subject to the exercise by one party of a right contained within the contract (as with options).

Report this item regardless of whether favourable or unfavourable to the reporting entity.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Off Balance Sheet Market Related Contracts Other ARF 112 2A Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of credit exposures arising from market-related off-balance sheet business.

This item is to be determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.

A credit exposure represents an asset, liability, claim or commitment of an entity, which may be recorded on or off the balance sheet and which gives rise to credit risk. For the purposes of this item, only report off-balance sheet market-related credit exposures.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Off Balance Sheet Market Related Exposures Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of guarantees that constitute direct credit substitutes.
     
A guarantee is a pledge or agreement to be responsible for another party's debt or contractual performance if that other party does not pay or perform.
     
A direct credit substitute is any irrevocable off-balance sheet obligation that carries the same credit risk as a direct extension of credit, such as an undertaking to make a payment to a third party in the event that a counterparty fails to meet a financial obligation, or an undertaking to a counterparty to acquire a potential claim on another party in the event of default by that party (i.e. the risk of loss depends on the creditworthiness of the counterparty or the party on that a potential claim is acquired).
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Direct Credit Substitutes Guarantees Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of standby letters of credit on issue that are serving as financial guarantees for loans, securities and any other financial liabilities. Report only standby letters of credit that constitute direct credit substitutes.
     
A direct credit substitute is any irrevocable off-balance sheet obligation that carries the same credit risk as a direct extension of credit, such as an undertaking to make a payment to a third party in the event that a counterparty fails to meet a financial obligation, or an undertaking to a counterparty to acquire a potential claim on another party in the event of default by that party (i.e. the risk of loss depends on the creditworthiness of the counterparty or the party on that a potential claim is acquired).
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Direct Credit Substitutes Standby Letters Of Credit Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of bills that have been endorsed under bill endorsement lines, but have not been accepted by, or have the prior endorsement of, another ADI. Report only bills that constitute direct credit substitutes.
     
A direct credit substitute is any irrevocable off-balance sheet obligation that carries the same credit risk as a direct extension of credit, such as an undertaking to make a payment to a third party in the event that a counterparty fails to meet a financial obligation, or an undertaking to a counterparty to acquire a potential claim on another party in the event of default by that party (i.e. the risk of loss depends on the creditworthiness of the counterparty or the party on that a potential claim is acquired).
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Direct Credit Substitutes Bill Endorsements Amount

content.definition:
This is a balancing item in the list in which it is being used.

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of any potential credit exposures arising from the issue of direct credit substitutes which are not classified as any of the following:
- Guarantees;
- Credit derivatives - sold protection in the banking book;
- Standby letters of credit; or
- Bill endorsements.

A direct credit substitute is any irrevocable off-balance sheet obligation that carries the same credit risk as a direct extension of credit, such as an undertaking to make a payment to a third party in the event that a counterparty fails to meet a financial obligation, or an undertaking to a counterparty to acquire a potential claim on another party in the event of default by that party, constitutes a direct credit substitute (i.e. the risk of loss depends on the creditworthiness of the counterparty or the party on that a potential claim is acquired).
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Direct Credit Substitutes Other Amount
Financial Risk Credit Trade Related Contingencies Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of any potential credit exposures arising from sale and repurchase agreements ('Repos').
     
Sale and repurchase agreements represent arrangements whereby an entity sells a loan, security or other asset to another party with a commitment to repurchase the asset at an agreed price on an agreed future date.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Sale And Repurchase Agreements Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of any potential credit exposures arising from assets sold with recourse.
     
Assets sold with recourse are asset sales (to the extent that such assets are not included on-balance sheet) by an entity where the holder of the asset is entitled to 'put' the asset back to the entity within an agreed period or under certain prescribed circumstances (e.g. deterioration in the value or credit quality of the asset concerned).
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Assets Sold With Recourse Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of any potential credit exposures arising from forward asset purchases deemed non-market-related off-balance sheet transactions.. 
     
A forward asset purchase is a commitment to purchase at a specified future date, and on pre-arranged terms, a loan, security or other asset from another entity, including written put options on specified assets with the character of a credit enhancement.

For the purposes of this item, non-market-related off-balance sheet forward asset purchases exclude: 
     
- commitments where the entity purchasing the asset has an unequivocal right to substitute cash settlement in place of accepting delivery of the asset, and the price on settlement is calculated with reference to a general market price indicator (and not to the financial condition of any specific entity). This is deemed a market-related off-balance sheet transaction; and
     
- written put options expressed in terms of market rates for currencies or financial instruments bearing no credit risk. This is also deemed a market-related off-balance sheet transaction.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Non Market Related Forward Asset Purchases Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of undrawn irrevocable non-market-related commitments available for redraw under redraw facilities, but which are not certain of drawdown. This represents the maximum unused portion of the commitment that could be drawn during the remaining period to maturity.

This item is reported for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.

Commitments, for capital adequacy purposes, are generally considered to have arisen once the reporting party makes a firm offer to a client (i.e. customer acceptance is not required). Therefore, a commitment will arise once a letter of offer is provided to the client by the reporting party.

For the purposes of this item, do not report undrawn balances of revolving facilities.
content.name: Assets Exposures Off Balance Sheet Non Market Related Commitments Available For Redraw Under Redraw Facilities Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of any undrawn irrevocable non-market-related standby commitments which have been provided under APRA's approved industry support arrangements. This represents the maximum unused portion of the commitment that could be drawn during the remaining period to maturity. Any drawn portion of a commitment forms part of an entity's on-balance sheet exposure and is not to be reported at this item.

Commitments are generally considered to have arisen once the reporting party makes a firm offer to a client (i.e. customer acceptance is not required). Therefore, a commitment will arise once a letter of offer is provided to the client by the reporting party.
content.name: Assets Off Balance Sheet Undrawn Commitments Irrevocable Standby APRA Approved Industry Support Arrangements Amount
Financial Risk Credit Off Balance Sheet Non Market Related Other Transactions ARF 112 2A Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of any credit exposure arising from non-market-related off-balance sheet business.

This item is calculated for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.

A credit exposure represents an asset, liability, claim or commitment of an entity, which may be recorded on or off the balance sheet and which gives rise to credit risk.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Off Balance Sheet Non Market Related Exposures Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the floating charge that has been granted over the assets of the reporting party.

A floating charge is a form of security provided by a borrower to a lender where the creditor's charge or claim is not lodged over a particular asset, but is fixed on a specific asset, or group of assets, only if the default occurs. This process is called crystallisation of the charge. A floating charge leaves the debtor free to buy, sell and vary the assets until such time as the charge is crystallised.
content.name: Liabilities Off Balance Sheet Floating Charge Granted Over Assets Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of credit exposures arising from off-balance sheet business.

The measurement and classification basis used is to be determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.

A credit exposure represents an asset, liability, claim or commitment of an entity, which may be recorded on or off the balance sheet and which gives rise to credit risk. For the purposes of this item, only report off-balance sheet credit exposures.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Off Balance Sheet Business Amount

content.definition:
This is, as at the relevant date, the exposure weighted average loss given default (LGD) for on-balance sheet credit exposures.

This item is calculated for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.

Weighted average LGD = SIGMAi LGDi x EADi / SIGMAi EADi

Where:
LGDi = the LGD associated with the ith exposure in the group.
EADi = the EAD associated with the ith exposure in the group.

Loss given default (LGD) represents an entities economic loss upon the default of an obligor.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit On Balance Sheet Exposures Weighted Average LGD Percent

content.definition:
Report in years, calculated as at the relevant date, the exposure weighted average effective maturity (M) for on-balance sheet credit exposures.

This item is calculated for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.

Weighted average maturity = SIGMAi Mi x EADi / SIGMAi EADi

Where:
Mi = the maturity associated with the ith exposure in the group.
EADi = the EAD associated with the ith exposure in the group.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit On Balance Sheet Exposures Weighted Average Maturity Number

content.definition:
This is, as at the relevant date, the exposure weighted average firm size of on-balance sheet credit exposures.

This item is calculated for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.

Weighted average firm size = SIGMAi Salesi x EADi / SIGMAi EADi

Where:
Salesi = the level of annual sales associated with the ith exposure.
EADi = the exposure at default(EAD) associated with the ith exposure.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit On Balance Sheet Exposure Weighted Average Firm Size Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of off-balance sheet credit exposures.

A credit exposure represents an asset, liability, claim or commitment of an entity, which may be recorded on or off the balance sheet and which gives rise to credit risk.

This item is calculated for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant Prudential Standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Off Balance Sheet Exposures Amount

content.definition:
This is, as at the relevant date, the exposure weighted average loss given default (LGD) of off-balance sheet credit exposures.

This item is calculated for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.

Weighted average LGD = SIGMAi LGDi x EADi / SIGMAi EADi

Where:
LGDi = the LGD associated with the ith exposure in the group.
EADi = the EAD associated with the ith exposure in the group.

Loss given default (LGD) represents an entities economic loss upon the default of an obligor.

A credit exposure represents an asset, liability, claim or commitment of an entity, which may be recorded on or off the balance sheet and which gives rise to credit risk.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Off Balance Sheet Exposures Weighted Average LGD Percent

content.definition:
Report in years, as at the relevant date, the exposure weighted average effective maturity (M) of off-balance sheet credit exposures.

This item is reported for capital adequacy purposes and is to be in accordance with relevant prudential standards.

Weighted average maturity = SIGMAi Mi x EADi / SIGMAi EADi

Where:
Mi = the maturity associated with the ith exposure in the group.
EADi = the EAD associated with the ith exposure in the group.

A credit exposure represents an asset, liability, claim or commitment of an entity, which may be recorded on or off the balance sheet and which gives rise to credit risk.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Off Balance Sheet Exposures Weighted Average Maturity Number

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of expected losses (EL) arising from on-balance sheet credit exposures (refer APS 113)

This item is calculated for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit On Balance Sheet Expected Losses Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of expected losses arising from off-balance sheet credit exposures.

This item is calculated for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Off Balance Sheet Expected Losses Amount

content.definition:
This is, as at the relevant date, the exposure weighted average firm size of off-balance sheet credit exposures.

This item is reported for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.

Weighted average firm size = SIGMAi Salesi x EADi / SIGMAi EADi

Where:
Salesi = the level of annual sales associated with the ith exposure.
EADi = the exposure at default(EAD) associated with the ith exposure.

A credit exposure represents an asset, liability, claim or commitment of an entity, which may be recorded on or off the balance sheet and which gives rise to credit risk.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Off Balance Sheet Exposures Weighted Average Firm Size Amount

content.definition:
This is the description of the transaction that gives rise to the non-market related off-balance sheet credit exposure, and for which the Credit Conversion Factor (CCF) is other than 100%. 

This item is calculated for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with Prudential Standard APS 113.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Off Balance Sheet Non Market Related Exposure Credit Conversion Factor Not 100 Percent Description

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of non-market related off-balance sheet credit exposures, and for which the applicable Credit Conversion Factor (CCF) is other than 100%.

A credit exposure represents an asset, liability, claim or commitment of an entity, which may be recorded on or off the balance sheet and which gives rise to credit risk.

This item is calculated for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with Prudential Standard APS 113.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Off Balance Sheet Non Market Related Exposures Credit Conversion Factor Not 100 Percent Amount

content.definition:
This is, as at the relevant date, the exposure weighted average probability of default (PD) for on-balance sheet credit exposures.

Probability of default (PD) represents the risk of obligor default.

A credit exposure represents an asset, liability, claim or commitment of an entity, which may be recorded on or off the balance sheet and which gives rise to credit risk.

This item is calculated for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit On Balance Sheet Exposures Weighted Average PD Percent

content.definition:
This is, as at the relevant date, the exposure weighted average probability of default (PD) of off-balance sheet credit exposures.

Probability of default (PD) represents the risk of obligor default.

A credit exposure represents an asset, liability, claim or commitment of an entity, which may be recorded on or off the balance sheet and which gives rise to credit risk.

This item is calculated for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Off Balance Sheet Exposures Weighted Average PD Percent

content.definition:
This is, as at the relevant date, the exposure weighted average probability of default (PD) for on-balance sheet and off-balance sheet credit exposures.

Probability of default (PD) represents the risk of obligor default.

A credit exposure represents an asset, liability, claim or commitment of an entity, which may be recorded on or off the balance sheet and which gives rise to credit risk.

This item is calculated for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Exposures Weighted Average PD Percent

content.definition:
As at the relevant date, report in years the exposure weighted average effective maturity (M) of credit exposures.

This item is reported for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.

Weighted average maturity = SIGMAi Mi x EADi / SIGMAi EADi

Where:
Mi = the maturity associated with the ith exposure in the group.
EADi = the EAD associated with the ith exposure in the group.

A credit exposure represents an asset, liability, claim or commitment of an entity, which may be recorded on or off the balance sheet and which gives rise to credit risk.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Exposures Weighted Average Maturity Number

content.definition:
This is, as at the relevant date, the exposure weighted average firm size of credit exposures.

This item is calculated for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.

Weighted average firm size = SIGMAi Salesi x EADi / SIGMAi EADi

Where:
Salesi = the level of annual sales associated with the ith exposure.
EADi = the exposure at default(EAD) associated with the ith exposure.

A credit exposure represents an asset, liability, claim or commitment of an entity, which may be recorded on or off the balance sheet and which gives rise to credit risk.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Exposures Weighted Average Firm Size Amount

content.definition:
This is, as at the relevant date, the exposure weighted average loss given default (LGD) of credit exposures.

This item is calculated for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined risk in accordance with relevant prudential standards.

Weighted average LGD = SIGMAi LGDi x EADi / SIGMAi EADi

Where:
LGDi = the LGD associated with the ith exposure in the group.
EADi = the EAD associated with the ith exposure in the group.

Loss given default (LGD) represents an entities economic loss upon the default of an obligor.

A credit exposure represents an asset, liability, claim or commitment of an entity, which may be recorded on or off the balance sheet and which gives rise to credit risk.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Exposures Weighted Average LGD Percent

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of on-balance sheet credit exposures arising from purchased receivables.

A credit exposure represents an asset, liability, claim or commitment of an entity, which may be recorded on or off the balance sheet and which gives rise to credit risk.

This item is reported for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit On Balance Sheet Purchased Receivables Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of expected losses from on-balance sheet credit exposures arising from purchased receivables.

This item is reported for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit On Balance Sheet Expected Losses Purchased Receivables Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of off-balance sheet credit exposures arising from purchased receivables.

A credit exposure represents an asset, liability, claim or commitment of an entity, which may be recorded on or off the balance sheet and which gives rise to credit risk.

This item is reported for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined under the Internal-Ratings-based approach to credit risk in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Off Balance Sheet Purchased Receivables Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of expected losses from off-balance sheet credit exposures arising from purchased receivables.

This item is reported for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Off Balance Sheet Expected Losses Purchased Receivables Amount

content.definition:
This is the scaling factor applicable to the risk weighted assets of the reporting party.

Report 1 at this item where:
- the reporting party is not using the IRB approach to credit risk; 
- RWA is derived from specific (defined) risk-weights (i.e. RWA amounts for specialised lending supervisory slotting and other assets, claims and exposures); or
- the scaling factor has already been applied, the ADI should enter a value of 1 in this field.

Report 1.06 at this item where:
- the reporting party is using the IRB approach to credit risk;
- RWA is derived from the IRB risk-weight functions; or
- the scaling factor has not been applied, the ADI should enter a value of 1.06 in this field.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Scaling Factor IRB Approach Number

content.definition:
This is the description of the transaction that gives rise to the non-market related off-balance sheet credit exposures.

This item is calculated for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant Prudential Standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Off Balance Sheet Non Market Related Exposures Description

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of equity exposures.

Equity exposures are defined according to the economic substance of the instrument. This includes both direct and indirect ownership interests, whether voting or non-voting, in the assets and income of a commercial enterprise or financial institutions, and holdings of units in unit trusts.

Exclude equity securities:
- which are deducted from capital for capital adequacy purposes; and 
- held in the reporting party's trading book, with the exception of those exposures that give rise to counterparty credit risk.

Short positions held in the banking book are permitted to offset long positions in the same individual equities provided that these instruments have been explicitly designated as hedges of specific equity holdings and that they have remaining maturities of at least one year.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Equity Exposures Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of leases that expose the reporting party to residual value risk, excluding discounted lease payment streams.

This item is reported as part of the credit risk component for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Exposures Leases Residual Value Risk Amount

content.definition:
This is the balancing item in the list in which it is being used.

This is the value of all other exposures for the purposes of form ARF_113_4.

This item is reported for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Exposures Other ARF 113 4 Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of credit exposures, excluding assets included in the equity IRB asset class.

A credit exposure represents an asset, liability, claim or commitment of an entity, which may be recorded on or off the balance sheet and which gives rise to credit risk.

This item is reported for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined under the Internal-Ratings-based approach to credit risk in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Exposures Excluding Equity IRB Approach Amount

content.definition:
This is a balancing item within the list in which it is being used.

This is, for the duration of the relevant period, the value of all other investment income of the reporting party, as required to be reported on APRA form SRF_100_0.
content.name: Income Investment Superannuation Fund Other SRF 100 0 Amount

content.definition: This is the value of any Superannuation Tax plus any Superannuation Surcharge recognised in the Income (Profit and Loss) Statement by the reporting party for the relevant period.
content.name: Superannuation Contribution Tax Plus Surcharge Amount

content.definition: This is the value of doubtful debts expense (i.e. where a provision for doubtful debts/impairment has been raised) and/or bad debts written off directly against income for the relevant period in respect of Interest, Dividends, Trust Distributions and Rent that have all been classified as Investment Income in accordance with accounting standards.
content.name: Expense Bad Doubtful Debts Investment Interest Dividends Distributions Rent Amount

content.definition:
This is a balancing item within the list in which it is being used.     
     
This is, for the duration of the relevant period, the value of all other fees and commissions received by the reporting party that relate to investment activity but that are not related to scrip lending or underwriting activities, as required to be reported on APRA form SRF_100_0.
content.name: Income Investment Fees Commissions Not Scrip Lending Underwriting SRF 100 0 Amount

content.definition:
This is a balancing item within the list in which it is being used.
     
This is, for the duration of the relevant period, the net value of other realised gains/losses brought to account, as required by APRA form SRF_300_0.
content.name: Profit Or Loss Investment Realised Other SRF 300 0 Amount

content.definition:
This is a balancing item within the list in which it is being used.
     
This is, for the duration of the relevant period, the amount of all other income that has not been classified as investment income in accordance with accounting standards, as required to be reported on APRA form SRF_100_0.
content.name: Income Not Investment Other SRF 100 0 Amount

content.definition:
This is a balancing item within the list in which it is being used.

This is, for the duration of the relevant period, the net value of other unrealised gains/losses brought to account, as required by APRA form SRF_100_0.
content.name: Profit Or Loss Investment Unrealised Other SRF 100 0 Amount

content.definition:
This is a balancing item within the list in which it is being used.
     
This is, for the duration of the relevant period, the value of other expenses that have not been classified as investment expenses in accordance with the relevant accounting standards, as required on APRA form SRF_100_0.
content.name: Expense Non Investment Other SRF 100 0 Amount

content.definition:
This is a balancing item within the list in which it is being used.
     
This is, as at the relevant date, the amount required to reconcile the value of net assets, as calculated on APRA form SRF_100_0, with the value of net assets reported in accordance with accounting standards.
content.name: Assets Net Assets Reconciling Items SRF 100 0 Amount

content.definition:
This is the total eligible high quality cash and liquid assets at the relevant date determined in accordance with liquidity prudential standards.
     
This comprises currency notes and coins, settlement funds from recognised clearing houses in relation to security and payments system transactions, and amounts receivable from financial institutions.
content.name: Assets Cash And Liquid Assets Eligible HQLA Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of deferred tax assets (DTA):
     (a) excluding any DTA associated with collective provisions (refer relevant Accounting Standards) eligible to be included in the General Reserve for Credit Losses (refer relevant Prudential Standards); and
     (b) net of deferred tax liabilities (DTL) (except DTL amounts associated with surpluses in any ADI (or other group member) employer-sponsored superannuation funds).
     
The reporting party must net these items on a consistent basis in accordance with the requirements set out in the relevant prudential standards.
     
For the purposes of this item, where the amount of DTL exceeds the amount of DTA, report zero.
     
DTA and DTL amounts are to be determined in accordance with relevant accounting standards.
content.name: Assets Deferred Tax Assets Net Excluding General Reserve For Credit Losses Minimum Zero Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of credit exposures excluding those related to applicable revolving facilities.

Revolving facility exposures are exposures arising from redrawable facilities, other than exposures in the nature of redrawable home loans where the amounts likely to be redrawn are expected to be immaterial relative to the size of the pool. Revolving facilities are only applicable to this item where the reporting party transfers a pool of revolving exposures into a securitisation that contains an early amortisation provision, as determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.

A credit exposure represents an asset, liability, claim or commitment of an entity, which may be recorded on or off the balance sheet and which gives rise to credit risk.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Exposures Excl Revolving Facilities With Early Amortisation Provision Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of exposures (on and off balance sheet) arising from revolving facilities, being exposures arising from redrawable facilities, other than exposures in the nature of redrawable home loans where the amounts likely to be redrawn are expected to be immaterial relative to the size of the pool.

Revolving facilities are only applicable to this item where the reporting party transfers a pool of revolving exposures into a securitisation that contains an early amortisation provision.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Exposures Revolving With Early Amortisation Excl Immaterial Home Loans Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of credit exposures, before required APRA adjustments.

A credit exposure represents asset, liability, claim or commitment of an entity, which may be recorded on or off the balance sheet and which gives rise to credit risk.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Exposures Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of any other adjustments to credit exposures, as required by APRA.

A credit exposure represents an asset, liability, claim or commitment of an entity, which may be recorded on or off the balance sheet and which gives rise to credit risk.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Exposures APRA Other Adjustments Amount
Financial Risk Credit Exposures Most Senior And ABCP Securitisations Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of exposures arising from undrawn eligible facilities, excluding eligible servicer cash advance facilities and applicable revolving facilities.

Revolving facility exposures are exposures arising from redrawable facilities, other than exposures in the nature of redrawable home loans where the amounts likely to be redrawn are expected to be immaterial relative to the size of the pool. Revolving facilities are only applicable to this item where the reporting party transfers a pool of revolving exposures into a securitisation that contains an early amortisation provision.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Exposures Eligible Facilities Excl Servicer Cash Advance And Revolving With Early Amortisation Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of exposures arising from undrawn servicer cash advance facilities, excluding applicable revolving facilities.

Revolving facility exposures are exposures arising from redrawable facilities, other than exposures in the nature of redrawable home loans where the amounts likely to be redrawn are expected to be immaterial relative to the size of the pool. Revolving facilities are only applicable to this item where the reporting party transfers a pool of revolving exposures into a securitisation that contains an early amortisation provision.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Exposures Servicer Cash Advance Facilities Excl Revolving With Early Amortisation Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of credit exposures arising from the following:
- the most senior exposure in a securitisation (e.g. the most senior tranche of securities issued by the SPV or an obligation under a facility that ranks ahead of the first tranche);
- asset-backed commercial paper securitisation (i.e. where the securities issued are predominantly commercial paper with an original maturity of one year or less) exposures in a second loss, or better, position;
- undrawn facilities; and
- undrawn servicer cash facilities.

This item excludes those exposures related to applicable revolving facilities, being exposures arising from redrawable facilities, other than exposures in the nature of redrawable home loans where the amounts likely to be redrawn are expected to be immaterial relative to the size of the pool. Revolving facilities are only applicable to this item where the reporting party transfers a pool of revolving exposures into a securitisation that contains an early amortisation provision.

A credit exposure represents asset, liability, claim or commitment of an entity, which may be recorded on or off the balance sheet and which gives rise to credit risk.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Exposures Senior And ABCP Securitisation And Eligible Facilities Excl Revolving Early Amortisation Amount
Financial Risk Credit Exposures Excl Revolving Facilities With Early Amortisation Provision And Other Exceptions Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the reporting party's exposures (on and off balance sheet) arising from revolving credit facilities extended to its customers, other than those related to credit cards.
     
Revolving credit is a loan arrangement in which the borrowing party may repay funds on loan and immediately borrow it again up to an agreed limit.
content.name: Assets Exposures Revolving Credit Not Cards Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the reporting party's exposures (on and off balance sheet) arising from credit card facilities extended to its customers.

A credit card is a card whose holder has been granted a revolving credit line up to a pre-arranged limit.
content.name: Assets Exposures Credit Card Amount

content.definition:
This is, as at the relevant date, the total committed amount, or limit, of loan facilities provided by the reporting party.

A Loan Facility is an arrangement in which the counterparty has the right but not the obligation to draw down funds to a specified limit.
content.name: Assets Exposures Loans Facilities Approved Limit Amount

content.definition:
This is the value of all exposures (both on and off balance sheet) arising from term loans receivable by the reporting party as at the relevant date.
     
Term loans are non securitised debt financing with a specified maturity date by which the loan must be repaid.
content.name: Assets Exposures Term Loans Amount

content.definition: This is the value of all exposures (both on and off balance sheet) arising from finance leases receivable by the reporting party as at the relevant date.
content.name: Assets Exposures Leases Amount

content.definition:
