Gains (losses) are realised where the entity disposed of an asset during the relevant period. If an asset has not been disposed of during the relevant period, then any increases or decreases in the fair value of the asset are recognised as unrealised gains (losses).
content.name: Profit Or Loss Realised Gains Or Losses Insurance Portfolios Excluding Foreign Exchange Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, during the relevant period, of unrealised gains (losses) on equity securities, including gains (losses) from subordinated debt.

For the purpose of this item exclude foreign currency gains (losses) that occur due to the currency translation of the securities.

Equity investments or securities are contracts that evidence a residual interest in the assets of an entity after deducting all its liabilities.

Gains (losses) are realised where the entity disposed of an asset during the relevant period. If an asset has not been disposed of during the relevant period, then any increases or decreases in the fair value of the asset are recognised as unrealised gains (losses)
content.name: Profit Or Loss Unrealised Gains Or Losses Equity Securities And Subordinated Debt Excluding Foreign Exchange Amount

content.definition:
This is the value of the rise in claims expense recognised for the relevant period which is due to prior period reserve strengthening. This item refers to movements in outstanding claims provisions due to changes in the assumptions used to calculate outstanding claims in prior periods that result in increases in the provision. It includes the impact of changes in the probability of sufficiency.

This item is determined in accordance with the relevant accounting standards, except that it is not discounted as required by those accounting standards.
content.name: Expense Insurance Claims Gross Reserve Strengthening Not Discounted Amount

content.definition:
This is the value of the reduction in claims expense recognised for the relevant period which is due to prior period reserve releases. This item refers to movements in outstanding claims provisions due to changes in the assumptions used to calculate outstanding claims in prior periods that result in decreases in the provision. It includes the impact of changes in the probability of sufficiency, and the release of risk margin as claims are paid.

This item is determined in accordance with the relevant accounting standards, except that it is not discounted as required by those accounting standards.
content.name: Income Insurance Claims Gross Reserve Releases Not Discounted Amount

content.definition:
This is the value of acquisition costs and other underwriting expenses recognised during the relevant period, as determined in accordance with relevant Accounting Standards.

This item should be an aggregate of all expenses incurred in writing insurance business. However, for the purposes of this item exclude:
- commission or brokerage paid to agents or brokers for obtaining business for the insurer; and
- results of the liability adequacy test (LAT).

Acquisition costs are incurred in obtaining and recording insurance contracts. They include commission or brokerage paid to agent or brokers for obtaining business for the insurer, selling and underwriting costs such as advertising and risk assessment, the administrative costs of recording policy information and premium collection costs.
content.name: Expense Insurance Underwriting Excluding Liability Adequacy Test Results And Commission Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, during the relevant period, of unrealised gains (losses) on loans and advances. For the purpose of this item exclude foreign currency gains (losses) that occur due to the currency translation of the securities.

Loans and advances are those financial assets categorised as "Loans and Receivables" in the accounting standards, other than "Trade Receivables" and "Cash".

Gains (losses) are realised where the entity disposed of an asset during the relevant period. If an asset has not been disposed of during the relevant period, then any increases or decreases in the fair value of the asset are recognised as unrealised gains (losses).
content.name: Profit Or Loss Unrealised Gains Or Losses Loans And Advances Excluding Foreign Exchange Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, during the relevant period, of unrealised gains (losses) on holdings of units in trusts or other management investment vehicles.

For the purpose of this item exclude foreign currency gains (losses) that occur due to currency translation of the units and management investment vehicles.

Gains (losses) are realised where the entity disposed of an asset during the relevant period. If an asset has not been disposed of during the relevant period, then any increases or decreases in the fair value of the asset are recognised as unrealised gains (losses).
content.name: Profit Or Loss Unrealised Gains Or Losses Unit Trusts And Managed Investment Vehicles Excluding Foreign Exchange Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, during the relevant period, of realised gains (losses) on equity securities, including gains (losses) from subordinated debt.

For the purpose of this item exclude foreign currency gains (losses) that occur due to the currency translation of the securities.

Equity investments or securities are contracts that evidence a residual interest in the assets of an entity after deducting all its liabilities.

Subordinated debt is a debt where the claim to repayment ranks lower in priority to other claims.

Gains (losses) are realised where the entity disposed of an asset during the relevant period. If an asset has not been disposed of during the relevant period, then any increases or decreases in the fair value of the asset are recognised as unrealised gains (losses).
content.name: Profit Or Loss Realised Gains Or Losses Equity Securities And Subordinated Debt Excluding Foreign Exchange Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, during the relevant period, of realised gains (losses) on loans and advances. For the purpose of this item exclude foreign currency gains (losses) that occur due to the currency translation of the loans and advances.

Loans and advances are those financial assets categorised as "Loans and Receivables" in the accounting standards, other than "Trade Receivables" and "Cash".

Gains (losses) are realised where the entity disposed of an asset during the relevant period. If an asset has not been disposed of during the relevant period, then any increases or decreases in the fair value of the asset are recognised as unrealised gains (losses).
content.name: Profit Or Loss Realised Gains Or Losses Loans And Advances Excluding Foreign Exchange Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, during the relevant period, of realised gains (losses), excluding foreign currency gains (losses) that occur due to currency translation.

Gains (losses) are realised where the entity disposed of an asset during the relevant period. If an asset has not been disposed of during the relevant period, then any increases or decreases in the fair value of the asset are recognised as unrealised gains (losses).
content.name: Profit Or Loss Realised Gains Or Losses Excluding Foreign Exchange Amount

content.definition: This is the value, during the relevant period, of the increments and decrements in value when assets are revalued in the books of a business to reflect their current market price. Revaluations may also result from assessed impairment of assets. A gain (or loss) is unrealised if there is no actual disposal of an asset involved.
content.name: Income Unrealised Gains Or Losses From Asset Revaluations Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, during the relevant period, of realised gains (losses) on holdings of units in trusts or other management investment vehicles.

For the purpose of this item exclude foreign currency gains (losses) that occur due to the currency translation.

Gains (losses) are realised where the entity disposed of an asset during the relevant period. If an asset has not been disposed of during the relevant period, then any increases or decreases in the fair value of the asset are recognised as unrealised gains (losses).
content.name: Profit Or Loss Realised Gains Or Losses Unit Trusts And Managed Investment Vehicles Excluding Foreign Exchange Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, during the relevant period, of realised gains (losses) on the fair value of debt securities.

This item does not include foreign currency gains (losses) that occur due to currency translation of the debt securities during the period.

Gains (losses) are realised where the entity disposed of an asset during the relevant period. If an asset has not been disposed of during the relevant period, then any increases or decreases in the fair value of the asset are recognised as unrealised gains (losses).

Debt securities are transferable instruments evidencing a relationship of indebtedness. It is characterised by having a definable income stream that is not based on the economic performance of the issuing entity. This item excludes loans and advances, and subordinated debt.
content.name: Profit Or Loss Realised Gains Or Losses Debt Securities Excluding Subordinated Debt And Foreign Exchange Amount

content.definition:
This is a balancing item in the list in which it is being used.

This is the value of realised gains (losses) from the disposal of other assets, as required to be reported on APRA Insurance forms 310_3.

This item does not include foreign currency gains (losses) that occur due to currency translation.
content.name: Profit Or Loss Realised Gains Or Losses Other Assets APRA Insurance 310 3 Excluding Foreign Exchange Amount

content.definition: This is the value of operating income for the relevant period, as required to be reported on GRF_310_3.
content.name: Income Insurance Operating GRF 310 3 Amount

content.definition:
This is a balancing item in the list in which it is being used.

This is the value of other foreign exchange gains (losses) from operating activities, as required to be reported on APRA Insurance forms 310_3.

Gains (losses) on foreign exchange represents exchange differences arising on the settlement of monetary items or on translating monetary items at rates different from those at which they were translated on initial recognition during the relevant period or in the previous period.

Gains (losses) are realised where the entity disposed of an asset during the relevant period. If an asset has not been disposed of during the relevant period, then any increases or decreases in the fair value of the asset are recognised as unrealised gains (losses).
content.name: Profit Or Loss Realised And Unrealised Foreign Exchange Gains Or Losses Other Insurance 310 3 Amount

content.definition:
This is a balancing item in the list in which it is being used.

This is the value of other fee and commission income, as required on APRA Insurance form 310_3.
content.name: Income Insurance Fees Commissions Other 310 3 Amount

content.definition:
This is the value of any fee income or commission associated with underwriting for the relevant period.

Do not include commission revenue that is associated with underwriting activities and is disclosed as commission revenue in the calculation of underwriting expenses in accordance with relevant Accounting Standards.
content.name: Income Insurance Fees And Commissions Underwriting Amount

content.definition: This is the value of any fee or commission income associated with scrip lending activities during the relevant period. This refers to the situation where the entity buys or borrows securities from another party in exchange for cash. The entity agrees to return the securities to the other party in the future in exchange for the return of the cash (plus an additional amount of earnings, fees or commissions).
content.name: Income Fees And Commissions Scrip Lending Amount

content.definition: This is the value, during the relevant period, of any fee income or commission. Do not include commission revenue that is associated with underwriting activities and is disclosed as commission revenue in the calculation of underwriting expenses in accordance with the relevant Accounting Standards.
content.name: Income Fees Commissions Excluding Underwriting Amount

content.definition: This is the value, during the relevant period, of gains (losses) from the revaluation of assets that are recognised in the profit (loss). This item relates to any increment (write-down) in the carrying amount of assets.
content.name: Profit Or Loss Gains Or Losses From Asset Revaluation Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, during the relevant period, of realised and unrealised foreign exchange gains (losses) relating to derivatives over hedged borrowings. This item is in accordance with the relevant accounting standards.

Derivatives are generally defined as those instruments/contracts, where the value is based on other products, and/or on prices associated with financial products. Derivative contracts involve:
- Future delivery, receipt or exchange of financial items such as cash or another derivative instrument; or
- Future exchange of real assets for financial items where the contract may be tradeable and has a market value.
The contracts can either be binding on both parties (e.g. as with a currency swap) or subject to the exercise by one party of a right contained within the contract (as with options).

Gains (losses) are realised where the entity disposed of an asset during the relevant period. If an asset has not been disposed of during the relevant period, then any increases or decreases in the fair value of the asset are recognised as unrealised gains (losses).
content.name: Profit Or Loss Foreign Exchange Gains Or Losses Derivatives Over Hedged Borrowings Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, during the relevant period, of realised and unrealised foreign exchange gains (losses) relating to derivatives over hedged claims exposure. This item is in accordance with the relevant accounting standards.

Derivatives are generally defined as those instruments/contracts, where the value is based on other products, and/or on prices associated with financial products. Derivative contracts involve:
- Future delivery, receipt or exchange of financial items such as cash or another derivative instrument; or
- Future exchange of real assets for financial items where the contract may be tradeable and has a market value.
The contracts can either be binding on both parties (e.g. as with a currency swap) or subject to the exercise by one party of a right contained within the contract (as with options).

Gains (losses) are realised where the entity disposed of an asset during the relevant period. If an asset has not been disposed of during the relevant period, then any increases or decreases in the fair value of the asset are recognised as unrealised gains (losses).
content.name: Profit Or Loss Foreign Exchange Gains Or Losses Derivatives Over Hedged Claims Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, during the relevant period, of realised and unrealised foreign exchange gains (losses) relating to borrowings which have been hedged. This item is in accordance with the relevant accounting standards.

Derivatives are generally defined as those instruments/contracts, where the value is based on other products, and/or on prices associated with financial products. Derivative contracts involve:
- Future delivery, receipt or exchange of financial items such as cash or another derivative instrument; or
- Future exchange of real assets for financial items where the contract may be tradeable and has a market value.
The contracts can either be binding on both parties (e.g. as with a currency swap) or subject to the exercise by one party of a right contained within the contract (as with options).

Gains (losses) are realised where the entity disposed of an asset during the relevant period. If an asset has not been disposed of during the relevant period, then any increases or decreases in the fair value of the asset are recognised as unrealised gains (losses).

Foreign exchange gains (losses) relate to the conversion or translation of the item into the reporting currency.
content.name: Profit Or Loss Foreign Exchange Gains Or Losses On Hedged Borrowings Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, during the relevant period, of realised and unrealised foreign exchange gains (losses) relating to claims liabilities which have been hedged. This item is in accordance with the relevant accounting standards.

Derivatives are generally defined as those instruments/contracts, where the value is based on other products, and/or on prices associated with financial products. Derivative contracts involve:
- Future delivery, receipt or exchange of financial items such as cash or another derivative instrument; or
- Future exchange of real assets for financial items where the contract may be tradeable and has a market value.
The contracts can either be binding on both parties (e.g. as with a currency swap) or subject to the exercise by one party of a right contained within the contract (as with options).

Gains (losses) are realised where the entity disposed of an asset during the relevant period. If an asset has not been disposed of during the relevant period, then any increases or decreases in the fair value of the asset are recognised as unrealised gains (losses).

Foreign exchange gains (losses) relate to the conversion or translation of the item into the reporting currency.
content.name: Profit Or Loss Foreign Exchange Gains Or Losses On Hedged Claims Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the Maximum Event Retention (MER) calculated. This represents the Probable Maximum Loss (PML) plus claims handling expenses calculated, and net of allowable reinsurance. This item is to be determined in accordance with relevant Prudential Standards.

Probable Maximum Loss (PML) is the largest gross loss to which an insurer will be exposed (taking into account the probability of that loss) due to a concentration of risk exposures, without any allowance for potential reinsurance recoveries.
content.name: Financial Risk Maximum Event Retention Amount

content.definition: This is the value of distributions received from trusts where the entity has chosen a non look-through basis during the relevant period.
content.name: Income Trust Distributions Non Look Through Amount

content.definition: This is the profit (loss) after tax for the relevant period attributable to non-controlling interests. This item is calculated in accordance with the relevant Prudential Standards and represents the proportion of profit (loss) after tax of both continuing and discontinued operations not attributable directly, or indirectly to the parent of the reporting party.
content.name: Profit Or Loss Insurance After Tax Attributable To Non Controlling Interests Amount

content.definition: This is the profit (loss) after tax for the relevant period attributable to members of the reporting party. This item is calculated in accordance with the relevant Prudential Standards and represents the proportion of profit (loss) after tax of both continuing and discontinued operations  attributable directly, or indirectly to the members of the reporting party.
content.name: Profit Or Loss Insurance After Tax Attributable To Members Amount

content.definition:
This is the value of realised gains (losses) on the fair value of debt securities during the relevant period.

This item does not include foreign currency gains (losses) that occur due to currency translation of the debt securities.

Gains (losses) are realised where the entity disposed of an asset during the relevant period. If an asset has not been disposed of during the relevant period, then any increases or decreases in the fair value of the asset are recognised as unrealised gains (losses).

Debt securities are transferable instruments evidencing a relationship of indebtedness. It is characterised by having a definable income stream that is not based on the economic performance of the issuing entity.
content.name: Profit Or Loss Realised Gains Or Losses Debt Securities Excluding Foreign Exchange Amount

content.definition:
This is the value of realised gains (losses) on equity securities for the relevant period.

For the purpose of this item exclude foreign currency gains (losses) that occur due to the currency translation of the securities.

Equity investments or securities are contracts that evidence a residual interest in the assets of an entity after deducting all its liabilities.

Gains (losses) are realised where the entity disposed of an asset during the relevant period. If an asset has not been disposed of during the relevant period, then any increases or decreases in the fair value of the asset are recognised as unrealised gains (losses).
content.name: Profit Or Loss Realised Gains Or Losses Equity Securities Excluding Foreign Exchange Amount

content.definition:
This is a balancing item in the list in which it is being used.

This is for the duration of the relevant period, the value of realised gains (losses) on the fair value of other investments as required on APRA form GRF_310_0_G.

This item does not include foreign currency gains (losses) that occur due to currency translation.

Gains (losses) are realised where the entity disposed of an asset during the relevant period. If an asset has not been disposed of during the relevant period, then any increases or decreases in the fair value of the asset are recognised as unrealised gains (losses).
content.name: Profit Or Loss Realised Gains Or Losses Other GRF 310 G Excluding Foreign Exchange Amount

content.definition:
This is the value of unrealised gains (losses) associated with changes in the fair value of investments during the relevant period.

Investments are assets or liabilities acquired principally for profit-taking purposes.

This item does not include foreign currency gains (losses) that occur due to currency translation.

Gains (losses) are realised where the entity disposed of an asset during the relevant period. If an asset has not been disposed of during the relevant period, then any increases or decreases in the fair value of the asset are recognised as unrealised gains (losses).
content.name: Profit Or Loss Investment Unrealised Gains Or Losses On Changes In Fair Value Excluding Foreign Exchange Amount

content.definition:
This is the value of unrealised gains (losses) on the fair value of debt securities during the relevant period.

This item does not include foreign currency gains (losses) that occur due to currency translation of the debt securities.

Gains (losses) are realised where the entity disposed of an asset during the relevant period. If an asset has not been disposed of during the relevant period, then any increases or decreases in the fair value of the asset are recognised as unrealised gains (losses).

Debt securities are transferable instruments evidencing a relationship of indebtedness. It is characterised by having a definable income stream that is not based on the economic performance of the issuing entity.
content.name: Profit Or Loss Unrealised Gains Or Losses Debt Securities Excluding Foreign Exchange Amount

content.definition:
This is the value of unrealised gains (losses) on equity securities for the relevant period.

For the purpose of this item exclude foreign currency gains (losses) that occur due to the currency translation of the securities.

Equity investments or securities are contracts that evidence a residual interest in the assets of an entity after deducting all its liabilities.

Gains (losses) are realised where the entity disposed of an asset during the relevant period. If an asset has not been disposed of during the relevant period, then any increases or decreases in the fair value of the asset are recognised as unrealised gains (losses).
content.name: Profit Or Loss Unrealised Gains Or Losses Equity Securities Excluding Foreign Exchange Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, during the relevant period, of the net value of realised gains and (losses) from the revaluation of the reporting entity's investment property portfolio, as determined in accordance with relevant accounting standards.

Investments are assets or liabilities acquired or incurred principally for profit-taking purposes.

This item does not include foreign currency gains (losses) that occur due to currency translation.

Gains (losses) are realised where the entity disposed of an asset during the relevant period. If an asset has not been disposed of during the relevant period, then any increases or decreases in the fair value of the asset are recognised as unrealised gains (losses).
content.name: Income Realised Gain Loss Investment Property Excluding Foreign Exchange Amount

content.definition:
This is a balancing item in the list in which it is being used.

This is for the duration of the relevant period, the value of unrealised gains (losses) on the fair value of other investments as required on APRA form GRF_310_0_G.

This item does not include foreign currency gains (losses) that occur due to currency translation.

Gains (losses) are realised where the entity disposed of an asset during the relevant period. If an asset has not been disposed of during the relevant period, then any increases or decreases in the fair value of the asset are recognised as unrealised gains (losses).
content.name: Profit Or Loss Unrealised Gains Or Losses Other GRF 310 G Excluding Foreign Exchanges Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of retained earnings calculated in accordance with the relevant Prudential Standards.
content.name: Equity Retained Profits Prudential Amount

content.definition: This is the value of interest expense from borrowings as determined in accordance with relevant Accounting Standards. For the purposes of this item exclude interest expense associated with derivative contracts or funds classified as loan capital.
content.name: Expense Interest Borrowings Amount

content.definition:
This is a balancing item in the list in which it has been used.

This is the value of interest expense associated with other interest bearing liabilities as required for APRA Insurance forms 310_3.
content.name: Expense Interest Other APRA Insurance 310 3 Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, during the relevant period, of interest expense associated with derivative contracts. This item is determined in accordance with relevant Accounting Standards.

Derivatives are generally defined as those instruments/contracts, where the value is based on other products, and/or on prices associated with financial products. Derivative contracts involve:
- Future delivery, receipt or exchange of financial items such as cash or another derivative instrument; or
- Future exchange of real assets for financial items where the contract may be tradeable and has a market value.
The contracts can either be binding on both parties (e.g. as with a currency swap) or subject to the exercise by one party of a right contained within the contract (as with options).
content.name: Expense Interest Derivative Contracts Amount

content.definition: This is the value of remuneration expenses, other than wages and salaries and share-based payments, for the relevant period as determined in accordance with accounting standards.
content.name: Expense Operating Other Non Share Based Remuneration Excluding Wages And Salaries Amount

content.definition: This is the value, during the relevant period, of personnel related expenses as determined in accordance with relevant accounting standards.
content.name: Expense Operating Personnel Amount

content.definition: This is the value, during the relevant period, of expenditure incurred on operating leases as determined in accordance with relevant Accounting Standards.
content.name: Expense Leases Operating Amount

content.definition:
This is a balancing item in the list in which it is being used.

This is the value of other occupancy and equipment expenses, as required to be reported on APRA Insurance forms 310_3.

This item represents occupancy and equipment expenses other than depreciation and operating lease rentals, as determined in accordance with accounting standards.
content.name: Expense Operating Office And Equipment Other APRA Insurance 310 3 Amount

content.definition: This is the value, during the relevant period, of expenditure incurred on occupancy and equipment as determined in accordance with relevant Accounting Standards.
content.name: Expense Occupancy And Equipment Amount

content.definition: This is the value, during the relevant period, of impairment charged to profit and loss in respect of intangible assets with indefinite useful life as determined in accordance with accounting standards.
content.name: Expense Operating Impairment Intangible Assets Indefinite Useful Life Amount

content.definition: This is the value, during the relevant period, of impairment charged to profit and loss in respect of assets other than those classified as goodwill or intangible assets with an indefinite useful life. This item is to be determined in accordance with relevant accounting standards.
content.name: Expense Operating Impairment Other Amount

content.definition: This is the value, during the relevant period, of non-audit related service fees provided by audit firms during the relevant period in accordance with relevant accounting standards.
content.name: Expense Operating Non Audit Related Amount

content.definition:
This is a balancing item in the list in which it is being used.

This is, for the duration of the relevant period,  of other operating expenses as required to be reported on APRA Insurance form 310_3.
content.name: Expense Operating Other APRA Insurance 310 3 Amount

content.definition:
This is a balancing item in the list in which it is being used.

This is, for the duration of the relevant period,  of total other operating expenses as required to be reported on APRA Insurance form 310_3.
content.name: Expense Operating Total Other APRA Insurance 310 3 Amount

content.definition: This is the value, during the relevant period, of remuneration expenses relating to wages and salaries as determined in accordance with accounting standards.
content.name: Expense Operating Wages And Salaries Amount

content.definition: This is the amount, as at the relevant date, by which the premium liability proxy calculated from figures determined in accordance with accounting standards exceeds (or is in deficit of) the equivalent figure determined in accordance with prudential standards. This item is calculated after adjusting for the deferred reinsurance expense for future policies.
content.name: Liabilities Insurance Premiums Liabilities Net Surplus Deficit Including Deferred Reinsurance Future Policies Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of amounts payable by the reporting party on reinsurance contracts.

For the purposes of this item, include the net amount payable by the insurer to reinsurers or retrocessionaires where a legal right of set-off exists. This reflects the current working balance due for settlement. Include premiums payable but not yet due for payment under the terms of the reinsurance contracts and deposits withheld from reinsurers which should correspond to the recognition of DRE under prudential standards and represent the total premium payable under reinsurance contracts. Include items such as the reinsurer's portion of recoveries and salvage and commissions due to reinsurers.
content.name: Liabilities Insurance Payable On Reinsurance Contracts Amount

content.definition:
This is the amount, as at the relevant date, of the tax effect relating to the outstanding claims liabilities (OCL) surplus/deficit and premiums liabilities surplus/deficit (i.e. the corporate tax rate multiplied by the net amount).

An OCL surplus/deficit results if the OCL net of any recoveries, determined in accordance with accounting standards exceeds (or is in deficit of) the equivalent figure determined in accordance with prudential standards.

A premium liabilities surplus/deficit results if the premium liability proxy calculated from figures determined in accordance with accounting standards exceeds (or is in deficit of) the equivalent figure determined in accordance with prudential standards.
content.name: Liabilities Insurance Outstanding Claims And Premiums Liabilities Net Surplus Deficit Tax Effect Adjustment Amount

content.definition:
This is the amount, as at the relevant date, of the outstanding claims provision (OCP) surplus/deficit and premiums liabilities surplus/deficit adjusted for tax effect. This item is calculated as A + B - C where:

A = OCP surplus/deficit, being the outstanding claims provision (OCP), net of any recoveries, determined in accordance with accounting standards in excess/deficit of the equivalent figure determined in accordance with prudential standards.

B = premium liabilities surplus/deficit, being the premium liability proxy calculated from figures determined in accordance with accounting standards in excess/deficit of the equivalent figure determined in accordance with prudential standards. This item includes deferred reinsurance expense for future policies.

C = tax effect of net OCP and premiums liabilities surplus/deficit, being of the tax effect relating to the OCP surplus/deficit and premiums liabilities surplus/deficit (i.e. the corporate tax rate multiplied by the net amount).
content.name: Liabilities Insurance Outstanding Claims Provision And Premiums Liabilities Net Surplus Deficit After Tax Effect Adjustment Amount

content.definition: This is, as at the relevant date, the principal amount of loans provided to an insured for the purposes of funding their premium, gross of associated provisions for impairment and deferred fee income, and including any accrued interest.
content.name: Assets Insurance Loans Premium Funding Gross Amount

content.definition: This is, as at the relevant date, the principal amount of loans provided to an insured for the purposes of funding their premium, net of associated provisions for impairment and deferred fee income, and including any accrued interest.
content.name: Assets Insurance Loans Premium Funding Net Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of provisions for impairment in relation to loans provided to an insured for the purposes of funding their premium.
content.name: Assets Insurance Loans Premium Funding Impairment Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of investment risk charge rebate in relation to eligible collateral, guarantees or letters of credit provided to the reporting party, as determined in accordance with relevant prudential standard.

Eligible collateral includes any form of security that supports the value of assets held by the reporting party other than guarantees and letters of credit.
content.name: Financial Risk Credit Eligible Collateral Guarantees Letters Of Credit Rebate Investment Risk Charge Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date of the concentration risk capital charge calculated as A + B, where

A = Maximum Event Retention, being the largest loss to which an insurer will be exposed (taking into account the probability of that loss) due to concentration of risk exposures, after netting out any potential reinsurance recoverables;

B = the cost of one reinstatement of the catastrophe reinsurance cover  in cases where the reinsurance cover has not been pre-paid by the insurer.

Concentration risk capital charge is the component of the minimum capital requirement that takes into account the highest aggregation of risks of an insurer and is determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Concentration Risk Capital Charge Amount

content.definition: This is the description, as at the relevant date, of the detailed line item comprising the variations in capital charges as approved by APRA.
content.name: Financial Risk Variation In Capital Charges Approved By APRA Description

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of variations in capital charges as approved by APRA.
content.name: Financial Risk Variation In Capital Charges Approved By APRA Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the minimum capital requirement, being the amount of risk-based capital that is required for an entity to hold to meet its obligations under a wide range of circumstances determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Minimum Capital Requirement Amount

content.definition: This is the amount, as at the relevant date, of liabilities net of surplus/deficit relating to insurance liabilities.
content.name: Liabilities Insurance Net Of Surplus Deficit Relating To Insurance Liabilities Amount

content.definition: This is the amount, as at the relevant date, of net assets after adding or deducting the net surplus/deficit related to insurance liabilities, but before any deductions excluded for capital adequacy purposes and determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Assets Insurance Net Before Excluded Deductions Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of net goodwill and intangible assets as determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards. For the purposes of this item include the value of unlisted equities that represent the purchased goodwill and other intangible assets in relation to acquisition of controlled entities.
content.name: Assets Goodwill And Intangible Assets Net Including Purchased Goodwill Controlled Entities Unlisted Equities Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of net goodwill and intangible assets as determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards. For the purposes of this item include the value of purchased goodwill and other intangible assets in relation to acquisition of controlled entities.
content.name: Assets Goodwill And Intangible Assets Net Including Purchased Goodwill Controlled Entities Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of deferred tax assets (DTA) net of any deferred tax liabilities, as determined in accordance with relevant accounting standards. For the purposes of this item exclude those DTAs related to surplus/deficit in defined benefit superannuation funds.
content.name: Assets Insurance Deferred Tax Net Excluding Relating To Surplus Deficit Defined Benefit Super Fund Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of any surplus in a defined benefit superannuation fund of which the reporting entity is an employer-sponsor, as determined in accordance with relevant accounting standards. 

The surplus in defined superannuation fund represents the favourable difference between the plan assets and the present value of the defined benefit obligation.
content.name: Assets Other Financial Assets Surplus Defined Benefit Superannuation Fund Amount

content.definition: Dividends are distributions of profits to the shareholders of a company in proportion to their holdings of a particular class of capital.
content.name: Equity Dividends Paid Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of any deficit in a defined benefit superannuation fund of which the reporting entity is an employer-sponsor, determined in accordance with the relevant accounting standards.
content.name: Liabilities Other Non Financial Liabilities Deficit Defined Benefit Superannuation Fund Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of any asset (net of provisions for doubtful debts) recognised by the reporting entity that relates to reinsurance where the reporting entity has not complied with the threshold levels of reinsurance documentation set out in the relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Assets Insurance Reinsurance Do Not Meet Documentation Test Net Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of reinsurance assets receivable under each reinsurance contract entered into by the insurer incepting on or after 31 December 2008 that do not meet the governing law requirements specified in the relevant prudential standard.
content.name: Assets Insurance Reinsurance Do Not Meet Governing Law Requirement Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of dividends/head office transfers that the reporting party is expecting, but which have not been declared or paid.
content.name: Assets Dividend Expected Not Declared Or Paid Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of other deductions as required for either GRF_110_0_B or GRF_110_0_L, as determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Capital Adequacy Other Deductions GRF 110 0 B And GRF 110 0 L Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of variations in deduction as approved by APRA.
content.name: Financial Risk Variation In Deduction Approved By APRA Amount

content.definition: This is, as at the relevant date, the capital adequacy ratio of the reporting party as determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Capital Adequacy Ratio Percent

content.definition:
This is the value. as at the relevant date, of the reporting party's capital coverage surplus or deficit.

The capital coverage surplus or deficit represents the adequacy of an entity's current capital resources in meeting the current and future needs of the entity. Adequacy will generally be reflected in the extent of surplus capital when capital levels are considered with respect to capital adequacy requirements as determined in accordance to relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Capital Coverage Surplus Or Deficit Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of solvency coverage ratio, as determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.

Solvency refers to the ability of an entity to meet its obligations (liabilities) under all contracts at any time.
content.name: Financial Risk Solvency Coverage Ratio Fraction

content.definition:
This is the amount, as at the relevant date, of technical provisions in excess of liability valuation, calculated as A + B, where:

A = technical provisions in excess of liability valuation on Outstanding Claims Provision (OCP), being the amount by which the outstanding claims provision (OCP), net of any recoveries, determined in accordance with accounting standards exceeds (or is in deficit of) the equivalent figure determined in accordance with prudential standards; and

B = excess technical provisions on premiums liabilities, being the amount by which the premium liability proxy calculated from figures determined in accordance with prudential standards exceeds (or is in deficit of) the technical provision determined in accordance with accounting standards.
content.name: Liabilities Insurance Technical Provisions In Excess Of Liability Valuation Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of deferred reinsurance expense that relates to future policies.
content.name: Assets Insurance Deferred Reinsurance Expense Policies Future Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of other deductions as required to be reported on the APRA GRF_120_0 form series, as determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Capital Adequacy Other Deductions GRF 120 0 Amount

content.definition:
This is a balancing item in the list in which it is being used.

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of all other Upper Tier 2 capital instruments perpetual and cumulative in nature, as required to be reported on the APRA GRF_120_0 form series.

This item is calculated for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant Prudential Standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Capital Adequacy Upper Tier 2 Perpetual Cumulative Capital Instruments Other GRF 120 0 Amount

content.definition:
This is a balancing item in the list in which it is being used.

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of all other Upper Tier 2 capital instruments perpetual and cumulative in nature, as required to be reported on the APRA GRF_120_0 form series.

This item is calculated for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant Prudential Standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Capital Adequacy Upper Tier 2 Perpetual Cumulative Capital Instruments Permanent Nature Other GRF 120 Amount

content.definition:
This is a balancing item in the list in which it is being used.

This is the value, as at the relevant date, of all Lower Tier 2 capital instruments, other than those classified as term subordinated debt or limited life redeemable preference shares, as required to be reported in the APRA GRF_120_0 form series. 

This item is calculated for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant Prudential Standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Capital Adequacy Lower Tier 2 Other Capital Instruments GRF 120 Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of equity exposures and other capital investments held by the reporting party.

Where a facility, including a guarantee, provided to a related party or a non-related party constitutes 'capital support', it must be treated as 'other capital investments'.

This item is calculated for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant Prudential Standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Capital Adequacy Equity Exposures And Capital Investments Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of reserves arising from the revaluation of Investments in non-consolidated controlled entities not held at fair value, and which can be classified as Upper Tier 2 capital. 

For the purposes of this item, exclude any reserve recognised from the revaluation of the goodwill component of investments in subsidiaries not held at fair value.

This item is calculated for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant Prudential Standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Capital Adequacy Upper Tier 2 Asset Revaluation Reserve Of Investments In Non Consolidated Controlled Entities Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of gross Tier 2 capital. 

Gross Tier 2 capital represents the sum of net Upper Tier 2 capital and net Lower Tier 2 capital, gross of any Tier 2 capital deductions.

This item is calculated for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant Prudential Standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Capital Adequacy Tier 2 Gross Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the cost of one full reinstatement premium for the insurer's catastrophe cover as determined in accordance with relevant Prudential Standards.

Following a loss occurrence recoverable under a catastrophe excess of loss reinsurance program, the cost of one reinstatement is the contracted premium payable by the insurer to fully reinstate the reinsurance program to its original level existing prior to the occurrence of that loss.  

For prudential purposes, the loss occurrence is considered to be the probable maximum loss event eroding one total loss from the entire catastrophe excess of loss reinsurance program.  The cost of one reinstatement is the contracted premium of reinstating the entire catastrophe excess of loss reinsurance program.
content.name: Financial Risk Cost Of One Reinstatement Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of reserves arising from the revaluation of property (including owner-occupied and investment property readily available to be sold), but only where that property is classified as Upper Tier 2 capital. 

Where a particular asset belongs to a class of assets for which the Asset Revaluation Reserve (ARR) are included in Upper Tier 2 capital and the asset has been identified as impaired and losses arise, the losses may be offset against any existing revaluations of the asset or class of revalued assets.

If the ARR is negative after adjustment for revaluations of assets included in the reserve, for losses due to impairment of assets covered by the reserve, and for any gains or losses on hedges offsetting revaluations of assets included in the reserve, report zero at this item.

This item is net of any fair value gains and losses, and any gains or losses on hedges offsetting revaluations included in reserves.

For the purposes of this item, do not include any ARR amounts that have been included as Capital Profit Reserves.

This item is calculated for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant Prudential Standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Capital Adequacy Upper Tier 2 Asset Revaluation Reserves Property Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of reserves arising from the revaluation of the Eligible Component of Investments in Associates, Joint Ventures and non-consolidated Subsidiaries, and which can be classified as Upper Tier 2 capital.

Where a particular asset belongs to a class of assets for which the Asset Revaluation Reserve (ARR) are included in Upper Tier 2 capital and the asset has been identified as impaired and losses arise, the losses may be offset against any existing revaluations of the asset or class of revalued assets.

If the ARR is negative after adjustment for revaluations of assets included in the reserve, for losses due to impairment of assets covered by the reserve, and for any gains or losses on hedges offsetting revaluations of assets included in the reserve, report zero at this item.

This item is net of any fair value gains and losses, and any gains or losses on hedges offsetting revaluations included in reserves.

For the purposes of this item, do not include any ARR amounts that have been included as Capital Profit Reserves.

This item is calculated for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant Prudential Standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Capital Adequacy Upper Tier 2 Asset Revaluation Reserve Eligible Component Of Investments Amount

content.definition: Has the person who has ceased to be a responsible person ceased because they are no longer fit and proper?
content.guidance:
A choice of TRUE/FALSE values
TRUE = the person has ceased to be a responsible person because they are no longer fit and proper
FALSE = the person who has ceased to be a responsible person did not cease because they are no longer fit and proper
content.name: Regulatory Disclosures No Longer Fit And Proper Indicator

content.definition: This item indicates whether the person has been assessed under the entity's Fit and Proper Policy.
content.guidance:
The valid enumerated values are: 
Yes = the person has been assessed under the entity's Fit and Proper Policy. 
No = the person has not been assessed under the entity's Fit and Proper Policy. 
Interim = the appointment has been made with a pending fit and proper assessment.
content.name: Regulatory Disclosures Assessed Fit And Proper Code

content.definition: Is the responsible person, as determined in accordance with relevant Prudential Standards, a director of the company?
content.guidance:
A choice of TRUE/FALSE values
TRUE = the responsible person, as determined in accordance with relevant Prudential Standards, is a director of the company.
FALSE = the responsible person, as determined in accordance with relevant Prudential Standards, is not a director of the company.
content.name: Regulatory Disclosures Director Indicator

content.definition: Is the responsible person the Senior Officer outside Australia, as required and determined in accordance with relevant Prudential Standards?
content.guidance:
A choice of TRUE/FALSE values
TRUE = the responsible person is the Senior Officer outside Australia, as required and determined in accordance with relevant Prudential Standards.
FALSE = the responsible person is not the Senior Officer outside Australia, as required and determined in accordance with relevant Prudential Standards.
content.name: Regulatory Disclosures Senior Officer Outside Australia Indicator

content.definition: This is the main responsibilities of the person associated with the name.
content.name: Party Main Responsibilities Text

content.definition: This is a person's former name(s). This is where the person has had a change in name due to marriage or other reasons.
content.name: Identification Details Former Name Text

content.definition: Indicates the entity's preferred method for receiving APRA levy invoices.
content.name: Miscellaneous Preferred Invoice Format Code

content.definition:
This is the value of acquisition costs and other underwriting expenses recognised during the relevant period, as determined in accordance with relevant Accounting Standards.

This item should be an aggregate of all expenses incurred in writing insurance business gross of any commission revenue.
content.name: Expense Insurance Underwriting Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of premium income received in advance which is still unearned and is classified as a liability to the entity. For the purposes of this item, exclude the unearned portion of premium that relates to fire services levy or other levies imposed by state and territory governments.

Unearned premium income is that portion of the written premium applicable to the unused part of the period for which the premium has been paid. Thus, in the case of an annual premium, at the end of the first month of the premium period, eleven-twelfths of the premium is unearned.

Premiums, as defined by the Australian Accounting Standards, are amounts charged in relation to accepting risk from the insured, but does not include amounts collected on behalf of third parties.
content.name: Liabilities Insurance Unearned Premium Income Excluding Fire Service Or Other Government Levy Amount

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the outstanding claims provision (OCP) liability, net of any recovery assets that relate to the gross OCP (including reinsurance recoveries, GST recoveries and other recoveries).  Assets and liabilities are as determined in accordance with relevant Accounting Standards.
content.name: Liabilities Insurance Outstanding Claims Provision Net Accounting Amount

content.definition:
This is the number of used passenger vehicles for which an offer by the reporting party has been accepted by its customer during the relevant period.
                                                                                                                                            
Vehicles to be included in this total are cars, station wagons, four wheel drive and forward control passenger vehicles that have previously been owned. Do not include utilities, panel vans, buses, motor cycles/scooters or special purpose vehicles - e.g. ambulances, tow trucks, hearses, fire engines, etc.
content.name: Assets Exposures New Commitments Goods Financed Passenger Vehicles Used Count

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the traded market risk, as determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Financial Risk.Market Traded Amount

content.definition:
This is the principal amount, gross of provisions for impairment and including accrued interest, of loans and advances that have been sold to or originated into securitisation programs, by or on behalf of the reporting party, or by a third party to a securitisation program sponsored by the reporting party, as at the relevant date.

Loans and advances are those financial assets categorised as "Loans and Receivables" in the accounting standards, other than "Trade Receivables" and "Cash".

A securitisation program represents a structure (a special purpose vehicle, or SPV) where the cash flows from a pool (of assets, or interests in assets) are used to service obligations to creditors (typically holders of debt securities) who fund the SPV.
     
A SPV is a "bankruptcy-remote entity" with operations limited to the acquisition and financing of specific assets. Usually a subsidiary entity with balance sheet and legal status that makes its obligations secure even if the parent company goes bankrupt."
content.name: Assets Securitised Loans And Advances Including Accrued Interest Gross Impairment Amount

content.definition:
This is the principal value, gross of provisions for impairment and including accrued interest, of assets that have been sold to or originated into securitisation programs, by or on behalf of the reporting party, or by a third party to a securitisation program sponsored by the reporting party, as at the relevant date.

For the purpose of this item, only report those assets that have been transferred into securitisation warehouses and other short-term term (i.e. less than one year in maturity) funding vehicles, whether or not funded by commercial paper or other arrangements.

A securitisation warehouse represents a structure that accumulates exposures until a sufficiently large pool is available for issuance of securities to the market.

A securitisation program represents a structure (a special purpose vehicle, or SPV) where the cash flows from a pool (of assets, or interests in assets) are used to service obligations to creditors (typically holders of debt securities) who fund the SPV.

A SPV is a "bankruptcy-remote entity" with operations limited to the acquisition and financing of specific assets. Usually a subsidiary entity with balance sheet and legal status that makes its obligations secure even if the parent company goes bankrupt.
content.name: Assets Securitised Including Accrued Income Gross Impairment Held By Warehouses Amount

content.definition: This is the value of staff related costs paid or payable to employment agencies by the reporting party during the relevant period.
content.name: Expense Operating Employment Agencies Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of term subordinated debt classified as Lower Tier 2 capital. Only report the amount that is eligible for inclusion at this item. This is calculated based on each instruments residual term to maturity, as determined in accordance with prudential standards.

Term subordinated debt instruments have significant deficiencies as constituents of capital in view of their fixed maturity and inability to absorb losses except in a liquidation. These deficiencies justify an additional restriction on the amount of such debt capital which is eligible for inclusion within the capital base.

This item is calculated for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant prudential standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Capital Adequacy Lower Tier 2 Term Subordinated Debt Eligible Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of limited life redeemable preference shares classified as Lower Tier 2 capital. Only report the amount that is eligible for inclusion at this item. This is calculated based on each instruments residual term to maturity.

This item is calculated for capital adequacy purposes and is to be determined in accordance with relevant Prudential Standards.
content.name: Financial Risk Capital Adequacy Lower Tier 2 Limited Life Redeemable Preference Shares Eligible Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, for the duration of the relevant period, of the net value of unrealised gains and (losses) from the revaluation of the reporting party's investment property portfolio, as determined in accordance with relevant accounting standards.

Investments are assets or liabilities acquired or incurred principally for profit-taking purposes.

This item does not include foreign currency gains (losses) that occur due to currency translation of the debt securities.

Gains (losses) are realised where the entity disposed of an asset during the relevant period. If an asset has not been disposed of during the relevant period, then any increases or decreases in the fair value of the asset are recognised as unrealised gains (losses).
content.name: Income Unrealised Gain Loss Investment Property Excluding Foreign Exchange Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of all undrawn lending commitments, or firm offers, provided by the reporting party.

For the purposes of this item, where an amount has been previously advanced in relation to a revolving loan, repayments of these amounts should not increase the undrawn commitment. Additions to the stock of undrawn commitments can only be made by new commitments, while reductions in the stock of undrawn commitments can only occur through advances and cancellation of those new commitments.

A commitment is a firm offer to provide finance which has been accepted by the client. A commitment exists once the loan application has been approved, and a loan contract or letter of offer has been issued to the borrower.
content.name: Assets Exposures Lending Commitments Undrawn Amount

content.definition:
This is the value of new lending commitments, or firm offers, other than those in the form of revolving credit loans, provided by the reporting party during the relevant period, regardless of whether or not they have subsequently been withdrawn, or cancelled, during or after the period. New commitments will also include commitments for hire purchase agreements, commitments for debt participation in leveraged lease agreements, commitments that involve or make provision for the issue of bills of exchange to be accepted, discounted or drawn down, and commitment for standby agreements. Do not report commitments for lease agreements (other than hire purchase agreements and debt participation in leveraged lease agreements, the purchase of securities unless it involves a direct commitment to a client, bills of exchange and promissory notes purchased and held, commitments contingent on some specified eventuality (e.g. bill endorsement, guarantees, letter of credit) unless and until that eventuality occurs) and commitments for discounts which exists as options under acceptance commitments.

A commitment is a firm offer to provide finance which has been accepted by the client. A commitment exists once the loan application has been approved, and a loan contract or letter of offer has been issued to the borrower. 

Revolving credit facilities involve a commitment for a credit or borrowing limit and where the extent of the borrowings used at any one time may be for any amount up to the authorised limit. Repayments (other than of changes and interest) reduce the borrowings thereby increasing the amount of unused credit available.

With transactions involving a change of residence, you should treat the discharge of the existing loan and the commitment to a new loan as separate events, and report the total value of the new loan as a new commitment..
content.name: Assets Exposures Lending Commitments Excluding Revolving Credit New 391 Amount

content.definition:
This is the value of new lending commitments, or firm offers, in the form of revolving credit loans provided by the reporting party during the relevant period, regardless of whether or not they have subsequently been withdrawn, or cancelled, during or after the period.

A commitment is a firm offer to provide finance which has been accepted by the client. A commitment exists once the loan application has been approved, and a loan contract or letter of offer has been issued to the borrower. 

Revolving credit facilities involve a commitment for a credit or borrowing limit and where the extent of the borrowings used at any one time may be for any amount up to the authorised limit. Repayments (other than of changes and interest) reduce the borrowings thereby increasing the amount of unused credit available.

With transactions involving a change of residence, you should treat the discharge of the existing loan and the commitment to a new loan as separate events, and report the total value of the new loan as a new commitment..
content.name: Assets Exposures Lending Commitments Revolving Credit New 391 Amount

content.definition:
This is a balancing item.
                                                                                                                                                 
This is the amount of any discrepancy between the total credit limits approved for revolving credit reported in the previous relevant period and the amounts reported on the APRA 394.0 series of forms.
content.name: Assets Exposures Balancing Item APRA Form 394 Amount

content.definition:
This is a description of a balancing item.
                                                                                                                                                 
This is the reason for any discrepancy between the total credit limits approved for revolving credit reported in the previous relevant period and the amounts reported on the APRA 394.0 series of forms.
content.name: Assets Exposures Balancing Item APRA Form 394 Text

content.definition: This is the value, as at the relevant date, of applicable assets to be reported on the APRA form GRF_110_0_G 'Capital Adequacy'. This includes assets listed under APRA form GRF_300_0_G Statement of Financial Position. This excludes derivatives and other assets that are subject to a risk charge under the APRA forms GRF_141_0_G and GRF_301_0_G.
content.name: Financial Risk Capital Adequacy Assets GRF 110 G Amount

content.definition:
This is the value, for the duration of the relevant period, of realised and unrealised capital gains/losses associated with the entity's investments.

This item does not include foreign currency gains (losses) that occur due to currency translation.

Capital gains/losses are realised where the entity disposed of an asset during the relevant period. If an asset has not been disposed of during the relevant annual period, then any gains or losses recognised as the difference between the acquisition cost of the asset and the market value are unrealised.
content.name: Profit Or Loss Investment Total Realised And Unrealised Excluding Foreign Exchange Amount

content.definition: This is the value, for the duration of the relevant period, of other operating expense. This item represents all expense which is not associated with the generation of investment income (i.e. expenses that are not related to investment portfolios) on assets backing insurance liabilities (ABI. This item is determined in accordance with relevant accounting standards.
content.name: Expense Operating other Not Investment On Assets Backing Insurance Liabilities Amount

content.definition:
This is the value of the reporting party's total on and off balance sheet exposure to Office commercial property.
     
Commercial property exposure is defined according to the nature of the risk. An exposure should be classified as commercial property risk, if the exposure is subject to the performance of the property market.
     
For reporting purposes, an exposure exists when a facility has been provided for the development, acquisition or improvement of office buildings, and the servicing and repayment of the facility is dependent on the cash flows generated by the office property itself through sale or rental income, and/or from cash flows generated from other office properties owned by the borrower.
content.name: Financial Risk Market Exposure Property Office Amount

content.definition:
This is the value of the reporting party's total  on and off balance sheet exposure to Retail commercial property.
     
Commercial property exposure is defined according to the nature of the risk. An exposure should be classified as commercial property risk, if the exposure is subject to the performance of the property market.
     
For reporting purposes, an exposure exists when a facility has been provided for the development, acquisition or improvement of retail buildings, and the servicing and repayment of the facility is dependent on the cash flows generated by the retail property itself through sale or rental income, and/or from cash flows generated from other retail properties owned by the borrower.
content.name: Financial Risk Market Exposure Property Retail Amount

content.definition:
This is the value of the reporting party's total on and off balance sheet exposure to industrial commercial property.
     
Commercial property exposure is defined according to the nature of the risk. An exposure should be classified as commercial property risk, if the exposure is subject to the performance of the property market.
     
For reporting purposes, an exposure exists when a facility has been provided for the development, acquisition or improvement of Industrial property, and the servicing and repayment of the facility is dependent on the cash flows generated by the Industrial property itself through sale or rental income, and/or from cash flows generated from other Industrial properties owned by the borrower.

Industrial commercial property may include for example, warehouses and factories.
content.name: Financial Risk Market Exposure Property Industrial Amount

content.definition:
This is the value of the reporting party's total  on and off balance sheet commercial property exposure to land development and subdivision.
     
Commercial property exposure is defined according to the nature of the risk. An exposure should be classified as commercial property risk, if the exposure is subject to the performance of the property market.
     
For reporting purposes, an exposure exists when a facility has been provided for the development and/or subdivision of land, and the servicing and repayment of the facility is dependent on the cash flows generated through sale of the land, and/or from cash flows generated from other land development or subdivision activity owned by the borrower.
content.name: Financial Risk Market Exposure Property Land Development Amount

content.definition:
This is the value of the reporting party's total  on and off balance sheet exposure to residential commercial property.
     
Commercial property exposure is defined according to the nature of the risk. An exposure should be classified as commercial property risk, if the exposure is subject to the performance of the property market.
     
For reporting purposes, an exposure exists when a facility has been provided for the development, acquisition or improvement of residential buildings, and the servicing and repayment of the facility is dependent on the cash flows generated by the commercial residential property itself through sale or rental income, and/or from cash flows generated from other commercial residential properties owned by the borrower.
     
Commercial residential property exposure is that related to property used for housing but not for owner occupied housing or loans to households for investment residential property.
content.name: Financial Risk Market Exposure Property Commercial Residential Amount

content.definition:
This is the value of the reporting party's total on and off balance sheet exposure to tourism and leisure commercial property.
     
Commercial property exposure is defined according to the nature of the risk. An exposure should be classified as commercial property risk, if the exposure is subject to the performance of the property market.
     
For reporting purposes, an exposure exists when a facility has been provided for the development, acquisition or improvement of land and buildings used in the tourism and leisure or hospitality industries, and the servicing and repayment of the facility is dependent on the cash flows generated by the property itself through sale or rental income, and/or from cash flows generated from other tourism and leisure properties owned by the borrower.

Tourism & leisure commercial property may include for example, hotels, motels and lodgings, recreational and sporting facilities, hotel developments, time-share developments and other hospitality industries.
content.name: Financial Risk Market Exposure Property Leisure Amount

content.definition:
This is a balancing item in the list in which it is being used.
     
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of the reporting party's on and off balance sheet exposure to other commercial property, as required to be reported on APRA form ARF_230_0.
     
Commercial property exposure is defined according to the nature of the risk. An exposure should be classified as commercial property risk, if the exposure is subject to the performance of the property market.
content.name: Financial Risk Market Exposure Property Commercial Other ARF 230 0 Amount

content.definition:
This is the value of the reporting party's total  on and off balance sheet exposure to commercial property.
     
Commercial property exposure is defined according to the nature of the risk. An exposure should be classified as commercial property risk, if the exposure is subject to the performance of the property market.
     
For reporting purposes, an exposure exists when a facility has been provided for the development, acquisition or improvement of commercial property, and the servicing and repayment of the facility is dependent on the cash flows generated by the property itself through sale or rental income, and/or from cash flows generated from other commercial properties owned by the borrower.
content.name: Financial Risk Market Exposure Property Commercial Amount

content.definition:
This is the value of provisions for impairment of the reporting party's exposure to Office commercial property.
     
Commercial property exposure is defined according to the nature of the risk. An exposure should be classified as commercial property risk, if the exposure is subject to the performance of the property market.
     
For reporting purposes, an exposure exists when a facility has been provided for the development, acquisition or improvement of office buildings, and the servicing and repayment of the facility is dependent on the cash flows generated by the office property itself through sale or rental income, and/or from cash flows generated from other office properties owned by the borrower.
content.name: Financial Risk Market Exposure Property Office Impairment Amount

content.definition:
This is the value of provisions for impairment of the reporting party's exposure to Retail commercial property.
     
Commercial property exposure is defined according to the nature of the risk. An exposure should be classified as commercial property risk, if the exposure is subject to the performance of the property market.
     
For reporting purposes, an exposure exists when a facility has been provided for the development, acquisition or improvement of retail buildings, and the servicing and repayment of the facility is dependent on the cash flows generated by the retail property itself through sale or rental income, and/or from cash flows generated from other retail properties owned by the borrower.
content.name: Financial Risk Market Exposure Property Retail Impairment Amount

content.definition:
This is the value of provisions for impairment of the reporting party's exposure to industrial commercial property.
     
Commercial property exposure is defined according to the nature of the risk. An exposure should be classified as commercial property risk, if the exposure is subject to the performance of the property market.
     
For reporting purposes, an exposure exists when a facility has been provided for the development, acquisition or improvement of Industrial property, and the servicing and repayment of the facility is dependent on the cash flows generated by the Industrial property itself through sale or rental income, and/or from cash flows generated from other Industrial properties owned by the borrower.

Industrial commercial property may include for example, warehouses and factories.
content.name: Financial Risk Market Exposure Property Industrial Impairment Amount

content.definition:
This is the value of provisions for impairment of the reporting party's commercial property exposure to land development and subdivision.
     
Commercial property exposure is defined according to the nature of the risk. An exposure should be classified as commercial property risk, if the exposure is subject to the performance of the property market.
     
For reporting purposes, an exposure exists when a facility has been provided for the development and/or subdivision of land, and the servicing and repayment of the facility is dependent on the cash flows generated through sale of the land, and/or from cash flows generated from other land development or subdivision activity owned by the borrower.

content.definition:
This is the value, as at the relevant date, of all assets of the reporting party that are not designated as "Loans and Advances" or "Debt Securities".
                                                                                                                                                       
Debt securities are transferable instruments evidencing a relationship of indebtedness. It is characterised by having a definable return that is not based on the economic performance of the issuing entity.

Loans and Advances are, for the purposes of this item, defined as those financial assets listed below:

- any financial assets that are created through the lending of funds by a creditor (lender) to a debtor (borrower) and that are not represented by negotiable securities, including interbank borrowings, loans and inter-office balances; 
- foreign trade-related credits; 
- holdings of international notes and coins that are in circulation
- international loans granted and deposits made on a trust basis
- Sale and repurchase transactions (repos)
- financial leases 
- promissory notes
- non-negotiable debt securities
-  endorsement liabilities arising from bills rediscounted abroad
- subordinated loans (including subordinated non-negotiable debt securities)
- Loans which have become negotiable de facto should be classified under debt securities (For doing so there needs to be evidence of a secondary market trading.)
content.name: Assets Not Loans Advances Debt Securities Amount

content.definition:
This is the value of all liabilities of the reporting party as at the relevant date that are not designated as Deposits or Debt Securities (own issues).
                                                                                                                                   
Deposits are funds that are redeemable or withdrawable by depositors from the reporting party. This item is to be determined in accordance with accounting standards.
